title: Hawksbill Summit via Upper Hawksbill Trailhead
listingDescription: Upper Hawksbill Parking Area (mile 46.5) | A hike to the top of Shenandoah’s highest peak, offering 360-degree views of the Shenandoah Valley, the Blue Ridge Mountains, and the Virginia Piedmont.

images.altText: A view over a line of trees with mountains descending into a rural valley below.
images.title: Upper Hawksbill Trailhead
images.caption: Take in a nearly 360 degree view of Shenandoah from the highest mountain in the Park.

bodyText:
A hike to the top of Shenandoah’s highest peak, offering 360-degree views of the Shenandoah Valley, the Blue Ridge Mountains, and the Virginia Piedmont. Pets must be on a physical leash no longer than 6 feet at all times.

Note that very limited closures are in effect in an effort to prevent further degradation of important outcrop ecosystems on Hawksbill.

Distance: 2.1-mile round trip hike
Difficulty: Easiest (hiking difficulty scale)
Hiking Time: 1 hour 30 minutes
Elevation Gain: 520 feet
 

Hike Description 

  1. From the trailhead at the Upper Hawksbill Parking Area (mile 46.5), take the Upper Hawksbill Trail to Byrds Nest 2 Shelter.
  2. Follow the trail to the stone viewing platform.
  3. Retrace your steps to return.
audioDescription: The Upper Hawksbill Trailhead panel is a 36 by 54 inch color poster. On the upper left of the panel is a photograph taken at the summit of the trail that shows the gnarled tree and shrub growth between exposed boulders in these harsh conditions. The text reads, "Hunkering Down: It's harsher - colder, icier, windier - up high, and to adapt, trees and shrubs on Hawksbill hug the warmer-than-air ground and grow gnarled, at a wedge-like angle. They've had to be tough to adapt to harsher conditions on this summit. But adaptation is stressful, so they are fragile - tread lightly. The balsam firs and red spruce you see on Hawskbill summit are boreal, or northern, trees; they thrive in New England-like climates. These species were more widespread in the Blue Ridge Mountains in the last ice age, but now that the climate is warmer, they have retreated to a few high-elevation spots, like Hawksbill." The picture on the bottom left of the panel is a beautiful blue cerulean warbler on a a bare gray tree branch. The text reads, "The Times They Are A-changin': Change may be the only constant, but in regards to climate, some change is natural and some is not. The retreat of these cold loving plants as the last ice ice segued into warmer times was organic - unrelated to any workings of humans. The same is not true of what we face today. Climate change over the past century owes much to humans and our waste-emitting cars and industry. Climate change begets other changes that affect sensitive animal and plant life. The cerulean warbler, whose numbers have decreased by 70%, depends on the delicately timed, weather driven balance of insect emergence. Reducing carbon emissions can't come too soon." The top right of the panel is a 20 by 20 inch topographic map of the hike to Hawksbill Summit and Observation Platform. The trail is marked in yellow with a brown dashed line. The text reads, "Suggested Hike: Hike: Upper Hawksbill; 2.1 mile round trip, easiest, 1.5 hours hiking time, 520-foot elevation gain. Take Upper Hawksbill Trail to Byrds Nest 2 Shelter and continue on road, following signs to the summit. From the summit, retrace your steps to return to the starting point. Camping is not allowed on Hawksbill summit. Byrds Nest 2 Shelter is for day use only." A red text box below the map gives important information that hikers need. The text reads, "Emergency 1-800-732-0911 (cell phone service is unreliable.) Before You Go! Pets must be on a leash at all times. Be sure you are physically able to complete the hike you've chosen. Take plenty of water - at least a quart per hour Be sure you know your route. Free maps are available at entrance stations, visitor centers, and www.nps.gov/shen When you return from your hike, check for ticks. Stay on the trail and avoid trampling sensitive vegetation. Be sure someone knows where you are and when to expect your return." A Hiking Difficulty Scale reads: "Easiest - A hike that is generally suitable for anyone who enjoys walking. Mostly level or with a slight incline. Generally less than 3 miles. Moderate - A moderate hike generally suitable for novice hikers seeking a bit of a challenge. The terrain will involve a moderate incline and may have some steeper sections. Generally 3 to 5 miles. Moderately Strenuous - Generally challenging for an unconditioned person. The terrain will involve a steady and often steep incline. Generally 5 to 8 miles. Strenuous - Will challenge most hikers. The hike will generally be longer and steeper, but may be deemed strenuous because of the elevation gain. Generally 7 to 10 miles. Very Strenuous - Only well-conditioned and well-prepared hikers should attempt. Generally long and steep, and may include rock scrambling, stream crossings, and other challenging terrain. Generally 8 miles and over."

title: Hazel Mountain Overlook
listingDescription: Looking southeast from an elevation of 2,770 ft (844 m), the view from Hazel Mountain Overlook includes the granodiorite rock formation and Hazel Mountain in the distance

images.altText: View of tree atop rock formation with hills in the distance.
images.title: Hazel Mountain Overlook

bodyText: Looking southeast from an elevation of 2,770 ft (844 m), the view from Hazel Mountain Overlook includes the granodiorite rock formation and Hazel Mountain in the distance. Granodiorite forms miles under the surface and makes up the base of the Blue Ridge Mountains in Shenandoah National Park.
audioDescription: This overlook faces southeast. There is a rock formation in the foreground with a tree atop it. Beyond the rock formation is Buck Ridge, a long ridge running across most of the view. Beyond Buck Ridge in the distance is Hazel Mountain.

title: Hazel River Falls Trailhead
listingDescription: Meadow Spring Parking Area (mile 33.5) | A trail that leads you through a rugged section of the Park to an exceptional waterfall.

images.altText: A tree silhouette from a scenic, forested overlook against a pink sunrise.
images.title: Hazel Mountain Overlook

bodyText:
A trail that leads you through a rugged section of the Park to an exceptional waterfall. Pets must be on a physical leash no longer than 6 feet at all times.

Distance: 5.3-mile round trip hike
Difficulty: Moderate (hiking difficulty scale)
Hiking Time: 5 hours
Elevation Gain: 1,070 feet

Hike Description

  1. From Meadow Spring Parking Area (mile 33.5), take the yellow-blazed Hazel Mountain Trail past the Buck Ridge Trail.
  2. At the fork, go left onto the yellow-blazed White Rocks Trail.
  3. At the next trailpost, go right and continue to two small waterfalls.
  4. Turn around and retrace your steps back to the parking area.

title: Hazeltop Ridge Overlook
listingDescription: Gaze upon the Blue Ridge Mountains from Hazeltop Ridge Overlook. The view from this overlook stretches from the northwest to the southwest.

images.altText: View of field with trees in distance and mountain ridges extending to the horizon.
images.title: Hazeltop Ridge Overlook

bodyText: Gaze upon the Blue Ridge Mountains from Hazeltop Ridge Overlook. The view from this overlook stretches from the northwest to the southwest.
audioDescription: This overlook faces west. There is a field that expands to a line of trees. Beyond the trees are the ridges of the Blue Ridge Mountains with a sliver of the Shenandoah Valley in the distance. From the left are Hanse Mountain, Powell Mountain, Grindstone Mountain, Smith Mountain, Devils Tanyard, and Long Ridge.

title: Hemlock Springs Overlook
listingDescription: Facing east from an elevation of 3,380 ft (1030 m), Hemlock Springs Overlook is a great place to contemplate the dynamic nature of the forest.

images.altText: View over large brush out to mountains beyond.
images.title: Hemlock Spring Overlook

bodyText: Facing east from an elevation of 3,380 ft (1030 m), Hemlock Springs Overlook is a great place to contemplate the dynamic nature of the forest. The ridge to the right is home to a few eastern hemlock trees once very common in Shenandoah. Most of the Eastern Hemlocks were killed by an invasive pest called the hemlock woolly adelgid. Nicholson Hollow is below you, with Pinnacle Ridge rising above.
audioDescription: This overlook faces east. In the foreground is shrubs and vegetation. Beyond the vegetation is a drop in elevation that leads to Nicholson Hollow. Mountains rise up past Nicholson Hollow. Pinnacle Ridge straight ahead is the highest mountain. Hazel Mountain is a small dome in the distance. There is an interpretive sign at this overlook. The Hemlock Springs Overlook interpretive sign is a 36 by 24 inch color graphic panel on a dark metal frame angled towards the viewer. The poster is split horizontally with the title and body text in the lower third. The title text reads, "Lost Treasures." The body text reads, "The eastern hemlock tree holds a special place in the hearts of Appalachian dwellers. Birds such as the Blackburnian warbler and the winter wren find homes in hemlock forests. Brook trout thrive in cold mountain streams sheltered from sun by the hemlock's shade. Shenandoah residents and visitors treasured the enchanting old growth stands at Hemlock Springs, Limberlost, and Rapidan Camp (where some of the hemlocks were over 300 years old). We'll never experience that magic again. Ninety-five percent of Shenandoah's hemlocks are gone, killed by an invasive pest called the hemlock woolly adelgid. Park scientists use chemical and biological treatments to protect the remaining hemlock trees. The gray, broken tree trunks of Hemlock Springs remind us of the hundreds of thousands already lost and the ecosystems forever changed." Above the title are two images, one on the left half and one on the right half of the poster. The image to the left has the date "1968" printed on it and shows a sepia colored images with full, healthy Hemlock trees on it. The image to the right has the date "2014" printed on it and shows a sepia colored image of a slope covered with bare, dead trees. In the middle of the two is an orange box with a close up image of Hemlock needles covered near the branch with a white substance. The text for this image reads, "The aphid-like hemlock woolly adelgid builds white cottony egg sacks at the base of hemlock needles, where it feeds on the tree's sap. This kills the needles, thereby starving the tree and killing it. A hemlock tree will live about three to five years after an adelgid infestation." On the lower third of the image to the right of the title is brown box with four photographs in it. The title for this small box reads, "History Repeats Itself." Text under the title reads, "Non-native blights, insects, and diseases, introduced into the ecosystem by human activity, have caused dramatic changes in the Shenandoah forest." Each of the four photographs is numbered with the corresponding text. Image one shows a shiny green beetle on a leaf with the text, "1. The emerald ash borer threatens Shenandoah's ash trees today." Image two shows three creamy white flowers against a blue background with the text, "2. Dogwood anthracnose disease has caused the number of dogwood trees to dwindle since the 1970s." Image three shows a fuzzy, brown, caterpillar with the text, "Gypsy moths decimated white oak trees in the 1980s and 1990s." Image four is a black and white picture of a forest of dead, fallen trees with the text, "A blight killed American chestnut trees in the early 1900s." A black bar on the top of the graphic reads "Shenandoah National Park" on the left and on the right is the National Park Service Arrowhead symbol with the text "National Park Service/U.S. Department of the Interior"

title: Hensley Hollow Overlook
listingDescription: Look north from an elevation of 2,560 ft (780 m) at Hensley Hollow Overlook and view the Shenandoah Valley below. Beyond Hensley Ridge is the town of Elkton, Virginia.

images.altText: View across field with line of trees and foothills in the distance.
images.title: Hensley Hollow Overlook

bodyText:
Look north from an elevation of 2,560 ft (780 m) at Hensley Hollow Overlook and view the Shenandoah Valley below. Beyond Hensley Ridge is the town of Elkton, Virginia. In 1812 a man named George Conrad built a general store near where the Elk Run stream intersects with the Shenandoah River. The community that followed was referred to as Conrad's Store until the official incorporation in 1908, when the town became Elkton.

Maintenance of this view funded by Rockingham County Tourism through the Shenandoah National Park Trust Adopt an Overlook program.
audioDescription: This overlook faces north. There is an open meadow with a line of trees surrounding the meadow in the distance. Beyond the trees are ridges of the Blue Ridge Mountains descending into the Shenandoah Valley below. Hensley Hollow, straight ahead, is the lower portions of the hills where the ridges descend and meet in the middle. From the left are Hensley Ridge and Lick Hollow. Beyond the Shenandoah Valley is the long ridge of Massanutten Mountain spanning the horizon.

title: Highest Point on Skyline Drive
listingDescription: Mile 41.7, just at the northern entrance to Skyland is the highest point on Skyline Drive at 3,680 feet. The highest point in Shenandoah is the summit of Hawksbill Mountain at 4,050 feet. Getting to the summit entails a relatively short hike of less than 2 miles.

images.altText: A wooden routed sign indicating the highest point on Skyland Drive at elevation 3680.
images.title: Highest point along Skyline Drive
images.caption: The highest point along Skyline Drive is at the entrance to Skyland at mile 41.7.

bodyText: Mile 41.7, just at the northern entrance to Skyland is the highest point on Skyline Drive at 3,680 feet. The highest point in Shenandoah is the summit of Hawksbill Mountain at 4,050 feet. Getting to the summit entails a relatively short hike of less than 2 miles.
audioDescription: A brown wooden sign on two posts that reads, "Highest point on Skyline Drive, elevation 3680 ft"

title: Hightop Summit Trailhead
listingDescription: Hightop Mountain Parking Area (mile 66.7) | Wind your way up a ridge on this hike to a rocky viewpoint that stands at 3,296 feet.

images.altText: Snow covered rocks lie in the foreground of a view into a blue valley below.
images.title: Hightop Summit in the Snow

bodyText:
Wind your way up a ridge on this hike to a rocky viewpoint that stands at 3,296 feet. Pets must be on a physical leash no longer than 6 feet at all times.

Distance: 3-mile round trip hike
Difficulty: Moderate (explanation of our hiking difficulty scale)
Hiking Time: 3 hours
Elevation Gain: 935 feet

Hike Description

  1. From the Hightop Mountain Parking Area (mile 66.7), cross Skyline Drive and take the white-blazed Appalachian Trail (A.T.)
  2. As you climb, the trail winds its way up the ridge.
  3. You’ll swing left around the summit, then look for a side trail on your right that leads to a rocky viewpoint.
  4. Turn around and retrace your steps to return to the parking area.

title: Hogback Overlook
listingDescription: Looking north from an elevation of 3,385 ft (1031 m), Hogback Overlook extends 0.2 miles along Skyline Drive, making it the longest overlook in the park.

images.altText: Expansive view from overlook with ridge descending to valley below.
images.title: Hogback Overlook

bodyText: Looking north from an elevation of 3,385 ft (1031 m), Hogback Overlook extends 0.2 miles along Skyline Drive, making it the longest overlook in the Park. Straight ahead is Gimlet Ridge. Gimlet Ridge veers left and descends into the Shenandoah Valley. Veering right from Gimlet Ridge is Mathews Arm. Far in the distance, on a clear day, you may see the Allegheny Mountains.
audioDescription: This overlook faces north. Straight ahead is Gimlet Ridge that veers left and descends into the Shenandoah Valley. Veering right from Gimlet Ridge is Mathews Arm. In the distance is Massanutten Mountain, followed by the Valley and Ridge Appalachians. Further in the distance, on a clear day, the Allegheny Mountains stretch across the distant horizon. There is an interpretive sign at this overlook. The Hogback Overlook interpretive sign is a 36 by 24 inch color graphic panel on a dark metal frame angled towards the viewer. The title text reads, "On the Horizon." The body text reads, "Shenandoah National Park's stunning vistas are the reason many of you are here. Unfortunately, these views are often marred by air pollution. Small particles of pollutants suspended in the atmosphere create haze-a white or brownish veil over the scene that smudges it and scrubs it of its colors, shapes, and textures, eroding your ability to see and enjoy it. Although dust, fog, wildfire smoke, moisture-emitting plants and trees, and natural atmospheric humidity create some of this haze, particles from human sources such as coal-fired power plants, agriculture, industry, and vehicle exhaust account for much of it. Air pollution at Shenandoah National Park has many sources, both local and-because of wind and weather patterns-from at least four other states besides Virginia: West Virginia, Pennsylvania, Kentucky, and Ohio. Here at Hogback Overlook, the quality of the air affects how well-or even if-you can see other ridges and hollows in the Park, the Shenandoah Valley, and the Massanutten and Allegheny Mountains beyond. The National Park Service monitors visibility conditions in Shenandoah and other parks, investigates the causes of haze, and works with air regulatory agencies and partners to lessen the effects of air pollution. These large-scale efforts have paid off: due to reductions in power plant emissions, Shenandoah National Park has seen fewer extremely hazy days. Small-scale, more personal efforts- reducing our dependence on fossil fuels and being more mindful of how we live-will do even more to help us see even farther." Behind the text is an image taken from a higher elevation looking down to the mountains below. It is a winter image, there is some snow on the ground and none of the trees have leaves. In the distance is the Shenandoah Valley below with haze into the horizon. To the right of the text is a blue box with two color photographs of an Air Quality Station and the title text, "Tracking Changes Over Time." The image on the left shows a white, square building with scientific instruments around it. The image on the right shows a white table with buckets and scientific instruments on top of it. The text accompanying the images reads, "Shenandoah's air quality monitoring programs have been providing data for 30 years, giving scientists some of the most valuable information available about trends in air quality over time. Scientists across the nation use Shenandoah's data to advise protection agencies and lawmakers. Historical records show that when strong regulations are in place, the quality of our air improves." A black bar on the top of the graphic reads "Shenandoah National Park" on the left and on the right is the National Park Service Arrowhead symbol with the text "National Park Service/U.S. Department of the Interior"

title: Hogwallow Flats Overlook
listingDescription: Hogwallow Falts Overlook faces southeast from an elevation of 2,665 ft (812 m). You are looking down to Rappahannock County and the town of Flint Hill.

images.altText: View over hedge of valley and mountain to the right.
images.title: Hogwallow Flat Overlook

bodyText: Hogwallow Falts Overlook faces southeast from an elevation of 2,665 ft (812 m). You are looking down to Rappahannock County and the town of Flint Hill. Flint Hill was founded in 1836 and by the 1840s and 1850s became prosperous from tobacco production, largely aided by the labor of enslaved African-Americans. When a train was constructed in nearby Wentzville, Flint Hill's production began to slow. Rappahannock County remains an agricultural region to this day.
audioDescription: This overlook faces southeast over the Piedmont region into Rappahannock County. The town of Flint Hill is visible straight ahead, while to the right is Mount Marshall. There is an interpretive sign at this overlook. The Hogwallow Flats Overlook interpretive sign is a 36 by 24 inch color graphic panel on a dark metal frame angled towards the viewer. The title text reads, "Beneath the Treetops." The body text reads, "From here, the forest looks peaceful. But underneath the treetops, Shenandoah is busy. Native oaks, hickories, maples, poplars, and other plant species provide food and shelter for Shenandoah's animals. With 1,325 plant species, over 340 vertebrates, and a multitude of invertebrates, this forest is a lively place! This diversity is a sign of success: Shenandoah's forests are healthy communities that support the animals and plants that call this place home." In the background is an image from above looking down on the forest below. In the distance is the Shenandoah Valley. On the lower third of the graphic are five circles, each with a photograph of an animal in it and text below it. From the left, the first image is a millipede crawls atop green vegetation. The text reads, "American giant millipedes eat the decaying vegetation and organic matter that covers the forest floor. They are one of the thousands of species that "clean" the forest; millipedes are also a food source for turkeys, chipmunks, and bears." The second image is a chipmunk standing on a log with its hands together looking to the right. The text reads, "Agile chipmunks dart up, down, and around tree trunks on their way between burrows, hiding places, and food caches. Chipmunks thrive in hardwood forests due to the variety of foods-seeds, nuts, and insects-found throughout the seasons." The third image shows the head of a black bear surrounded by ferns looking straight toward the viewer. The text reads, "Black bears prefer the shelter of the hardwood forest to open fields because they can hide in the dense underbrush while they hunt for berries, nuts, and insects." The forth image shows the head of a deer with large antlers in an area of tall grass looking to the left. The text reads, "White-tailed deer browse the tender leaves of dozens of grass and leafy plant species. They love acorns, something that is abundant in oak-hickory forests like Shenandoah." The fifth image shows a bird with a black head, white breast, and brown wings. The bird has its mouth open and head pointed up. The text reads, "The Eastern towhee's song- "Drink your tea-e-e-e-e"-trills across Shenandoah's forest in the morning and evening hours. The ground-dwelling bird builds its nest in the underbrush from the abundant leaf litter." A black bar on the top of the graphic reads "Shenandoah National Park" on the left and on the right is the National Park Service Arrowhead symbol with the text "National Park Service/U.S. Department of the Interior"

title: Horsehead Overlook
listingDescription: Look northwest to the Shenandoah Valley from an elevation of 2,580 ft (786 m) at Horsehead Overlook. You are looking into Augusta County in the southern Shenandoah Valley.

images.altText: A view over tall bushes to hills and valley beyond.
images.title: Horsehead Overlook

bodyText: Look northwest to the Shenandoah Valley from an elevation of 2,580 ft (786 m) at Horsehead Overlook. You are looking into Augusta County in the southern Shenandoah Valley. Augusta County was formed in 1738 and named after Augusta of Saxe-Gotha, Princess of Wales and mother of future King George III.
audioDescription: This overlook faces northwest. For much of the year there are tall bushes and shrubs blocking the view. Over the vegetation there is Rocks Mountain descending from the left and Trayfoot Mountain descending from the right. Horsehead Mountain is a smaller mountain straight ahead. Beyond the mountains is the Shenandoah Valley stretching to the horizon. There is an interpretive sign at this overlook. The Horsehead Overlook interpretive sign is a 36 by 24 inch color graphic panel on a dark metal frame angled towards the viewer. The graphic is divided vertically with the title and body text on the left quarter of the graphic on top of a transparent gray background. The title text reads, "Rock Rivers." The body text reads, "The bare patches you see in the distance seem bleak and immobile. In fact, talus is an agent of change, a rock river flowing down the mountainside at an imperceptibly slow pace. Talus forms when the freeze and thaw cycle breaks off pieces of exposed bedrock. These pieces, some as big as cars, fall together into a stream of rock (see illustrations to the right). Additional weathering breaks the large chunks into smaller pieces, which continue falling downhill. When the rocks stop moving, soil accumulates and plants take root and cover the rocks." In the middle of the body text is an image with a white border of a slope covered in trees with a few bare gaps in the trees. The right section of the graphic contains a photograph of a person atop a rocky slope. The lower portion of the right section contains three illustrations on a transparent black background. The illustrations, from the left, show a group of large rocks, then the group of rock cracks and separates a bit, then the rocks are crumbled to pieces. The text accompanying the illustrations reads, "Even without soil, talus supports an ecosystem. Lichen grows on rock surfaces. Reptiles and rodents find shelter in the crevices. Predators like bobcats stalk the rocks, waiting for a tasty meal to appear between the cracks." A black bar on the top of the graphic reads "Shenandoah National Park" on the left and on the right is the National Park Service Arrowhead symbol with the text "National Park Service/U.S. Department of the Interior"

title: Indian Run Overlook
listingDescription: Indian Run Overlook faces east and sits at an elevation of 2,400 ft (731 m). Indian Run is a stream that has formed the hill in front of you through the slow process of erosion.

images.altText: View of ridge slowly descending to meet valley below.
images.title: Indian Run Overlook

bodyText: Indian Run Overlook faces east and sits at an elevation of 2,400 ft (731 m). Indian Run is a stream that has formed the hill in front of you through the slow process of erosion.
audioDescription: This overlook faces east to a ridge that descends from the left and meets the valley below to the right. Out toward the horizon on the right is the flatter Piedmont region of Virginia.

title: Iron Mike Statue
listingDescription: Iron Mike stands outside Byrd Visitor Center. This statue was donated to the Park to honor the young men in the Civilian Conservation Corps who, together, built much of the infrastructure of Shenandoah National Park still in use today.

images.altText: A color photograph of an iron statue of man wearing work clothes and leaning on an ax handle.
images.title: Iron Mike Statue
images.caption: A tribute to the young men of the Civilian Conservation Corps

bodyText: Iron Mike stands outside Byrd Visitor Center. This statue was donated to the Park to honor the young men in the Civilian Conservation Corps who, together, built much of the infrastructure of Shenandoah National Park still in use today.
audioDescription: Iron Mike is a cast iron statue standing outside Byrd Visitor Center. The statue depicts a young man wearing work pants and boots, and holding his shirt in his left hand and an ax that he is leaning on in his right hand. There is a plaque to the left of Iron Mike mounted to a rock on the ground. The plaque reads, "Between 1933 and 1942 more than 10,000 young men served in the Civilian Conservation Corps Camps in Shenandoah National Park. These 'boys' created the form and fabric of the new park so that future generations could find recreation and re-creation here. The statue of 'Iron Mike' was given by the Barlow family to honor the CCC and their parents, Russell Thompson Barlow and Louise Painter Barlow."

title: Ivy Creek Overlook
listingDescription: Facing east from an elevation of 2,890 ft (880 m), you will look out to the rolling ridges of Shenandoah National Park from Ivy Creek Overlook. The Appalachian Trail intersects with this overlook, as well.

images.altText: A view with grass in the foreground and mountains in the distance.
images.title: Ivy Creek Overlook

bodyText:
Facing east from an elevation of 2,890 ft (880 m), you will look out to the rolling ridges of Shenandoah National Park from Ivy Creek Overlook. Weaver Mountain descends from the left, while Loft Mountain descends from the right. Straight ahead is Flattop Mountain. The Appalachian Trail intersects with this overlook, as well.

Maintenance of this view funded Greene County and Hugh and Temple Joyce through the Shenandoah National Park Trust Adopt an Overlook program.
audioDescription: This long overlook faces east. There is a line of shrubs and vegetation in the foreground and mountains rising in the distance. Descending from the left is Weaver Mountain. Flattop Mountain is straight ahead in the distance, Brokenback Mountain is to the right of Flattop and further in the distance, and Loft Mountain is rising off to the right. The flat Virginia Piedmont spans the horizon. There is an interpretive sign at this overlook. The Ivy Creek Overlook interpretive sign is a 36 by 24 inch color graphic panel on a dark metal frame angled towards the viewer. The graphic is split vertically with the title and body text in front of a green background on the left side. The title text reads, "Escape Route." The body text reads, "Stretching over 2,180 miles, the Appalachian Trail (A.T.) crosses 14 states, five national parks, seven national forests, and numerous state parks and towns between Maine and Georgia. A physically daunting task, the climbing required in hiking the entire length of the A.T. is the equivalent of Mt. Everest-16 times. Hikers finish with strong legs and renewed spirits. Benton MacKaye, Myron Avery, and other hikers created the A.T. in the 1930s so that Americans could escape busy modern life for a minimalist adventure in nature. Whether hiking for one day or many, today's A.T. visitors enjoy the trail for the same reason. One hundred and one miles of the A.T. pass through Shenandoah National Park. This stretch forms the backbone of the Park's trail system. From the A.T., hikers of all abilities can access other Shenandoah trails to reach Wilderness, mountain peaks, waterfalls, adventure, and solitude." To the left of the body text is a photograph of an Appalachian Trail marker: a concrete post with an AT symbol engraved into it and a metal band around the top of it. The right side of the graphic has a photograph of a hiker walking along a trail in the woods wearing a large backpack. On the lower third of the right side of the image is a horizontal panel with three images. From the left the first image shows a woman holding a pickax about to hit the ground. The second image shows three people arranging a log on a trail. The third image shows a man sawing a fallen tree. The text accompanying these images reads, "Volunteers built the A.T. using handsaws, shovels, and axes. They finished in 1937. Volunteers continue to form the core of the A.T. workforce. Over 30 hiking clubs and 6,000 individual volunteers donate over 200,000 hours of trail work every year, using the same hand tools as the first crew of volunteers. The Potomac Appalachian Trail Club takes care of the A.T. in Shenandoah, and assists with other Park trails as well." To the right of this text is the Potomac Appalachian Trail Club logo: a red, yellow, and turquoise symbol with trees in the foreground, mountains in the distance, and the decorative letters, PATC. A black bar on the top of the graphic reads "Shenandoah National Park" on the left and on the right is the National Park Service Arrowhead symbol with the text "National Park Service/U.S. Department of the Interior"

title: Jenkins Gap Overlook
listingDescription: Jenkins Gap Overlook peers onto the Piedmont from a small window above the v-shaped intersection of two hills. Looking east, and at an elevation of 2,355 ft (717 m), you are peering into a hollow formed by the Bolton Branch of the Burgess River.

images.altText: View from overlook of hills in the foreground and a small section of flat land out to horizon.
images.title: Jenkins Gap Overlook

bodyText: Jenkins Gap Overlook peers onto the Piedmont from a small window above the intersection of two hills. Looking east, and at an elevation of 2,355 ft (717 m), you are peering into a hollow formed by the Bolton Branch of the Burgess River. Jenkins Gap is named after the Jenkins families that were displaced from their homes within the boundaries of what became Shenandoah National Park.
audioDescription: This overlook faces east with the Compton Peak rising from the left in the foreground and a smaller hill on the right. These two hills are descending toward the middle of the view. Between the hills there is a small section of flatter land, the Piedmont region in the distance.

title: Jeremys Run Overlook
listingDescription: Looking west from Jeremys Run Overlook, at an elevation of 2,410 ft (734 m), you will see the hollow formed by Jeremys Run cutting between Neighbor Mountain on the left and Knob Mountain on the right.

images.altText: A view overlooking trees into a valley below.
images.title: Jeremys Run Overlook

bodyText: Looking west from Jeremys Run Overlook, at an elevation of 2,410 ft (734 m), you will see the hollow formed by Jeremys Run cutting between Neighbor Mountain on the left and Knob Mountain on the right. Jeremys Run can be accessed from Elkwallow Picnic Area. It is a beautiful place to hike, but be careful! There are multiple stream crossings that might be full of water after frequent rain.
audioDescription: This overlook faces west through Jeremys Run in between two mountains, Neighbor Mountain on the left and Knob Mountain on the right. Shenandoah Valley is visible in the distance.

title: Jewell Hollow Overlook
listingDescription: Facing north-northwest at an elevation of 3,320 ft (1,011 m), you can see the Blue Ridge Mountains descend into the valley from atop the Jewell Hollow Overlook.

images.altText: View over bushes into valley below.
images.title: Jewell Hollow Overlook

bodyText: Facing north-northwest at an elevation of 3,320 ft (1,011 m), you can see the Blue Ridge Mountains descend into the valley from atop the Jewell Hollow Overlook. Leading Ridge is the closest ridge to the overlook. Behind Leading Ridge is Jewell Hollow. Morning Star Lake, to the left, was created by the Dry Run Dam and is used for flood control purposes in the valley below.
audioDescription: This overlook faces north-northwest. Over a line of shrubs and trees the mountains are gently descending to the Shenandoah Valley below. From the valley on the left is Morning Star Lake. Moving right and up the mountains are Leading Ridge, closest to the overlook, Jewell Hollow beyond, and Neighbor Mountain in the distance There is an interpretive sign at this overlook. The Jewell Hollow Overlook interpretive sign is a 36 by 24 inch color graphic panel on a dark metal frame angled towards the viewer. The title text reads, "If These Walls Could Talk." Below the title is a quote that reads, " The hand-cut walls have stories to tell for those willing to listen.' Reed Engle, The Greatest Single Feature... A Sky-line Drive." The body text reads, "May 15, 1933 saw the first Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) camps established in Shenandoah at Skyland and Big Meadows. Young, strong men were now available to help turn the dream of Skyline Drive into reality. Under the leadership of National Park Service landscape architects, CCC enrollees and engineers helped build Skyline Drive's stone walls and overlooks, including the one where you stand now-Jewell Hollow. As you drive through Shenandoah National Park, you'll see plenty of the fruits of the CCC's labor-re-placed boulders, graded slopes, and transplanted trees and shrubs. While much of the boys' work blends seamlessly with the natural landscape, the walls stand out as visible testament to the quality and permanence of the CCC's work." Below the text is a close up image of a stone wall. To the right of the text is a black and white photograph of a dirt road with some stones laid out on the sides of the road, an old 1930s car off to the side, and two groups of workers standing around. The caption for the image reads, "Jewell Hollow Overlook under construction, c. 1930." In the lower left of the graphic is an image and text over a transparent black background. The image shows a side view of a stone wall surrounded by grasses. The title of the text next to this image reads, "Wall Construction." The body of the text reads, "In the 1930s, stone walls in Shenandoah National Park were built in two styles of masonry: dry-laid and ashlar. Dry-laid walls, like those here at Jewell Hollow Overlook, could be built by less-experienced stone workers, like the young men of the CCC, since they require only moving and aligning heavy stones-more muscle than skill. Mortared ashlar masonry walls require more expertise and had to be built by experienced masons." A black bar on the top of the graphic reads "Shenandoah National Park" on the left and on the right is the National Park Service Arrowhead symbol with the text "National Park Service/U.S. Department of the Interior"

title: Jones Run Falls Trailhead
listingDescription: Jones Run Parking Area (mile 84.1) | This hike takes you over a mountain stream, through the forest, and beside a 42’ waterfall.

images.altText: A waterfall cascading over rock with slight hints of fall color in the trees above.
images.title: Jones Run Falls

bodyText:
This hike takes you over a mountain stream, through the forest, and beside a 42 foot waterfall. There is one stream crossing. Pets must be on a physical leash no longer than 6 feet at all times.

Distance: 3.2-mile round trip hike
Difficulty: Moderate (explanation of our hiking difficulty scale)
Hiking Time: 2 hours 30 minutes
Elevation Gain: 1,045 feet

Hike Description

  1. From the trailhead at the Jones Run Parking Area (mile 84.1), cross the Appalachian Trail and follow the blue-blazed Jones Run Trail to Jones Run Falls
  2. Return by the same route.
audioDescription: The Jones Run Falls Trailhead panel is a 36 by 54 inch color poster. On the upper left of the panel is a photograph taken along the shores of the Chesapeake Bay...a destination of the water that flows from this area of Shenandoah National Park. The text reads, "Keep It Clean - Jones Run is a source stream for the James River watershed, one of three major watersheds in Shenandoah National Park. Here is how the watershed works: Jones Run flows into the Doyles River, which flows into the Moormans River, which flows into the Rivanna River, which flows into the James River, which flows into the the Chesapeake Bay, which empties into the Atlantic Ocean. This means that what happens in Shenandoah's streams does not stay in Shenandoah's streams. Effects accumulate, good or bad, as the water travels to its final destination." The picture on the bottom left of the panel is a handsome brook trout in its natural habitat. The text reads, "Full of Life - Pick up a rock and take a look. You'll see small creatures underneath it, like crayfish and caddisfly cases, evidence that Jones Run, like all of Shenandoah's streams, is teeming with activity. You might also see stoneflies and mayflies, indicators of good water quality and evidence that Shenandoah is sending clean water downstream. This tiny, aquatic life is also food for brook trout." "Brook trout thrive here in the mountains because they are cold water fish. Shenandoah's high elevation and shady forests keep the water cool. Brook trout are indicator species, so the fact that they're living in the Park means the streams are healthy and clean." The top right of the panel is a 20 by 20 inch topographic map of the hike to Jones Run Falls. The text reads, "Suggested Hike: Hike #1: Jones Run Falls - (This trail is marked in yellow with a brown dashed line.) 3.2-mile round trip, moderate, 2.25 hours hiking time, 1,045-foot elevation gain, one stream crossing. Follow Jones Run Trail to Jones Run Falls, and return by the same route." "Hike #2: Jones Run Falls and Doyles River Falls (The trail is marked in purple with a brown dashed line.) 6.5-mile circuit, moderately strenuous, 5 hours hiking time, 1,701-foot elevation gain, several stream crossings. Follow the Appalachian Trail north to Browns Gap parking. Without crossing Skyline Drive, walk several yards alongside the road until you reach Browns Gap Road on the right. Follow Browns Gap Road; turn right onto Doyles River Trail. Trail posts mark the location of Upper and Lower Doyles River Falls. Another trail post marks the end of Doyles River Trail and the beginning of Jones Run Trail. Follow Jones Run Trail. A trail post marks the location of Jones Run Falls. Continue uphill to return to the parking lot." A red text box below the map gives important information that hikers need. The text reads, "Emergency 1-800-732-0911 (cell phone service is unreliable.) Before You Go! Pets must be on a leash at all times. Do not attempt to cross streams during icy conditions or flooding. Be sure you are physically able to complete the hike you've chosen. Take plenty of water - at least a quart per hour. Be sure you know your route. Free maps are available at entrance stations, visitors centers, and www.nps.gov/shen When you return from your hike, check for ticks. Stay on the trail and avoid trampling sensitive vegetation. Be sure someone knows where you are and when to expect your return. Leave what you find. Artifacts are protected by law. It's dangerous and potentially deadly to climb on the rocks near waterfalls. Filter or treat water from streams before drinking."

title: Knob Mountain - Jeremys Run Trailhead
listingDescription: Elkwallow Wayside (mile 24) | This hike goes around a beautiful area of the Park featuring one of the most picturesque streams in Shenandoah.

images.altText: A tree stands in the foreground of a mountainous overlook covered in snow.
images.title: Jeremys Run Overlook

bodyText:
Starting at Elkwallow Wayside, this hike goes around a beautiful area of the Park featuring one of the most picturesque streams in Shenandoah. Pets must be on a physical leash no longer than 6 feet at all times.

Distance: 6.0-mile circuit hike
Difficulty: Moderately Strenuous (hiking difficulty scale)
Hiking Time: 7 hours 30 minutes
Elevation Gain: 1,303 feet

Hike Description

  1. From the parking lot at Elkwallow Wayside (mile 24), take the Appalachian Trail (white-blazed) to its junction with Jeremys Run Trail (blue-blazed).
  2. The A.T. goes sharply left here, but stay straight onto Jeremys Run Upper Trail.
  3. Take a right onto the Knob Mountain Cutoff Trail.
  4. Take another right on Knob Mountain Trail (yellow-blazed). Follow it to Mathews Arm Campground registration station.
  5. Take the Elkwallow Trail back to your starting point at Elkwallow Wayside.

title: Lake Arrowhead
listingDescription: From many west-facing overlooks you can see a large lake in the valley. It is Lake Arrowhead and serves as a reservoir and a recreation area for the neighboring town of Luray. Lake Arrowhead features 6 picnic shelters for rent (Call 540-743-5511 for availability), fishing, white sand beach and swimming during the summer, ball field, volleyball nets, horseshoe pits, playground, 1 mile trail that circles the lake, and the Edwin Smith scout camping area. The physical address is

images.altText: A winter scene of a lake framed by snowy trees on the left and a mountain ridge on the right.
images.title: Lake Arrowhead in the Winter
images.caption: Lake Arrowhead in nearby Luray, Va.

bodyText:
From many west-facing overlooks you can see a large lake in the valley. It is Lake Arrowhead and serves as a reservoir and a recreation area for the neighboring town of Luray.
Lake Arrowhead features 6 picnic shelters for rent (Call 540-743-5511 for availability), fishing, white sand beach and swimming during the summer, ball field, volleyball nets, horseshoe pits, playground, 1 mile trail that circles the lake, and the Edwin Smith scout camping area. The physical address is 265 Lake Arrowhead Road. For more information visit http://www.townofluray.com/luray-parks.html#lakearrowhead
audioDescription: A 39 acre lake in the middle of the Shenandoah Valley next to the town of Luray.

title: Lands Run Falls Trailhead
listingDescription: Lands Run Parking Area (mile 9.2) | A short hike down a fire road to a series of cascades that descend about 80 feet into a gorge. Note that it may not have water in dry seasons.

images.altText: A small waterfall cascades down rocks amidst brown leaves.
images.title: Lands Run Falls

bodyText:
A short hike down a fire road to a series of cascades that descend about 80 feet into a gorge. Note that it may be waterless in dry seasons. Pets must be on a physical leash no longer than 6 feet at all times.

Distance: 1.3-mile round trip hike
Difficulty: Easiest (explanation of our hiking difficulty scale)
Hiking Time: 1 hour 30 minutes
Elevation Gain: 325 feet

Hike Description

  1.  From the Lands Run Parking Area (mile 9.2), follow the fire road downhill for about 0.6-mile and look for a small stream that flows under the road (it may be waterless in dry conditions).
  2. Follow the stream about 25 feet on the right to the top of a small waterfall. There is a series of cascades that descend about 80 feet into a gorge. It’s a beautiful area to explore, but use caution around the falls and steep, rocky areas.
  3. Turn around and retrace your steps back to the parking area.

title: Lewis Falls Trailhead
listingDescription: Big Meadows Amphitheater (mile 51.2) | This hike leads to an observation point over a beautiful 81’ waterfall.

images.altText: A concrete post at the head of a trail the reads Lewis Falls
images.title: Lewis Falls Trailhead

bodyText:
Leaving from Big Meadows amphitheater, this hike leads to an observation point over a beautiful 81 foot waterfall. Pets must be on a physical leash no longer than 6 feet at all times.

Distance: 3.3-mile circuit hike
Difficulty: Moderate (explanation of our hiking difficulty scale)
Hiking Time: 4 hours
Elevation Gain: 990 feet

Hike Description

  1. From the Big Meadows Amphitheater Parking Area (mile 51.2), walk downhill from the concrete marker post and turn left on the Appalachian Trail.
  2. Stay right onto the blue-blazed Lewis Falls Trail. It’s a steep, rocky descent to the falls viewing platform.
  3. To return, take the trail up to its intersection with a fire road and turn right.
  4. In a few yards, turn left onto the Appalachian Trail.
  5. Follow uphill to return to the parking area.

title: Lewis Mountain
listingDescription: The Lewis Mountain developed area is a favorite among return visitors. Its small, intimate atmosphere is both beautiful and relaxing. Lewis Mountain usually closes in November and reopens the end of March. Call 877-847-1919 for exact dates. For cabin rental, visit GoShenandoah.com . The campground is first-come, first-served. For more information: nps.gov/shen/planyourvisit/campgrounds.htm Other services in Lewis Mountain include a campstore, showers, a picnic ground, and a

images.altText: A color photograph of a large brown sign indicating the turn toward Lewis Mountain.
images.title: Lewis Mountain

bodyText:
The Lewis Mountain developed area is a favorite among return visitors. Its small, intimate atmosphere is both beautiful and relaxing. Lewis Mountain usually closes in November and reopens the end of March. 

Stay

For cabin rental, visit GoShenandoah.com . The campground is first-come, first-served. For more information: nps.gov/shen/planyourvisit/campgrounds.htm
Other services in Lewis Mountain include a campstore, showers, a picnic ground, and an amphitheater. Closed in winter.

History

Park management established Lewis Mountain as a segregated area for African American visitors in the 1930s. Integration began in 1947 due to political pressure from Washington.
audioDescription: A large wooden, routed brown sign in a grassy triangle indicates the entrance to the Lewis Mountain area. Three symbols indicate the major services: a bed for lodging, a tent for camping, and a picnic table for picnic grounds.

title: Lewis Mountain Amphitheater
listingDescription: Evening programs are held in the amphitheater once a week at night during late spring, summer, and early fall.

images.altText: Four sets of long wooden benches separated by aisles. Dirt underneath with a view of the forest.
images.title: Lewis Mountain Amphitheater

bodyText: Evening programs are held in the amphitheater once a week at night during late spring, summer, and early fall. Check our calander for dates and times.
audioDescription: Four sets of long wooden benches separated by aisles form a small, outdoor amphitheater in the middle of the woods.There is dirt underneath with a view of the forest and a fern bed.

title: Lewis Mountain Cabins
listingDescription: The historic Lewis Mountain Cabins offer comfortable accommodations to families, couples, or anyone seeking an authentic Shenandoah National Park experience.

images.altText: The interior of a rustic cabin with wood walls and a bed.
images.title: Lewis Mountain Cabin Interior 2

bodyText: With the Blue Ridge Mountains surrounding you, the historic Lewis Mountain Cabins offer comfortable accommodations to families, couples, or anyone seeking an authentic Shenandoah National Park experience. The cabins typically open in late spring and close in late fall and are operated by the Park concessioner, Delaware North. More information about rates, reservations, and operating hours can be found on their website.
audioDescription: A paved walkway leads to a stone-floored porch. Double screen doors open into the campstore and registration area for the cabins. the building is brown sided with green trim.

title: Lewis Mountain Campstore
listingDescription: Register for a cabin at Lewis Mountain here. Campground registration is at the campground. You'll also find a campstore with groceries and supplies, as well as a few souvenirs, showers, and laundry in this building. Lewis Mountain's coin-operated showers and laundry are open seasonally when the campground and cabins are open.

images.altText: A brown, wood paneled building with a slanted roof and two entry ways.
images.title: Lewis Mountain

bodyText:
Opens March 24, 2023. Closes November 26, 2023. 

The Lewis Mountain campstore provides groceries and supplies, as well as a few souvenirs, showers, and laundry in this building. Lewis Mountain's coin-operated showers and laundry are open seasonally when the campground and cabins are open. Check in for Lewis Mountain Cabins at this campstore.
audioDescription: A paved walkway leads to a stone-floored porch. Double screen doors open into the campstore and registration area for the cabins. the building is brown sided with green trim.

title: Lewis Mountain Picnic Grounds
listingDescription: Lewis Mountain Picnic Ground is open April through October. A pleasant, quiet wooded atmosphere makes it a great place to relax and have a picnic.

images.altText: Mature trees screening numerous picnic tables among the grassy areas of the picnic grounds.
images.title: Lewis Mountain Picnic Ground

bodyText: Lewis Mountain Picnic Ground is open April through October. A pleasant, quiet wooded atmosphere makes it a great place to relax and have a picnic.
audioDescription: The Lewis Mountain Picnic Ground is accessible via a one-way road that turns left from the main Lewis Mountain Road, and circles around a wooded area with sporadic parking off the one-way, one-lane road. Picnic tables with fire grates dot the grassy wooded area.

title: Limberlost Trailhead
listingDescription: Limberlost Parking Area (mile 43) | An ADA accessible path through the forest with mountain laurel in the springtime and an example of a columnar jointing geological feature. This hike is also a designated TRACK Trail, featuring a self-guided brochure designed for kids.

images.altText: A crushed rock trail leads into the forest, past several educational signs
images.title: Limberlost Trail

bodyText:
Pets are not allowed on this hike. An ADA accessible path through the forest with mountain laurel in the springtime and an example of a columnar jointing geological feature. Limberlost is a fully accessible trail (see more specific information below).

This hike is also a designated TRACK Trail, featuring a self-guided brochure and informational sign that turns your visit into a fun and exciting outdoors experience for kids of all ages. To find out more information about TRACK Trails and to log your adventure,visit the Kids in Parks website. 

Distance: 1.3-mile circuit hike
Difficulty: Easiest (explanation of our hiking difficulty scale)
Hiking Time: 1 hour 30 minutes
Elevation Gain: 130 feet

Hike Description

  1. From the trailhead at the Limberlost Parking Area (mile 43), take the trail to the right of the trailhead and follow the greenstone path.
  2. Stay on the path to loop back around to your starting point. 

Accessibility Information

Length: 2338.3 yards/2138.1 meters
Surface Type: primarily crushed greenstone
Typical Tread Width: 5 feet/1.5 meters
Minimum Tread Width: 2.7 feet/.8 meters
Typical Running Slope: 3.5%
Maximum Running Slope: 10.3%
Typical Cross Slope: 1.6%
Maximum Cross Slope: 5.0%
audioDescription: The Limberlost Trailhead is and 36 by 54 inch color poster. The upper left has a title: Did You Know? There are two photos, one of the area when the hemlock trails were healthy. The photo is of a forest of very large evergreen trees with very straight trunks and feathery foilage. Caption: Limberlost was once known for its majestic hemlocks-the largest old-growth stand in the park. They were killed by an invasive insect. The second photo is of a section of trail that boasts a beautiful stand of mountain laurel. The photo shows a bench backed by the delicate pink blossoms of the laurel, a wide greenstone path curves into the distance flanked by more of the pink blooms in the understory and accented by green foliage overhead. Caption: The magic of Limberlost is revealed in June with a spectacular explosion of mountain laurel. Below is a title: Ever-Changing Forest Text: As you explore Limberlost, you'll see evidence of a constantly changing forest. Both human-caused and natural events impact what lives and dies in nature. An invasive insect, a hurricane, and several ice storms caused many of the bent, broken, and downed trees. But, look closely! You'll see that they all fill an important role in the ecosystem. Examine the fallen hemlock trees. You'll see that the decaying logs are being decomposed by fungi and insects, shredded by hungry bears, and used as shelter by chipmunks and squirrels. Notice that new growth-a multitude of black birch-is taking the place of the once-dominant hemlock. Below is a photo of the excellent example of columnar jointing along this trail. The photo is dominated by a large rock formation. The gray-green rocks are arranged in columns, very much like a vertical stack of posts. In the background the fog hovers in the forest. Caption: Imagine the forces that created this outstanding example of columnar jointing that you will see along the trail. Title: Rock of Ages Text: There is change even in the rocks. Look for an outstanding example of columnar jointing. Jutting from the earth like a giant crystal, it is the remains of an ancient lava flow that cooled, contracted, and solidified into an array of columns. Erosion claimed the rocks that used to surround it, but, like the rest of the forest, it reflects both change and resilience. The upper right has a map of the area with the suggested hikes outlined in pink and yellow. Title: Suggested Hikes Text: Hike #1 - Limberlost 1.3 miles, circuit; fairly level stroll. Take the trail to your right and follow the greenstone path back to your starting point. See the opposite side of this kiosk for accessibility information. Pets are not allowed on Limberlost Trail. Hike #2 - Upper Whiteoak Falls 4.5 miles, round trip; moderate. Take the Limberlost trail to your left. In about 200 yards, turn right onto Whiteoak Canyon Trail and follow it 1.5 miles to the upper falls viewing area. Retrace your steps to return. Title: Exploring Further There are several more falls farther down the Whiteoak Canyon Trail, but be sure to plan ahead if you want to see them. It's an additional 1.9 miles to the bottom of the canyon (making the round trip hike 8.3 miles total) in much steeper, rockier terrain. You'll need significantly more time, water, and stamina! To the right of the Suggested Hikes information is a box. The top fifth of the box is bright red. Text: Emergency: 1-800-732-0911 (Cell phone service is unreliable.)Other text below the red: Before you go!- Be sure you are physically able to complete the hike you've chosen.- Be sure you know your route. Free maps are available at Entrance Stations, Visitor Centers, and www.nps.gov/shen- Take plenty of water-at least a quart per hour.- Pets are not allowed on Limberlost Trail.- When you return from your hike, check for ticks.- Be sure someone knows where you are and when to expect your return. The Limberlost Accessibility Trailhead panel is a 36 by 54 inch color poster. On the upper right of the panel is a photograph of a "resting interval" along the trail. The text reads, " The Limberlost area has been a favorite among visitors since before Shenandoah National Park was established. Skyland was a privately owned resort in the 1920s. The resort's owners, Addie and George Pollock arranged horseback excursions into the beautiful and mysterious "Limberlost Swamp." Because of its proximity to Skyland and its relatively gentle grade, park staff proposed making the trail accessible to all visitors in 1996. Over the years, several organizations have donated labor, equipment, supplies and funding. Alongside volunteers, the park staff has worked to make the trail compliant with current ADA standards, adjusting the grade and adding benches and over 20 resting areas. As of fall 2015, the Limberlost Trail is fully accessible. Your fee dollars, funding from the Shenandoah National Park Trust, and other contributions have made this accessible trail possible." The center of the panel is a 20 by 20 inch topographic map of the

title: Little Devils Stairs Loop Trailhead
listingDescription: Keyser Run Parking Area (mile 19.4) | A journey into a rocky gorge with some very rewarding, yet steep, sections along a stream.

images.altText: A view from an overlook down into a valley below filled with fall colors of red and orange.
images.title: View from Little Devils Stairs Overlook

bodyText:
This journey leads you through an impressive gorge with many cascades, past a family cemetery, and through the quiet forest. Pets must be on a leash no longer than 6 feet at all times.

Distance: 7.4-mile circuit hike
Difficulty: Strenuous (explanation of our hiking difficulty scale)
Hiking Time: 8 hours 30 minutes
Elevation Gain: 1,897 feet

Hike Description

  1. From the Keyser Run Parking Area (mile 19.4), take the Keyser Run Fire Road (yellow-blazed).
  2. Follow the fire road to the parking area on the boundary. Please stay on the fire road, and respect private property.
  3. Pick up the blue-blazed Little Devils Stairs Trail and continue until you reconnect with the Keyser Run Fire Road.
  4. Turn right, and return to the parking area.

title: Little Devils Stairs Overlook
listingDescription: Stop at Little Devils Stairs Overlook for a sweeping view to the south. Looking down from an elevation of 3,120 ft (950 m), you are peering into Little Devils Stairs, a rocky gorge with some very steep sections.

images.altText: View with tree in foreground overlooking mountains in the distance.
images.title: Little Devils Stairs Overlook

bodyText: Stop at Little Devils Stairs Overlook for a sweeping view to the south. Looking down from an elevation of 3,120 ft (950 m), you are peering into Little Devils Stairs, a rocky gorge with some very steep sections. Like the name implies, hiking this section is not for the faint of heart. Follow the view from Little Devils Stairs and you will see Pignut Mountain, the pinnacle of Pickerel Ridge. If the day is clear you will also be able to see Old Rag far in the distance.
audioDescription: This overlook faces south over a sloped meadow with many mountains in the distance. Straight ahead are two closer mountains that form a v-shape. This is the location of Little Devils Stairs gorge. Further in the distance from the left is Jenkins Mountain. Straight ahead beyond Little Devils Stairs is Pickerel Ridge leading up to Pignut Mountain. Old Rag is far in the distance on the right.

title: Little Hogback Overlook
listingDescription: Looking north-northeast from an elevation of 3,035 ft (925 m), Little Hogback Overlook gives you a narrow window from which to view Browntown Valley. A section of the Appalachian Trail runs directly below this overlook.

images.altText: View overlooking brush into narrow view of valley below.
images.title: Little Hogback Overlook

bodyText: Looking north-northeast from an elevation of 3,035 ft (925 m), Little Hogback Overlook gives you a narrow window from which to view Browntown Valley. A low ridge separates Browntown Valley from Shenandoah Valley further in the distance. Far in the distance Massanutten Mountain is visible with the Valley and Ridge Appalachians beyond. A section of the Appalachian Trail runs directly below this overlook.
audioDescription: This overlook faces north-northeast through a narrow window into Browntown Valley bellow. Beyond Browntown Valley is a ridge over which is the Shenandoah Valley with Massanutten Mountain visible in the distance. Directly below the overlook obscured by trees is the Appalachian Trail.

title: Loft Mountain
listingDescription: Welcome to the Loft Mountain area. Here you'll find a campground, amphitheater, campstore and Loft Mountain Wayside! Loft Mountain Campground facilities usually close at the end of October and reopen the beginning of May.

images.altText: A large brown sign with white letters is attached to a stone pillar on the right.
images.title: Loft Mountain
images.caption: From this sign it's just a short drive up the hill to the campground.

bodyText:
Welcome to the Loft Mountain area. Here you'll find a campground, amphitheater, campstore and Loft Mountain Wayside! Loft Mountain Campground facilities usually close at the end of October and reopen the beginning of May. Call 540-999-3500 for exact dates.

Nearby Services

There are many services nearby to help make your visit easier including:

Loft Mountain Wayside - casual dining, a gift store, outdoor picnic tables, and a bike repair station.
Loft Mountain Campground - tent and RC sites and a nearby dump station for RVs.
Loft Mountain Campstore, Showers, and Laundry - all the necessities for your camping trip, including coin operated showers and laundry facilities.

Many of these services and facilities are seasonal. Explore these different sites through the map to learn more.
audioDescription: A large brown sign with white letters is attached to a stone pillar on the right. Text on upper panel: Skyline Drive (plus directional arrow.) Text on middle panel: Loft Mountain (plus directional arrow.) Text on lower panel: Campstore, Campground, Amphitheater-Nature Trail. The sign sits on a grassy slope.

title: Loft Mountain Amphitheater
listingDescription: Evening programs are held in the amphitheater on some nights during late spring, summer, and early fall. The schedule is posted in the bulletin board at the amphitheater entrance and our calendar.

images.altText: A brown wooden building with a large garage-type door. There is an arrowhead beside the door.
images.title: Loft Mountain Amphitheater
images.caption: Loft Mountain Amphitheater is a great place to watch the sun set while enjoying a presentation.

bodyText: Evening programs are held in the amphitheater on some nights during late spring, summer, and early fall. The schedule is posted in the bulletin board at the amphitheater entrance and our calendar. Closed in winter.
audioDescription: A projection booth: brown wooden building with a large garage-type door. There is an arrowhead beside the door. At the base of the building is a stone platform that curves into a wall. In the curve is a matching stone fire ring. There are three sets of benches separated by crushed greenstone aisles. Beyond and to the left of the projection booth is a beautiful view of blue mountain ridges.

title: Loft Mountain Campstore, Showers, and Laundry
listingDescription: Get camping supplies, take a shower, and do laundry here at Loft Mountain Campstore. Loft Mountain Campground facilities usually close at the end of October and reopen the beginning of May. Call 540-999-3500 for exact dates. https://www.goshenandoah.com/dining/food-groceries

images.altText: Two buildings connected by a breezeway. Restrooms, showers, and laundry are on the right.
images.title: Loft Mountain Campstore

bodyText:
Opens May 5, 2023. Closes October 29, 2023. 

Get camping supplies, take a shower, and do laundry here at Loft Mountain Campstore. Loft Mountain Campground facilities usually close at the end of October and reopen the beginning of May. For more information visit GoShenandoah.com/dining/food-groceries.
audioDescription: Two buildings connected by a breezeway. Restrooms, showers, and laundry are on the right and the store is on the left. In front of the building on the right side are recycle containers and propane storage. There is also a bulletin board with changing information.

title: Loft Mountain Overlook
listingDescription: Looking southeast from an elevation of 2,455 ft (748 m), Loft Mountain Overlook presents you with a view of the Blue Ridge Mountains descending into the foothills that merge with the Piedmont region of Virginia.

images.altText: A view over trees to mountains beyond.
images.title: Loft Mountain Overlook

bodyText:
Looking southeast from an elevation of 2,455 ft (748 m), Loft Mountain Overlook presents you with a view of the Blue Ridge Mountains descending into the foothills that merge with the Piedmont region of Virginia. Straight ahead is County Line Mountain. Aptly named, County Line Mountain is the boundary between Greene County, where you are, and Albemarle County.

Maintenance of this view funded Greene County and Hugh and Temple Joyce through the Shenandoah National Park Trust Adopt an Overlook program.
audioDescription: A rustic dark brown wood-sided building with dark green trim. A center double door divides the two sides. A sidewalk leads to the door. The interpretive sign is a 36 by 24 inch color graphic panel on a dark metal frame angled towards the viewer. The title text reads, "Smarter Than Your Average Bear..." The body text reads, "... is pretty smart. Black bears are wily omnivores-quick learners who can easily destroy any tent or container to get at your food! Black bears thrive in Shenandoah National Park because the foods they need to eat-acorns, berries, grubs, honey-are plentiful. Human food is bad news for bears, and all Park wildlife. Bears that get human food lose their fear of humans. They are at a much greater risk for being illegally hunted and hit by vehicles. A "good bear gone bad" is dangerous to people and may have to be trapped and relocated or even killed by Park staff. Bears have an astounding sense of smell. They also have claws and strong teeth, which means they can make quick work of even a metal cooler. When you're picnicking in bear country, store your food properly and don't leave it unattended, even for a few moments. Remember to put all food and packaging inside your vehicle and dispose of garbage in bear-proof trashcans." The text is on top of a bright green background. To the left of the text is an image of a bear surrounded by green ferns, looking straight forward at the viewer. The caption for the image reads, "Black bear." A black bar on the top of the graphic reads "Shenandoah National Park" on the left and on the right is the National Park Service Arrowhead symbol with the text "National Park Service/U.S. Department of the Interior" The orientation shelter is a small roof supported by six brown beams. The beams are frames for six upright 36 inch by 54 inch posters in glass enclosures. Panel 1: Bulletin Board Bulletin boards contain seasonal information. Panel 2: Shenandoah Map This graphic is divided into two columns, the left has text and images and the right has a map. On the right column, title text reads, "Welcome to Shenandoah National Park." Below the title is a color photograph of a man standing atop a rock outcrop and looking to the mountains in the distance on a sunny day. Layered on the image is the quote " ...for the recreation and the re-creation they shall find here." -President Franklin Roosevelt, Shenandoah's Dedication." Text below the image reads, "Shenandoah National Park was established in 1935 to bring the western national park experience to the urban east. Here, within a few hours' drive of millions, you will find "recreation and re-creation." Experience the wonder of nature, the power of shared heritage, and the inspiration that is the future of our national parks." Below there is the subheading "Shenandoah Highlights," and the text "- Skyline Drive - 105 miles of beauty. Please observe the 35 mph speed limit to see it all safely. - 75 Overlooks - Spectacular views of the Shenandoah Valley and Virginia Piedmont. - 500 Miles of Trails - Beautiful waterfalls, quiet forests, and mountain summits are just a hike away. - Visitor Centers - Films, exhibits, and Ranger-led walks and talks tell Shenandoah's stories." The map to the right shows the boundaries of, driving route through, and highlights in Shenandoah National Park. The map area is 30 miles wide by 150 miles long. Shenandoah National Park is shaded green. Highlights include entrance stations, visitor centers, campgrounds, lodging, restrooms, food services, and trailheads. At the bottom of the map is the park emergency number: (800) 732-0911. At the top and bottom of the graphic are black bars. The black bar at the top has the text, "Shenandoah National Park," to the left, and "National Park Service, U.S. Department of the Interior," on the right with the National Park Service arrowhead logo to the far right. The lower black bar has the Leave No Trace logo on the left with the text "Leave No Trace Principe #6, Respect Wildlife," and on the right the text "www.nps.gov/shen." Panel 3: Spring/Summer Plants and Animals. The graphic is split into two horizontal sections with text and graphics in rectangles. The top section has the title, "Spring" with the subtitle "Renewal." The rectangle is split vertically. The left side contains three color photographs with text descriptions. The first image is white flowers with four petals labeled "Flowering Dogwood," and the accompanying text, "Dogwood blossoms are well-known messengers of spring, but this understory tree has other jobs, too - like providing food and shelter." The second image shows a mother deer and two fawns walking in high grasses labeled "White-tailed Deer" with the accompanying text "White-tailed deer hide their fawns under the dogwood's low-hanging branches and feed on its tender shoots, buds, and later, berries." The third image shows a dark blue bird with black tail feathers labeled "Indigo Bunting." The view from this overlook looks southeast.

title: Loft Mountain Wayside
listingDescription: The Loft Mountain Wayside is a great stop for a quick meal and souvenirs. Loft Mountain Wayside usually closes around the beginning of November and reopens in April. Call 877-847-1919 for exact dates. There is an orientation shelter in front of the wayside, along with a backcountry registration board, a bike repair station, and picnic tables. https://www.goshenandoah.com/dining/food-groceries

images.altText: A rustic dark brown wood-sided building with dark green trim.
images.title: Loft Mountain Wayside

bodyText:
Opens April 14, 2023. Food & beverage service available May 12 - October 29. Closes November 5, 2023. 

The Loft Mountain Wayside is a great stop for a quick meal and souvenirs. Loft Mountain Wayside usually closes around the beginning of November and reopens in April. There is an orientation shelter in front of the wayside, along with a backcountry registration board, a bike repair station, and picnic tables. For more information visit GoShenandoah.com/dining/food-groceries.
