title: Loft Mountain Wayside Backcountry Registration
listingDescription: Backcountry Camping is a wilder, more primitive experience than staying in a campground and requires important planning and appropriate equipment. Backcountry campers are required to have a permit. Register for a backcountry camping permit here.

images.altText: A small, angled roof supported by two brown, vertical beams shelters a large poster.
images.title: Loft Mountain Wayside

bodyText: Backcountry Camping is a wilder, more primitive experience than staying in a campground and requires important planning and appropriate equipment. Backcountry campers are required to have a permit. Register for a backcountry camping permit here. You must register 1 hour before sunset. For more information about backcountry camping, visit our website.
audioDescription: A small, angled roof supported by two brown, vertical beams shelters a large, flat glass case with a poster in it. The poster relates the backcountry camping regulations and explains how to fill out the permit.

title: Luray
listingDescription: When you are in the central part of the Park, the town you see to the west is Luray, one of Shenandoah National Park's gateway communities.

images.altText: An oval sign that reads: Welcome to Luray Virginia Where the Caverns meet the Sky.
images.title: Luray
images.caption: Luray is one of several gateway towns.

bodyText: When you are in the central part of the Park, the town you see to the west is Luray, one of Shenandoah National Park's gateway communities.
audioDescription: The town of Luray is 4.7 square miles. From an overlook, Luray is an area with a built up central downtown surrounded by sparse, rural farms and homes.

title: Marys Rock Summit Trailhead
listingDescription: Panorama Parking Area (mile 31.5) | Many legends surround the name of this hike, but there is no denying the beautiful westward views that it provides of the Shenandoah Valley and Massanutten Mountain.

images.altText: A man in a green shirt and backwards ball cap gazes out over a valley below from a mountain top.
images.title: Hiker at Marys Rock Summit

bodyText:
Many legends surround the name of this hike, but there is no denying the beautiful westward views that it provides of the Shenandoah Valley and Massanutten Mountain. Pets must be on a physical leash no longer than 6 feet at all times.

Note that very limited closures are in effect in an effort to prevent further degradation of important outcrop ecosystems on Marys Rock.

Distance: 3.7-mile round trip hike
Difficulty: Moderate (hiking difficulty scale)
Hiking Time: 3 hours 30 minutes
Elevation Gain: 1,210 feet

Hike Description 

  1. From the trailhead located in the back of the Panorama Parking Area (mile 31.5), take the short connector trail to the Appalachian Trail and go left (south).
  2. At the trailpost take a right to the viewpoint.
  3. Retrace your steps back to the parking area.
audioDescription: The Marys Rock Trailhead panel is a 36 by 54 inch color poster. On the upper left of the panel is a black and white photograph taken of a group of Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) "boys" as they paused in their work on the trail near Marys Rock. The narrow trail that curves around a bend in the trail has a abrupt 10-foot drop off held in place with an impressive hand-laid stone retaining wall. The text reads, "Value Added - The Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC), created in the early 1930s by President Franklin Roosevelt, helped ease the sting of the Great Depression. It put young men to work in public lands like Shenandoah National Park, and taught them skills like carpentry, landscaping, and masonry. CCC boys built the retaining walls along the Appalachian Trail south to Marys Rock. Those walls, like CCC work all over Shenandoah, endure as handsome reminders of the program that provided a depression-plagued nation with food, shelter, and trade skills." The bottom left of the panel has a photograph of a trail through lush, green forest. Downed trees span the trail, with the section over the foot path removed. The remainder of the trees lie on either side of the trail. The text reads, "Life Out of Death - On the Appalachian Trail north toward Pass Mountain, you will see lots of fallen trees, downed by storms, disease, or simply old age. Trail crews have removed the sections of the downed trees blocking the trail, but have left the debris beside the trail on purpose. Trail maintenance in the Park works toward preservation and regeneration: dead trees will provide habitat and food for wildlife and will eventually return to the ground as rich soil from which living things can draw life." The top right of the panel is a 20 by 20 inch topographic map of the hike to Marys Rock Summit and Pass Mountain Loop. The Marys Rock trail is marked in yellow with a brown dashed line. The text reads, "Suggested Hikes: Hike #1: Marys Rock Summit - 3.7 mile round trip, moderate, 2.75 hours hiking time, 1,210-foot elevation gain. Take the short connector trail to the Appalachian Trail (A.T.) south. Look for double blazes, indicating a change in the trail; the A.T. will make some sharp turns. Continue to a trail post; go right to Marys Rock viewpoint. Return by retracing your steps, being careful at the trail post to go left, to take the A.T. north back to Panorama." "Hike #2: Pass Mountain Loop - (This trail is marked in purple with a dashed line.) 3.4-mile circuit, moderate, 2.5 hours, 670-foot elevation gain. Take the short connector trail to the Appalachian Trail (A.T.) north. Cross U.S. 211. Continue for another tenth of a mile to Skyline Drive; cross the Drive. Go right onto Pass Mountain Hut Road. Stay on the fire road to Pass Mountain Hut. To return, near Pass Mountain Hut, look for the blue-blazed Pass Mountain Trail leading back to the A.T. south. Take the A.T. south back to Panorama, first crossing Skyline Drive, then U.S. 211, to the starting point." A red text box below the map gives important information that hikers need. The text reads, "Emergency 1-800-732-0911 (cell phone service is unreliable.) Before You Go! Pets must be on a leash at all times. Be sure you are physically able to complete the hike you've chosen. Take plenty of water - at least a quart per hour Be sure you know your route. Free maps are available at entrance stations, visitors centers, and www.nps.gov/shen. When you return from your hike, check for ticks. Stay on the trail and avoid trampling sensitive vegetation. Be sure someone knows where you are and when to expect your return."

title: Marys Rock Tunnel
listingDescription: This iconic feature of Skyline Drive is located at mile 32.2. Turn on those headlights and make sure your vehicle has enough clearance before travelling through. The height of this tunnel is 12'8".

images.altText: A tunnel cut into the mountain with trees on top of the rock tunnel exterior and a car's headlights

title: Massanutten Lodge
listingDescription: Massanutten Lodge is a historic building from the early days of Skyland. Built in 1911, it was the home of Addie Nairn Pollock, co-owner of Skyland Resort and wife of Skyland founder George Freeman Pollock. The lodge houses an exhibit, "The Women of Skyland," which documents the lives of several women who frequented the resort during the roaring 20s. The exhibit is typically open late-spring through fall.

images.altText: A color photograph of a wood-paneled two-story cottage tucked into a grassy hill.
images.title: Massanutten Lodge

bodyText:
Take a Virtual Tour

Massanutten Lodge is a historic building from the early days of Skyland. Built in 1911, it was the home of Addie Nairn Pollock, co-owner of Skyland Resort and wife of Skyland founder George Freeman Pollock. The lodge's living room has been historically refurnished to reflect how Addie lived around 1915. The lodge also houses an exhibit, "The Women of Skyland," which documents the lives of several women who frequented the resort in the roaring 20s. Although from very different backgrounds, they all held in common the need to reach beyond many of the social barriers of the time.

The lodge is open for visitation during our Ranger program season, generally late spring through autumn (view ranger program schedule). Please note that no bags, food, or drinks are allowed in the building. Photography is also prohibited inside the building.
audioDescription: There is a sidewalk leading down from the road to the lodge's main door. To the right of the sidewalk, approaching the building, is a low stone wall and along the sidewalk are plants and flowers. One outer wall of the lodge is built entirely with gray stone and there are five small windows. This wall is connected to the low stone wall along the sidewalk. The other outer wall is beige on the upper half but has bark siding on the lower half. A few steps lead up to a small deck and a green side door. A sign over the side door says "Massanutten." There is a red-tiled roof and two chimneys. A porch extends around the far side of the house. The lodge is built on a slope and has views facing west.

quickFacts.value: Historic former home of Addie Nairn Pollock, co-owner of Skyland Resort.
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Mathews Arm Amphitheater
listingDescription: The amphitheater at Matthews Arm hosts Ranger programs during the day and in the evening from spring to fall. Check the calendar of events to see if there are any programs during your visit! Closed in winter.

images.altText: A color photograph of a series of wooden benches arranged in rows.
images.title: Mathews Arm Campground
images.caption: Amphitheater at Mathews Arm Campground.

bodyText: The amphitheater at Matthews Arm hosts Ranger programs during the day and in the evening from spring to fall. Check the calendar of events to see if there are any programs during your visit! Closed in winter.
audioDescription: An unpaved trail from the parking lot leads to the amphitheater, a series of wooden benches arranged in rows.

title: McCormick Gap Overlook
listingDescription: View the southern end of the Shenandoah Valley from McCormick Gap Overlook. The Shenandoah Valley is bordered by the Blue Ridge Mountains to the east and the Valley and Ridge Appalachians to the west.

images.altText: A view over trees into a valley below.
images.title: McCormick Gap Overlook

bodyText: View the southern end of the Shenandoah Valley from McCormick Gap Overlook. The Shenandoah Valley is bordered by the Blue Ridge Mountains to the east and the Valley and Ridge Appalachians to the west. Origins of the name Shenandoah are unknown, though it is generally believed to be of American Indian origin. The most common, romantic theory is that the name means "Beautiful Daughter of the Stars," however there is no more evidence for this theory than any other.
audioDescription: This overlook faces north. The view looks down over a line of trees to the Shenandoah Valley below and to the left. To the right are mountains in Shenandoah National Park, descending to the left toward the valley. The orientation shelter is a small roof supported by six brown beams. The beams are frames for six upright 36 inch by 54 inch posters in glass enclosures. Panel 1: Bulletin Board Bulletin boards contain seasonal information. Panel 2: Shenandoah Map. This graphic is divided into two columns, the left has text and images and the right has a map. On the right column, title text reads, "Welcome to Shenandoah National Park." Below the title is a color photograph of a man standing atop a rock outcrop and looking to the mountains in the distance on a sunny day. Layered on the image is the quote " for the recreation and the re-creation they shall find here." President Franklin Roosevelt, Shenandoah's Dedication." Text below the image reads, "Shenandoah National Park was established in 1935 to bring the western national park experience to the urban east. Here, within a few hours' drive of millions, you will find "recreation and re-creation." Experience the wonder of nature, the power of shared heritage, and the inspiration that is the future of our national parks." Below there is the subheading "Shenandoah Highlights," and the text "- Skyline Drive - 105 miles of beauty. Please observe the 35 mph speed limit to see it all safely. 75 Overlooks. Spectacular views of the Shenandoah Valley and Virginia Piedmont. 500 Miles of Trails - Beautiful waterfalls, quiet forests, and mountain summits are just a hike away. - Visitor Centers. Films, exhibits, and Ranger-led walks and talks tell Shenandoah's stories." The map to the right shows the boundaries of, driving route through, and highlights in Shenandoah National Park. The map area is 30 miles wide by 150 miles long. Shenandoah National Park is shaded green. Highlights include entrance stations, visitor centers, campgrounds, lodging, restrooms, food services, and trailheads. At the bottom of the map is the park emergency number: (800) 732-0911. At the top and bottom of the graphic are black bars. The black bar at the top has the text, "Shenandoah National Park," to the left, and "National Park Service, U.S. Department of the Interior," on the right with the National Park Service arrowhead logo to the far right. The lower black bar has the Leave No Trace logo on the left with the text "Leave No Trace Principe #6, Respect Wildlife," and on the right the text "www.nps.gov/shen." Panel 3: Spring/Summer Plants and Animals. The graphic is split into two horizontal sections with text and graphics in rectangles. The top section has the title, "Spring" with the subtitle "Renewal." The rectangle is split vertically. The left side contains three color photographs with text descriptions. The first image is white flowers with four petals labeled "Flowering Dogwood," and the accompanying text, "Dogwood blossoms are well-known messengers of spring, but this understory tree has other jobs, too - like providing food and shelter." The second image shows a mother deer and two fawns walking in high grasses labeled "White-tailed Deer" with the accompanying text "White-tailed deer hide their fawns under the dogwood's low-hanging branches and feed on its tender shoots, buds, and later, berries." The third image shows a dark blue bird with black tail feathers labeled "Indigo Bunting," and the accompanying text "Indigo buntings often build their nests in dogwood trees and line them with deer hair. Birds love the berries' high fat content, a great trade-off for the dogwood, since its seeds are spread by those who eat them, ensuring the dogwood's renewal." The right side of the top panel contains the text, "From the moment the first plant pushes up through the forest floor beginning its annual growth cycle, spring is renewal. Hungry black bears come out of their dens with winter-born cubs. Migratory birds return, butterflies emerge, and wildflowers herald the season. Every life, new and old, depends on another." There are nine color photographs under this text arranged in a 3 by 3 square. From the top left they are: a bush with clumps of white flowers labeled "Mountain Laurel," a butterfly with white and yellow markings and blue tips on the wings labeled "Eastern Tiger Swallowtail," round mounds of fungus growing out of the forest floor labeled "Morel Mushrooms" a small curled up salamander labeled "Red-backed Salamander," a bird with yellow, black, and white markings labeled "Chestnut-sided Warbler," a single white flower with three petals and large green leaves labeled "Large-flowered Trillium," a light brown toad on the ground labeled "Spring Pepper," a set of three yellow and red bell shaped flowers labeled "Wild Columbine," and a bird with a white chest and tan head and wings labeled "Red-eyed Vireo." The bottom section has the title "Summer" and the subtitle "Abundance."

title: Mill Prong - Laurel Prong Loop Trailhead
listingDescription: Milam Gap Parking Area (mile 52.8) | A circuit hike to Camp Rapidan, the rustic getaway of President Herbert Hoover and First Lady Lou Henry Hoover. Today, this restful spot features exhibits on the First Couple and their perspectives.

images.altText: An historic cabin with a large porch sits in the middle of a snow-covered forest.
images.title: Brown House

bodyText:
A circuit hike to Camp Rapidan, the rustic getaway of President Herbert Hoover and First Lady Lou Henry Hoover. Today, this restful spot features exhibits on the First Couple and their perspectives. This hike contains three stream crossings. Pets must be on a physical leash no longer than 6 feet at all times.

Distance: 7.4-mile circuit hike
Difficulty: Moderately Strenuous (explanation of our hiking difficulty scale)
Hiking Time: 8 hours
Elevation Gain: 1,520 feet

Hike Description

  1. From the Milam Gap Parking Area (mile 52.8), cross Skyline Drive and take the Appalachian Trail (A.T.) a few feet to the trailpost.
  2. Go left onto the blue-blazed Mill Prong Trail.
  3. Take a slight right onto the yellow-blazed Mill Prong Horse Trail and follow it to Rapidan Camp.
  4. After exploring the camp, take the Laurel Prong Trail (an old road trace), which is yellow-blazed, for about a half mile.
  5. Continue straight on Laurel Prong when it becomes blue-blazed and stay on it past the junction with Cat Knob Trail.
  6. At the junction with the A.T., turn right and follow it north across Hazeltop, the third highest peak in Shenandoah.
  7. The A.T. will take you back to your starting point Milam Gap.
audioDescription: The Milam Gap Trailhead panel is a 36 by 54 inch color poster. On the upper left of the panel is a black and white photograph of a man in bib overalls standing by a roadside fruit stand selling apples and apple cider. The text reads, "Apple of Their Eye - Apples were a cash crop for the people who lived in what is now Shenandoah National Park. Former residents raised different types of apples - some of which were actually created here - including the Milam, for which this gap is named. The Milam apple was probably developed in an orchard very near where you stand right now." The picture on the bottom left of the panel is a black and white photograph of President Herbert Hoover fly-fishing in one of the mountain streams that ran through his property. The text reads, "Fit for a President. The Park's clear mountain streams host a variety of fish species, including native eastern brook trout. Fly-fisherman and U.S. President Herbert Hoover chose a site two miles east of here, at the headwaters of the Rapidan River, for his weekend retreat because of its proximity to these streams and their trout. Rapidan Camp was built in 1929 and gave the 31st President the perfect place to practice his favorite pastime." The top right of the panel is a 20 by 20 inch topographic map of the hike to Rapidan Camp. The trail is marked in yellow with a brown dashed line. The text reads, "Suggested Hikes: Hike #1: Mill Prong - Rapidan Camp. 4-mile round trip, moderate, 2.75 hours hiking time, 870-foot elevation gain, 3 stream crossings. Go left on the Appalachian Trail south, and cross Skyline Drive. Go left on the blue-blazed Mill Prong Trail. Turn right on Mill Prong Horse Trail. Explore the camp, and then retrace your steps to Milam Gap parking." "Hike #2: Appalachian Trail - Tanners Ridge. The trail is marked in purple with a dashed line. 2.1-mile round trip, easiest, 1.5 hours hiking time, 175-foot elevation gain. Go right on the Appalachian Trail north to Tanners Ridge Road. Return by the same route to the starting point." A red text box below the map gives important information that hikers need. The text reads, "Emergency 1-800-732-0911 (cell phone service is unreliable.) Before You Go! Pets must be on a leash at all times. Do not attempt to cross streams in icy conditions or flooding. Be sure you are physically able to complete the hike you've chosen. Take plenty of water - at least a quart per hour Be sure you know your route. Free maps are available at entrance stations, visitors centers, and www.nps.gov/shen. When you return from your hike, check for ticks. Stay on the trail and avoid trampling sensitive vegetation. Be sure someone knows where you are and when to expect your return. Leave what you find. Artifacts are protected by law. Filter or treat water from streams before drinking. Please respect family cemeteries."

title: Millers Head Trailhead
listingDescription: Skyland Amphitheater (mile 42.5) | Take this hike to a spectacular viewpoint at the site of a former fire tower.

images.altText: A stone platform with a view of a valley below and blue mountains beyond.
images.title: View from Millers Head

bodyText:
Take this hike to a spectacular viewpoint at the site of a former fire tower. The trail is rocky and the return is a bit steep. Pets must be on a physical leash no longer than 6 feet at all times.

Distance: 1.6-mile round trip hike
Difficulty: Easiest (hiking difficulty scale)
Hiking Time: 2 hours
Elevation Gain: 450 feet

Hike Description

  1. From the trailhead just up the hill from the Skyland Amphitheater (mile 42.5), take the Millers Head Trail to the viewpoint.
  2. Retrace your steps down the Millers Head Trail to return to your starting point.

title: Moormans River Overlook
listingDescription: Facing east-southeast from an elevation of 2,975 ft (906 m), Moormans River Overlook looks straight out to the Charlottesville Reservoir, fed by Moorman's River.

images.altText: A view from atop a field looking down to mountains in the distance.
images.title: Moormans River Overlook

bodyText: Facing east-southeast from an elevation of 2,975 ft (906 m), Moormans River Overlook looks straight out to the Charlottesville Reservoir, fed by Moorman's River. Moorman's River has flooded many times, notably in 1895, 1924, 1942, and most recently on June 27, 1995. The 1995 flooding caused nearly 100 landslides. The Charlottesville Reservoir, also called Sugar Hollow Reservoir, contained much of the debris flowing downstream and prevented damage to homes nearby.
audioDescription: This overlook faces east-southeast. From atop a field the landscape sweeps down to the mountains below. Straight ahead and partially hidden behind a hill is a body of water, the Charlottesville Reservoir. To the left of the reservoir is Pasture Fence Mountain. To the right and in front of the reservoir is Sawlog Ridge. Behind Sawlog Ridge is the long ridge of Bucks Elbow Mountain.

title: Mount Marshall Overlook
listingDescription: Mount Marshall Overlooks sits at an elevation of 2,850 ft (868 m) and looks southeast onto the Piedmont region of Virginia.

images.altText: A view from and overlook looking down into valley with hills in the distance.
images.title: Mount Marshall Overlook

bodyText: Mount Marshall Overlooks sits at an elevation of 2,850 ft (868 m) and looks southeast onto the Piedmont region of Virginia. The land around Mount Marshall was once part of a land grant known as the Manor of Leeds belonging to Thomas, 6th Lord of Fairfax. After Fairfax died, the land went to his heirs, who sold it to speculators. The speculator who purchased this land was John Marshall, still well known today for his long tenure as a Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States. Marshall held this position from 1801 to 1835, during which time he made many decisions supporting federalism and made a lasting impact on the judicial branch of government.
audioDescription: This overlook faces southeast over a field and into the foothills blow. To the left are the two peaks on Mount Marshall, with South Marshall on the left and North Marshall on the right. Straight ahead is Jenkins Mountain with The Peak further away to the left. The Piedmont region of Virginia expands into the horizon.

title: Naked Creek Overlook
listingDescription: Looking west from an elevation of 3,250 ft (990 m), the view from Naked Creek Overlook stretches out beyond the tree line and out to the hills beyond. Nestled in the foothills below is the small town of Elkton.

images.altText: View of field with trees in distance and hills at horizon.
images.title: Naked Creek Overlook

bodyText: Looking west from an elevation of 3,250 ft (990 m), the view from Naked Creek Overlook stretches out beyond the tree line and out to the hills beyond. Nestled in the foothills below is the small town of Elkton. One of the historic buildings in the town is Jennings House. Dr. Simeon Jennings built this eight room brick structure in 1840. After the battles of Cross Keys and Port Republic, the house became a Confederate hospital where Dr. Jennings and his wife cared for injured soldiers.
audioDescription: This overlook faces west. There is a field that extends to a line of trees. Beyond the trees are a series of ridges in the distance. From the right is Long Ridge, behind and slightly smaller is Grindstone Mountain. Further to the left is Green Mountain and behind that is Hanse Mountain. In the valley between Green Mountain and Grindstone Mountain is the town of Elkton.

title: Nicholson Hollow via Park Boundary Trailhead
listingDescription: Old Rag Parking Area (Park Boundary) | An alternate option for visitors with pets who still wish to hike from the Old Rag parking area. This hike takes you to Corbin Cabin, an old homesite built by a former resident, and features several stream crossings along the way.

images.altText: An old, decaying log building is shrouded in fog in the middle of the woods.
images.title: Corbin Cabin Area

bodyText:
An alternate option for visitors with pets who still wish to hike from the Old Rag Parking Area on the Park boundary. This hike takes you to Corbin Cabin, an old homesite built by a former resident, and features several stream crossings along the way. There are several stream crossings on this hike. Pets must be on a physical leash no longer than 6 feet long at all times.

Distance: 8-mile round trip hike
Difficulty: Moderately Strenuous (hiking difficulty scale)
Hiking Time: 7 hours
Elevation Gain: 1,240 feet

Hike Description 

  1. From the Old Rag Parking Area on the Park boundary, look for the Nicholson Hollow Trail concrete marker across the road.
  2. Follow the Nicholson Hollow Trail to Corbin Cabin and retrace your steps to return.

Directions to Old Rag Parking Area from Sperryville: From Route 211, turn onto Route 522 and follow it south for 0.8-mile. Turn right on Route 231, follow 8 miles, turn right onto Route 601 and follow signs to the Old Rag parking area, approximately 3 miles.

Directions to Old Rag Parking Area from Madison: From Route 29 Business, turn onto Route 231 and follow it for 12.8 miles. Turn left onto Route 602. Follow signs for the parking area. Old Rag parking is approximately 3 miles from the turn onto Route 602.

title: No Name Overlook
listingDescription: This unassuming overlook really is named No Name Overlook, but that doesn't mean there is nothing to see! Facing west-northwest and at an elevation of 1,985 ft (605 m), No Name Overlook looks down upon the Shenandoah Valley.

images.altText: View of Shenandoah Valley and hills in the distance.
images.title: No Name Overlook
images.caption: What's the view from No Name Overlook?

bodyText: This unassuming overlook really is named No Name Overlook, but that doesn't mean there is nothing to see! Facing west-northwest and at an elevation of 1,985 ft (605 m), No Name Overlook looks down upon the Shenandoah Valley. Straight ahead is where the Massanutten Mountain Range splits the Shenandoah Valley in half. To the right is Dickey Ridge with a slice of Skyline Drive cutting through the hills.
audioDescription: This overlook faces west-northwest across the Shenandoah Valley. From the left is the Massanutten Mountain Range that splits the valley in two at its northern most point near Signal Knob. The Shenandoah River weaves through the landscape. The hill to the right is Dickey Ridge with some of Skyline Drive running through the hills.

title: Old Rag Circuit Trailhead
listingDescription: Old Rag Parking Area (Park Boundary) | Visitors must obtain an Old Rag day-use ticket in advance of this hike. Pets are not allowed. Old Rag is a popular, very strenuous hike with sweeping views and several scrambles across large rocks. This route starts from the Old Rag parking area on the boundary of the Park.

images.altText: Two hikers standing on a huge boulder looking over a view of mountain ranges and a green valley
images.title: Hikers on Old Rag Summit

bodyText:
From March 1 - November 30, visitors to Old Rag Mountain, including hikers on the Saddle, Ridge, and Ridge Access trails, will need to obtain an Old Rag day-use ticket in advance, in addition to a Park entrance pass. Find out more information on our Old Rag day-use ticket FAQ page.

Pets are not allowed on this hike.

Featuring an adventurous rock scramble and a 360-degree view that makes you feel like you're on top of the world, there's no wonder why Old Rag is the most popular destination in Shenandoah National Park. While highly rewarding, hiking to the summit is also very physically demanding and can be dangerous if you have not planned properly, so be sure to check out our Old Rag planning guide before you lace up your boots!

Distance: 9.4-mile circuit hike
Difficulty: Very Strenuous (hiking difficulty scale)
Hiking Time: 7 hours 30 minutes
Elevation Gain: 2,348 feet

Hike Description

  1. From the Old Rag parking area at the Park boundary, take the blue-blazed Ridge Trail.
  2. Continue along the Ridge Trail, across the rock scramble and descend on the Saddle Trail (blue-blazed), which becomes a fire road after you pass Old Rag Shelter.
  3. At the T-intersection, go right and immediately right again at the fork onto Weakley Hollow Fire Road (yellow-blazed).
  4. Turn right onto the Ridge Access Trail and then left onto the Ridge Trail to return to your starting point.

Directions to Old Rag Parking Area from Sperryville: From Route 211, turn onto Route 522 and follow it south for 0.8-mile. Turn right on Route 231, follow 8 miles, turn right onto Route 601 and follow signs to the Old Rag parking area, approximately 3 miles.

Directions to Old Rag Parking Area from Madison: From Route 29 Business, turn onto Route 231 and follow it for 12.8 miles. Turn left onto Route 602. Follow signs for the parking area. Old Rag parking is approximately 3 miles from the turn onto Route 602.
audioDescription: The Old Rag Mountain Trailhead is a 36 by 54 inch color poster. The poster is organized into two columns. On the left the first column begins with the title, "Did You Know?" with a photograph of two hikers helping each other over a large boulder. This image is folloThe Old Rag Mountain Trailhead is a 36 by 54 inch color poster. The poster is organized into two columns. On the left the first column begins with the title, "Did You Know?" with a photograph of two hikers helping each other over a large boulder. This image is followed by the subtitle, "Are You Ready to Hike This Trail?" with text underneath, "The trail to Old Rag summit is strenuous and extremely challenging. Do not attempt this hike unless you are physically able and fully prepared." A list follows, "Wear sturdy footwear. Bring plenty of water and extra food. Bring flashlights and extra clothing in case of emergencies. Be sure you know what time it gets dark and leave adequate time to complete your hike. Note that cell phone service is unreliable throughout the hiking area. There is no public transportation in the Old Rag area." Below this text is a color photograph of a large boulder piles with people scrambling to the top. Below is a second subtitle, "Pets" followed by the text, "Pets are NOT permitted on the Ridge and Saddle Trails. This rule is strictly enforced. Pet owners have the special responsibility of following the park regulations for pets. The challenging terrain and unique habitat of Old Rag mountain make this trail unsuitable and dangerous for pets. If you have a pet, we recommend Hike #2." Beginning the second column on the upper right is a 20 by 20 inch north-oriented topographic map with two recommended hikes highlighted, Hike #1 in yellow and Hike #2 in pink. The text below reads, Hike #1: Old Rag Summit, 9.2-mile circuit, very strenuous, 7-½ hours hiking time, 2,380-foot elevation gain. From the parking area, make a left onto Route 600. Pass the Nicholson Hollow Trailhead and continue to the Ridge Trail. Make a left and continue on the Ridge Trail, crossing the rock scramble to the summit. Be very careful as the footing along the Ridge Trail is challenging, especially in the rock scramble area. Descend from the summit on the Saddle Trail. Continue to follow this path as you pass Old Rag Shelter and the trail becomes a fire road. At the trail intersection, make a right and immediately turn right again to follow Weakley Hollow Fire Road. Continue on this fire road and stay straight on the intersection with Route 600 back to this location. Hike #2: Robertson Mountain, 7.8 mile circuit, strenuous, 6 -½ hours hiking time, 2,130-foot elevation gain. From the parking area, make a left onto Route 600. Pass the Nicholson Hollow Trailhead and continue straight on to the Weakley Hollow Fire Road. Take Weakley Hollow Fire Road to Robertson Mountain Trail. Follow the Robertson Mountain Trail to the summit and descend to the Old Rag Fire Road. Turn left onto Old Rag Fire Road and then another left onto Weakley Hollow Fire Road. Continue on this fire road and stay straight on the intersection with Route 600 back to this location. This hike includes one of the steepest sections of trails in the park, but it is a good alternative for hikers in good physical condition who want a pet-friendly hike with excellent views." A red text box below the map gives important information that hikers need. The text reads, "Emergency 1-800-732-0911 (cell phone service is unreliable.) Before You Go! Pets are not allowed on the Ridge and Saddle Trails. Be sure you are physically able to complete the hike you've chosen. - Do not attempt this hike in wet or icy conditions. Take plenty of water-at least a quart per hour. Be sure you know your route. Free maps are available at entrance stations, visitor centers, and www.nps.gov/shen. When you return from your hike, check for ticks. Be sure someone knows where you are and when to expect your return.wed by the subtitle, "Are You Ready to Hike This Trail?" with text underneath, "The trail to Old Rag summit is strenuous and extremely challenging. Do not attempt this hike unless you are physically able and fully prepared." A list follows, "Wear sturdy footwear. Bring plenty of water and extra food. Bring flashlights and extra clothing in case of emergencies. Be sure you know what time it gets dark and leave adequate time to complete your hike. Note that cell phone service is unreliable throughout the hiking area. There is no public transportation in the Old Rag area." title: Old Rag Mountain
listingDescription: PARK BOUNDARY | Featuring hikes with adventurous rock scrambles and 360-degree views that make you feel like you're on top of the world, there's no wonder why Old Rag Mountain is the most popular destination in Shenandoah National Park. Old Rag is usually accessed from the Park boundary, as accessing it from Skyline Drive makes for an incredibly long hike.

images.altText: A rock outcrop overlooks mountain layers below, exploding with fall colors: red, orange, and yellow
images.title: Old Rag Summit

bodyText:
From March 1 to November 30, visitors to Old Rag Mountain, including hikers on the Saddle, Ridge, and Ridge Access trails, will need to obtain an Old Rag day-use ticket in advance, in addition to a Park entrance pass. Find out more information on our Old Rag day-use ticket FAQ page.

Featuring hikes with adventurous rock scrambles and 360-degree views that make you feel like you're on top of the world, there's no wonder why Old Rag is the most popular destination in Shenandoah National Park. 

While highly rewarding, hiking to the summit of Old Rag is also very physically demanding and can be dangerous if you have not planned properly. In order to ensure your safety and make the most out of your hike, be sure that you understand the basics of hiking safety before you set out on your adventure. Aside from these basics, there are a few more things that you need to know before hiking Old Rag:

Know Your Limits

Be sure that you are physically able to complete the hikes on Old Rag Mountain. Most hikes in this area are long, and there is significant elevation change with a strenuous rock scramble that requires good upper body strength. Often, children and shorter adults need assistance navigating the rock scramble.

Bring a Map

There are several different ways to hike Old Rag, so make sure that you pick the best route for you. Compare the different options and print or download the Old Rag trail map so that you have it with you while you're hiking.

Pack Lightly

Although you need to be sure you have plenty of water and food, it is a good idea to pack as lightly as possible. Most hikers prefer fanny packs to backpacks, which can be difficult to maneuver through the rock scramble.

Avoid the Crowds

Planning your hike on a weekday will likely enhance your experience since Old Rag can become very crowded on weekends. At times, the parking lot will be full, and there can be long lines and substantial waits at some of the narrow rock scrambles. During periods of peak visitation (summer and fall), you may want to consider a less-crowded hike.

Leave Your Pets at Home

Pets are prohibited on the Ridge, Saddle, Ridge Access trails, and from Post Office Junction to Old Rag Shelter. 

Know the Camping Regulations

Legal overnight camping sites are very limited in the Old Rag area as camping is prohibited above 2,800', so be sure to properly plan your backcountry trip.

Note the Numbers

You will notice numbers beneath the trail blazes on Old Rag. These are reference numbers for Search and Rescue personnel, so take note of the numbers as you pass them. If you need to report an incident, referring to the number you are closest to will help Park staff respond to you more quickly.

Tread Lightly

Old Rag is host to many rare and endangered plants that live in the rocky environment of the granite boulders. These plants are particularly susceptible to trampling, so please stay on the trail and observe all rock outcrop management closure areas.

Hiking Old Rag in the Winter

Be sure to carry microspikes or traction coil devices for your boots with you when you hike Old Rag. Even when it's perfectly clear in lower elevations, trails can be be icy and snow-covered during colder weather, and these devices can protect you from a nasty fall.

Parking

Although Old Rag Mountain is within the boundaries of Shenandoah National Park, most people approach it from the Park's eastern boundary, instead of from Skyline Drive. You are still required to pay an entrance fee, but parking at the lots operated by the National Park Service is free. Landowners with property adjacent to the Park are charging a fee for parking on their property, but paying a private citizen to park does not exempt you from the Park entrance fee. Parking is prohibited along the road shoulders.

Directions

Do not rely exclusively on your mobile GPS, Google Maps, or similar automated navigation systems to get to the Old Rag parking area. Routes can be misleading and incorrect, and cell service is unreliable

Sperryville to Old Rag Parking: From Route 211, turn onto Route 522 and follow it south for 0.8 mile. Turn right on Route 231, follow 8 miles, turn right onto Route 601 and follow signs to the Old Rag parking area, approximately 3 miles.
Madison to Old Rag Parking: From Route 29 Business, turn onto Route 231 and follow it for 12.8 miles. Turn left onto Route 602. Follow signs for the parking area, approximately 3 miles.
Sperryville to Berry Hollow Parking: take Rt. 231 S, turn right onto Rt. 643, then right onto Weakley Hollow Rd. Follow for about 4.5 miles to parking area. Parking is extremely limited.
Madison to Berry Hollow Parking: take Rt. 231 N, turn left onto Rt. 670, right onto Rt. 643, then continue straight onto Weakley Hollow Rd. Go past the Whiteoak Canyon parking area to Berry Hollow parking area. Parking is extremely limited.

title: Old Rag Parking and Fee Station
listingDescription: Park and pay the entrance fee here for entering Shenandoah National Park to hike Old Rag. Parking is limited, and will often fill up completely on busy days. Be prepared to pay the entrance fee at the boundary. Paying a private individual to park does not cover the entrance fee.

images.altText: A color photograph of a rocky peak rising above pastoral farmland.
images.title: Old Rag Parking and Fee Station
images.caption: Old Rag Mountain seen from the east.

bodyText: Park and pay the entrance fee here for entering Shenandoah National Park to hike Old Rag. Parking is limited, and will often fill up completely on busy days. Be prepared to pay the entrance fee at the boundary. Paying a private individual to park does not cover the entrance fee.
audioDescription: A parking lot with a small covered booth on the far end near the road where there is a Ranger present to collect fees and provide information about Old Rag.

title: Old Rag Summit via Berry Hollow Trailhead
listingDescription: Berry Hollow Parking Area (Park Boundary) | Visitors must obtain an Old Rag day-use ticket in advance of this hike. Pets are not allowed. Old Rag is a popular, strenuous hike with sweeping views. This route starts from the Berry Hollow parking area and allows you to get to the summit without having to navigate the rock scramble.

images.altText: Color photo, a summit of rocks highlighted by the yellows and reds of fall colors.
images.title: View from Old Rag Summit

tags: Old Rag Summit from Berry Hollow
bodyText:
From March 1 - November 30, visitors to Old Rag Mountain, including hikers on the Saddle, Ridge, and Ridge Access trails, will need to obtain an Old Rag day-use ticket in advance, in addition to a Park entrance pass. Find out more information on our Old Rag day-use ticket FAQ page.

Pets are not allowed on this hike.

Old Rag is a popular, strenuous hike with sweeping views. This route starts from the Berry Hollow parking area and allows you to get to the summit without having to navigate the rock scramble. Even without the scramble, however, hiking to the summit is physically demanding and can be dangerous if you have not planned properly. Be sure to check out our Old Rag planning guide before you lace up your boots! 

Distance: 5.4-mile round trip hike
Difficulty: Strenuous (hiking difficulty scale)
Hiking Time: 6 hours 15 minutes
Elevation Gain: 1,760 feet

Hike Description 

  1. From the trailhead at the Berry Hollow Parking Area on the Park boundary, hike the Berry Hollow Road 0.8-mile to the junction with Old Rag Fire Road.
  2. Turn right and continue 0.4-mile to the Old Rag Shelter.
  3. Turn left onto the Saddle Trail and continue the remaining 1.6 miles to the summit.
  4. Return to the parking area by the same route to avoid the Ridge Trail rock scramble.

Directions to Berry Hollow Parking Area from Sperryville
Start by taking Route 231 South past the turnoff for Nethers. From Madison, start from Route 29 Business, turning onto Route 231. Once on Route 231 (from either Sperryville or Madison), turn onto Route 670 near Banco. Turn right at Syria, then left onto Route 600. Go past the Whiteoak Canyon parking area to Berry Hollow parking area. Parking is extremely limited.

title: Old Rag View Overlook
listingDescription: Looking east-northeast from an elevation of 3,585 ft (1,092 m), Old Rag View Overlook will give you a glimpse of Old Rag, located about 3 miles away.

images.altText: An open field with a mountain visible in the distance.
images.title: Old Rag View Overlook

bodyText: Looking east-northeast from an elevation of 3,585 ft (1,092 m), Old Rag View Overlook will give you a glimpse of Old Rag, located about 3 miles away. The summit of Old Rag sits at 3,291 ft (1,003 m), and the climb up from the Park boundary is one of the most popular hikes in Shenandoah National Park. The strenuous circuit hike has an elevation gain of 2,415 ft (736 m) and is a little over 9 miles long.
audioDescription: This overlook faces east-northeast. There is an open field with sparse trees surrounded by a tree line further off. Straight ahead in the distance there is the peak of Old Rag Mountain.

title: Overall Run Falls Trailhead
listingDescription: Mathews Arm Campground (mile 22.1) | A hike through federally designated Wilderness to a view of the highest waterfall in the Park at 93 feet. Unless rain is plentiful, Overall Run Falls may have minimal to no water flow.

images.altText: A viewpoint down into a small canyon lined with green trees with a valley beyond.
images.title: View from Overall Run Falls

bodyText:
A hike through federally designated Wilderness to a view of the highest waterfall in the Park at 93 feet. Unless rain is plentiful, Overall Run Falls may have minimal to no water flow. Pets must be on a physical leash no longer than 6 feet long at all times.

Note that very limited closures are in effect in an effort to prevent further degradation of important outcrop ecosystems on Overall Run.

Distance: 5.1-mile round trip hike
Difficulty: Moderately Strenuous (explanation of our hiking difficulty scale)
Hiking Time: 4 hours
Elevation Gain: 1,291 feet

Hike Description

  1. From the trailhead at the Mathews Arm Campground Registration Parking Area (mile 22.1), take Traces Trail to the yellow-blazed Mathews Arm Road.
  2. The road becomes Mathews Arm Trail.
  3. Stay on the right at its intersection with Beecher Ridge Trail and continue on Mathews Arm Trail following it to the intersection with Tuscarora-Overall Run Trail.
  4. Go left and follow it about a tenth of a mile to a side trail. From here you can see the upper falls.
  5. Continue downhill on the main trail another 1,300 feet for views of the biggest falls in Shenandoah at 93 feet.
  6. Retrace your steps back to your starting point.

NOTE: If the campground is closed, you can park at mile 21 and take the Appalachian Trail to the Tuscarora-Overall Run Trail. This route adds another mile to your hike. If you are already in the campground, you can take the yellow-blazed Mathews Arm Road from the B-loop.
audioDescription: The Overall Run Trailhead panel is a 36 by 54 inch color poster. On the upper left of the panel is a photograph taken of a view of the vivid green of the Wilderness, the blue-green of the mountains, and the powder blue of the sky with a line of white clouds bisecting the tranquil scene. The text reads, "Border Crossing: To reach Overall Run Falls, you cross an invisible boundary into Wilderness. You will find all the things you expect to see in the woods: green plants, elusive animals, and water tumbling free over rocks and roots. You won't find many things built by human hands, such as campgrounds and roads. This is by design: Wilderness is specially designated land that is kept free of development to always be wild and natural. Such designation protects the ecosystem and provides enjoyment for those who wish to enter. Wilderness's primeval character offers you physical and mental challenges, solitude, and refreshment." "Standing on the ledge above Overall Run Falls, you are surrounded by Wilderness. You won't hear much of anything except for the roar of the falls, the croak of the raven, and a breeze in the leaves. You delight in the journey that brought you here and the simplicity of nature. This is the Wilderness experience." The top right of the panel is a 20 by 20 inch topographic map of 2 hikes: one to Overall Run Falls. That trail is marked in yellow with a brown dashed line. The text reads, "Suggested Hikes: Hike #1: Overall Run Falls; 6.1 mile round trip, moderately strenuous, 4.75 hours hiking time, 1,694-foot elevation gain. Follow the Appalachian Trail south. Turn right on Tuscarora-Overall Run Trail. Follow the trail to a rock viewpoint from which Overall Run Falls is visible. Retrace your steps to return to the starting point." "Hike #2: (The shorter round trip trail is marked in purple on the map.) Appalachian Trail North: 0.5 mile round trip, easiest, 0.5 hour hiking time, 114-foot elevation gain. Leave the parking lot from the south end and follow the Appalachian Trail (A.T.) north across the Skyline Drive. Continue on the A.T. north to the vista. Retrace your steps to return to the starting point." A red text box below the map gives important information that hikers need. The text reads, "Emergency 1-800-732-0911 (cell phone service is unreliable.) Before You Go! Be sure you are physically able to complete the hike you've chosen. ~ Be sure you know your route. Free maps are available at entrance stations, visitors centers, and www.nps.gov/shen. Take plenty of water - at least a quart per. Pets must be on a leash at all times. When you return from your hike, check for ticks. Be sure someone knows where you are and when to expect your return."

quickFacts.name: Location

title: Panorama
listingDescription: Just south of Thornton Gap Entrance Station is Panorama. Panorama is a large parking lot where there are restrooms with running water, water fountains, and park information on an orientation shelter and bulletin boards. Open year-round.

images.altText: A building with interpretive panels outside surrounded by a parking area.
images.title: Panorama
images.caption: Panorama has restrooms, bulletin boards, and water fountains.

bodyText: Just south of Thornton Gap Entrance Station is Panorama. Panorama is a large parking lot where there are restrooms with running water, water fountains, and park information on an orientation shelter and bulletin boards. Open year-round.
audioDescription: Turning off Skyline Drive, Panorama is a parking area next to a building. The building has a stone base, brown wood walls, and slanted roof. The building is split into two sections with the roof extending between the two creating a sheltered area. Inside are bathroom doors, water fountains, and bulletin boards with seasonal information. There is an orientation shelter between the entrance from Skyline Drive and the restrooms. The orientation shelter is a small roof supported by six brown beams. The beams are frames for six upright 36 inch by 54 inch posters in glass enclosures. Panel 1: Bulletin Board Bulletin boards contain seasonal information. Panel 2: Shenandoah Map This graphic is divided into two columns, the left has text and images and the right has a map. On the right column, title text reads, "Welcome to Shenandoah National Park." Below the title is a color photograph of a man standing atop a rock outcrop and looking to the mountains in the distance on a sunny day. Layered on the image is the quote " ...for the recreation and the re-creation they shall find here." -President Franklin Roosevelt, Shenandoah's Dedication." Text below the image reads, "Shenandoah National Park was established in 1935 to bring the western national park experience to the urban east. Here, within a few hours' drive of millions, you will find "recreation and re-creation." Experience the wonder of nature, the power of shared heritage, and the inspiration that is the future of our national parks." Below there is the subheading "Shenandoah Highlights," and the text "- Skyline Drive - 105 miles of beauty. Please observe the 35 mph speed limit to see it all safely. - 75 Overlooks - Spectacular views of the Shenandoah Valley and Virginia Piedmont. - 500 Miles of Trails - Beautiful waterfalls, quiet forests, and mountain summits are just a hike away. - Visitor Centers - Films, exhibits, and Ranger-led walks and talks tell Shenandoah's stories. "The map to the right shows the boundaries of, driving route through, and highlights in Shenandoah National Park. The map area is 30 miles wide by 150 miles long. Shenandoah National Park is shaded green. Highlights include entrance stations, visitor centers, campgrounds, lodging, restrooms, food services, and trailheads. At the bottom of the map is the park emergency number: (800) 732-0911. At the top and bottom of the graphic are black bars. The black bar at the top has the text, "Shenandoah National Park," to the left, and "National Park Service, U.S. Department of the Interior," on the right with the National Park Service arrowhead logo to the far right. The lower black bar has the Leave No Trace logo on the left with the text "Leave No Trace Principe #6, Respect Wildlife," and on the right the text "www.nps.gov/shen." Panel 3: Spring/Summer Plants and Animals The graphic is split into two horizontal sections with text and graphics in rectangles. The top section has the title, "Spring" with the subtitle "Renewal." The rectangle is split vertically. The left side contains three color photographs with text descriptions. The first image is white flowers with four petals labeled "Flowering Dogwood," and the accompanying text, "Dogwood blossoms are well-known messengers of spring, but this understory tree has other jobs, too - like providing food and shelter." The second image shows a mother deer and two fawns walking in high grasses labeled "White-tailed Deer" with the accompanying text "White-tailed deer hide their fawns under the dogwood's low-hanging branches and feed on its tender shoots, buds, and later, berries." The third image shows a dark blue bird with black tail feathers labeled "Indigo Bunting," and the accompanying text "Indigo buntings often build their nests in dogwood trees and line them with deer hair. Birds love the berries' high fat content, a great trade-off for the dogwood, since its seeds are spread by those who eat them, ensuring the dogwood's renewal." The right side of the top panel contains the text, "From the moment the first plant pushes up through the forest floor beginning its annual growth cycle, spring is renewal. Hungry black bears come out of their dens with winter-born cubs. Migratory birds return, butterflies emerge, and wildflowers herald the season. Every life, new and old, depends on another." There are nine color photographs under this text arranged in a 3 by 3 square. From the top left they are: a bush with clumps of white flowers labeled "Mountain Laurel," a butterfly with white and yellow markings and blue tips on the wings labeled "Eastern Tiger Swallowtail," round mounds of fungus growing out of the forest floor labeled "Morel Mushrooms" a small curled up salamander labeled "Red-backed Salamander," a bird with yellow, black, and white markings labeled "Chestnut-sided Warbler," a single white flower with three petals and large green leaves labeled "Large-flowered Trillium," a light brown toad on the ground labeled "Spring Pepper."

title: Pass Mountain Loop Trailhead
listingDescription: Panorama Parking Area (mile 31.6) | A hike along the Appalachian Trail to a shelter. Be on the lookout for wildflowers and birds through the fairly open woods along the trail!

images.altText: Color photo showing green trees surround an overlook looking down into a valley below.
images.title: View from Pass Mountain Overlook

bodyText:
A hike along the Appalachian Trail to a shelter. Be on the lookout for wildflowers and birds through the fairly open woods along the trail! Pets must be on a physical leash no longer than 6 feet at all times.

Distance: 3.4-mile round trip hike
Difficulty: Moderate (hiking difficulty scale)
Hiking Time: 2 hours 30 minutes
Elevation Gain: 670 feet

Hike Description 

  1. From the back of the Panorama Parking Area (mile 31.6), take the short connector trail to the Appalachian Trail (A.T.) and go right (north).
  2. Cross Route 211 and Skyline Drive.
  3. Go right onto the fire road and follow it to the hut.
  4. Once there, look for the blue-blazed Pass Mountain Trail and take that back to the A.T. south, which will take you back to your starting point.

title: Pass Mountain Overlook
listingDescription: Looking west from an elevation of 2,460 ft (749 m), Pass Mountain Overlook gives you the chance to glance over Kemp Hollow and Neighbor Mountain, into the town of Luray below.

images.altText: A view over brush down into a valley with mountains in the distance.
images.title: Pass Mountain Overlook

bodyText: Looking west from an elevation of 2,460 ft (749 m), Pass Mountain Overlook gives you the chance to glance over Kemp Hollow and Neighbor Mountain, into the town of Luray below. The town of Luray was officially established of February 6, 1812. There are multiple stories about how the town of Luray got its name, but it is most likely named in honor of Luray, France, the ancestral homeland of the town's founder, William Staige Marye.
audioDescription: This overlook faces west. On the right is Neighbor Mountain descending to Shenandoah Valley with Kemp Hollow between Neighbor Mountain and the overlook. To the left is the town of Luray in the Shenandoah Valley with the ridge of Massanutten Mountain spanning the horizon. There is an interpretive sign at this overlook. The Pass Mountain Overlook interpretive sign is a 36 by 24 inch color graphic panel on a dark metal frame angled towards the viewer. The title text reads, "Gaps in the Story." The body text reads, "Imagine it's 1740. You're traveling west, and you've arrived at this point on Pass Mountain. You have to cross that next mountain on the other side of the valley, and there are no roads to guide you. Where will you cross? Most people would choose the gap, or low spot in the mountain, you see about 16 miles off in the distance. Called New Market Gap today, that natural passageway makes traveling from one side of the mountain to the other easier, faster, and cheaper, even today. Look at your Park map. How many gaps can you find in Shenandoah? Consider how many people have traveled across those places through the centuries." Below the text is a photograph of the Shenandoah Valley in the foreground, with the river weaving through the agricultural landscape, and the Blue Ridge Mountains of Shenandoah National Park in the distance. Layered on the image is the text "You Are Here" with an arrow pointing to a tiny notch in one of the mountains. Under the text is more text "Looking back at Shenandoah National Park from New Market Gap (west), you can see the notch of Thornton Gap in the Blue Ridge Mountains, the first obstacle westward travelers had to overcome on their way from the east to the Shenandoah Valley and beyond." To the left is another text overlay at a low point between two mountains labeled with the text, "Thornton Gap." To the right of the main text are two black and white images on a black transparent background. The title text, "Travelers and Commerce," is above the images. The top image shows a road leading through a gap in the mountains accompanied by the text, "To get to New Market Gap from here, travelers first crossed Thornton Gap, a half mile south of here. The old footpath became a road, and then a turnpike in the 1700s. Travelers paid a toll to use smooth roads free of mud and ruts." The lower image shows a large house by a road with old fashioned gas pumps in front accompanied by the text, "Turnpike owners and local residents profited from travelers through inns, and later, filling stations. Travelers that stopped by Ramey's filling station on Rt. 211 in 1935 could purchase ten-cent ham sandwiches, drinks, ice, cider, and handmade baskets." A black bar on the top of the graphic reads "Shenandoah National Park" on the left and on the right is the National Park Service Arrowhead symbol with the text "National Park Service/U.S. Department of the Interior"

title: Piney River CCC Building
listingDescription: A Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) Camp was once situated in this area. This building was the camp's technical building and is one of a very few remaining CCC structures. Shenandoah National Park with the help of the National Park Foundation is attempting to raise money to restore this building to its original appearance and install exhibits designed to acquaint visitors with the stories of the CCC in Shenandoah.

images.altText: A long building with an L-on the front. A vehicle sits in front of it.
images.title: Piney River CCC Building
images.caption: The Piney River Technical building was home to landscape architects working on Park infrastructure.

bodyText: A Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) Camp was once situated in this area. This building was the camp's technical building and is one of a very few remaining CCC structures. Shenandoah National Park with the help of the National Park Foundation is attempting to raise money to restore this building to its original appearance and install exhibits designed to acquaint visitors with the stories of the CCC in Shenandoah.
audioDescription: A green T-shaped building that is obviously aging. Across the road is painted brown sign on a wooden post that reads "Civilian Conservation Corps: During the 1930's, this area was the site of CCC Camp NP-12, Company 1393, known as the 'Redbird Camp.'"

title: Pinnacles Overlook
listingDescription: Looking south from an elevation of 3,320 ft (1011 m), Hannah Run and Old Rag Mountain can be seen from Pinnacles Overlook.

images.altText: View over hedge of mountains in the distance.
images.title: Pinnacles Overlook

bodyText: Looking south from an elevation of 3,320 ft (1011 m), Hannah Run and Old Rag Mountain can be seen from Pinnacles Overlook. Pinnacles Ridge is the close ridge on the right side of the view. Across Hannah Run is Hot Mountain on the left.
audioDescription: This overlook faces south over a hedge and to the mountains beyond. Pinnacle Ridge stretches from the front right of the scene and moves into the distance. In the distance from the left is Hot Mountain. Hannah Run falls in between where Hot Mountains and Pinnacle Ridge descend. Straight ahead, but far away is Old Rag. There is an interpretive sign at this overlook. The Pinnacles Overlook interpretive sign is a 36 by 24 inch color graphic panel on a dark metal frame angled towards the viewer. The graphic is divided vertically into two panels with the text on the left over a transparent green background and an image on the right. The title reads "Wild Freedom." Under the title is a quote that reads, "... where the earth and its community of life are untrammeled by man, where man himself is a visitor who does not remain.' The Wilderness Act of 1964" The body text reads, "Welcome, visitor. What do you see? Wilderness stretches before you in an unbroken wave of green and gray, cradled by the craggy heights of Old Rag and bounded by civilization beyond. Although in appearance the land is the same color and shape as the mountainsides seen from other overlooks, this land is different. This is Wilderness, a place set apart from other natural places. The impact of modern man and technology is absent in Wilderness. You won't find buildings, developments, or machines here. And you, the visitor who does not remain, can experience nature in its purest form-unconstrained and primitive-and find opportunities for solitude, refreshment, or adventure." Next to the text, but on the same panel, is the shape of Shenandoah National Park with a white fill and bright yellow fill in some places. Under the shape there is a key with a yellow block text explaining that the yellow is "Federally Designated Wilderness within Shenandoah National Park." Under this graphic there is the text, "Wilderness is public land that is managed in accordance with the Wilderness Act. Wilderness must be primitive, natural, untrammeled, free of human elements, and unique. Nearly 40% (79,579 acres) of Shenandoah is Wilderness. Experience Wilderness from above at the overlooks, or find a trailhead and start walking." The panel to the right contains a photograph of a single person walking along a narrow trail in the woods on a sunny day. A black bar on the top of the graphic reads "Shenandoah National Park" on the left and on the right is the National Park Service Arrowhead symbol with the text "National Park Service/U.S. Department of the Interior"

title: Pinnacles Picnic Grounds
listingDescription: The picnic grounds are open; the shelter is not. Pinnacles Picnic Grounds is open year round. There are picnic tables, fire grates for cooking, and water. There is also an open pavilion with picnic tables and fireplaces available on a first-come, first-served basis.

images.altText: A picnic table in an open grassy area with more picnic tables in the background.
images.title: Pinnacles Picnic Grounds
images.caption: Take a break at Pinnacles Picnic Grounds.

bodyText: The picnic grounds are open; the shelter is not. Pinnacles Picnic Grounds is open year round. There are picnic tables, fire grates for cooking, and water. There is also an open pavilion with picnic tables and fireplaces available on a first-come, first-served basis.
audioDescription: The entrance to Pinnacles Picnic Ground is on the west side on Skyline Drive. There is a road that travels a long, narrow loop around the picnic grounds. There are picnic tables with fire grates scattered around the interior of the loop and along the perimeter outside the loop. Towards the bottom of the loop the picnic pavilion is in the center of the loop, while the restrooms are on the perimeter.

title: Range View Overlook
listingDescription: Come to Range View Overlook for an expansive view of the mountains of Shenandoah. Looking south from an elevation of 2,810 ft (856 m), you are glimpsing into the center of Shenandoah National Park, from Keyser Mountain in front of you all the way to Old Rag and Stony Man Mountain in the distance.

images.altText: View from overlook out to valley with many mountains in the distance.
images.title: Range View Overlook
images.caption: What's the view from Range View Overlook?

bodyText: Come to Range View Overlook for an expansive view of the mountains of Shenandoah. Looking south from an elevation of 2,810 ft (856 m), you are glimpsing into the center of Shenandoah National Park, from Keyser Mountain in front of you all the way to Old Rag and Stony Man Mountain in the distance.
audioDescription: This overlook faces south over a valley and out to many mountains in the distance. From the left is Jenkins Mountain, Pickerel Ridge, Keyser Moutain closer to the foreground, Old Rag out in the distance, Stony Man Mountain out in the distance, Pass Mountain, Mount Marshall Overlook on Skyline Drive, and then Hogback Mountain. There are two interpretive signs at Range View Overlook. They are both 36 by 24 inch color graphic panels on a dark metal frame angled towards the viewer. The left wayside's title reads, "Come Back When You Have More Time." There is a quote under the title that reads, "Park roads are for leisurely driving only. If you are in a hurry you might do well to take another route now, and come back when you have more time. From an early National Park Service brochure." The body text reads, "This is no place to rush. Skyline Drive was planned and built to be a scenic highway- not just a way to get you from one place to another." Originally billed as Shenandoah's "greatest single feature," the Drive's 35 mph speed limit is just right for safety and taking in the beauty of the Blue Ridge. Skyline Drive is both a marvel and a conundrum. It's easy to see why it's marvelous, for this is one of the prettiest scenic drives in the world. And sometimes there is oddness in beauty: because of the way the Drive twists and turns-part of its design-there are places where, even though you're in the northbound lane and driving to Front Royal, you're actually headed due south. "To the right of the text is a gray box with two black and white photographs in it. The left photograph shows a man with surveying equipment standing in an area where the ground has been cleared with some trees surrounding him. This images is accompanied by the text, "(Left) Highway engineers and surveyors used tools like the transit to help them decide on Skyline Drive's route through the Blue Ridge." The other photograph shows a picture of the mountains with a white line drawn over the image following the contour of the mountains with the accompanying text, "(Above) Planning the Skyline Drive was not as simple as building a roadway across the backbone of the mountain. Landscape architects studied the proposed Drive from high-elevation points, so they could get an idea of how the Drive would look from scenic lookouts and summits." Behind the text there is a photograph from a high elevation looking down to mountains in the distance. The text accompanying this photograph reads, "Range View Overlook provides a singular view of the Park: from here you can see numerous peaks stretched along the mountain range. Skyline Drive winds around them on its way south from Front Royal to Rockfish Gap." The right wayside's title reads, "A Skyline Drive for a Bird's-Eye View." There is a quote under the title that reads, "It is a wonderway over which the tourist will ride comfortably in his car while he is stirred by a view as exhilarating as the aviator may see from the plane. Senator Harry F. Byrd, Virginia." The body text reads, "When construction began on Skyline Drive in 1931, NPS landscape architects were challenged to design a new kind of road. Skyline Drive would, "lay lightly on the land," that is, roll across the mountain without major changes to the landscape. The scenic highway should also provide opportunities for recreation and the simple pleasure of enjoying the view. To accomplish this, civil engineers devised clever ways to build a scenic-yet-stable road in steep and rocky terrain. This careful attention to the driving experience means that you hardly notice the road as you travel along, taking in the grand vistas before gliding into green tunnels of trees. It all melds together into a smooth memory: road, car, and scenery." To the right of the text is a gray box with two black and white photographs in it. One photograph shows the retaining wall of Skyline Drive under construction with exposed logs on the exterior side of the wall separating the drive from the trees down a mountain slope. The second photograph shows a picture of a newly constructed Skyline Drive weaving through the mountains. The text under these images reads, "Engineers used toe walls and gabion (retaining) walls to shape the backbone of the Drive. These engineering accomplishments are largely hidden now by the landscape, which has reclaimed the scars left by road-building machinery." Behind the text there is a photograph from a high elevation looking down to mountains in the distance. The text accompanying this photograph reads, "As you travel along Shenandoah's Scenic Byway, notice how often you can see Skyline Drive peeking in and out from the trees, beckoning you to the next overlook. There are nearly 70 overlooks in all, each offering a different view of what's beyond." A black bar on the top of each of the graphics reads "Shenandoah National Park" on the left and on the right is the National Park Service Arrowhead symbol.

title: Rapidan Camp
listingDescription: Rapidan Camp was the beautiful, rustic getaway of President Herbert Hoover and First Lady Lou Henry Hoover during their time in the White House. Exhibits and tours to the area reveal what it was like to lead a nation during the Great Depression, and how this land provided respite and rejuvenation. **This area is only accessible via a shuttle bus tour, or by foot or horseback. The road is closed to all private vehicles.

images.altText: A wooden bridge leads across a mountain stream to a brown cabin in the woods.
images.title: Rapidan Camp in Fall

bodyText:
Take a Virtual Tour

Nestled deep in a hollow at the headwaters of the Rapidan River is a little piece of history: Rapidan Camp. This National Historic Landmark was the beautiful, rustic getaway of President Herbert Hoover and First Lady Lou Henry Hoover during their time in the White House. This restful spot provided the couple respite and rejuvenation throughout a tumultuous presidency and was the backdrop for historic meetings during one of our nation's most difficult times: the Great Depression. A visit to the exhibits at Rapidan Camp will reveal a different perspective of the First Couple and provide you with the same respite and rejuvenation prompted by the beauty and serenity of this special place.

A National Historical Landmark

Rapidan Camp earned the distinction of being named a National Historic Landmark in 1988 as "Camp Hoover," the common name of the camp during the years it operated as a government retreat. The camp was deemed nationally significant because of its association with the Hoovers and their presidential administration. In addition to providing the president and his family respite during tumultuous times, the camp is also significant because of the important meetings, conversations, and decisions made here. Hoover said, "I have discovered that even the work of government can be improved by leisurely discussions of its problems out under the trees where no bells or callers jar one's thoughts."

Getting Here

Rapidan Road, which lies across from Byrd Visitor Center (mile 51.2) and leads several miles down to Rapidan Camp, is closed to all private vehicles. There are still several options for visiting the camp, however:

  • Ranger-led Tour
    Starting with a shuttle ride from Byrd Visitor Center, Ranger-guided tours of Rapidan Camp include time inside both the Brown House and the Prime Minister's Cabin, as well as time exploring the grounds and gardens within this historic landmark. Tours are available by reservation only and are typically offered during the spring, summer, and fall. Visitors may book a reservation up to 6 months in advance and up to 4 hours before the tour.
  • Hiking
    We recommend the 4-mile Rapidan Camp hike from the Milam Gap parking area, although you may also choose to do the longer Mill Prong - Laurel Prong Loop hike, or the Mill Prong Horse Trail that is down Rapidan Road and to the right.
  • Horseback Riding
    Rapidan Camp is also accessible with a horse, by riding down Rapidan Road from the Rapidan parking area (mile 51.3) and returning the same way. Please take the time to review our horseback riding rules and best practices before taking this trip.

Getting Around

Within Rapidan Camp, each building, existing and obliterated, is marked with a sign, and most of them are on the main path. You can peruse the exterior interpretive panels year-round. When caretakers are here, (typically during the spring, summer, and fall) you can visit the exhibits in the Brown House and Prime Minister's Cabin.

The Brown House is historically refurnished to reflect the Hoover era. The Prime Minister's Cabin houses an interpretive exhibit about the Hoover's and their life at Rapidan. If you're up for a walk, follow the trail up to the site of Five Tents and/or take the President's Walk, a beautiful stroll along the creek to the sluice built to divert the natural Laurel Prong to feed the Marine-built Hemlock Run.
audioDescription: There are two color graphic, interpretive panels at this location. An introductory panel begins with a quote from Herbert Hoover: "Here is peace and quietude." A black and white historic photo of President and Mrs. Hoover is flanked by text: Shortly after his election in 1928, Herbert C. Hoover and his wife, Lou Henry expressed the desire for a weekend retreat--a place where they could find respite from the demands of Washington life and be rejuvenated by "the blessings of nature." Here among the trees and trout streams they established their rustic summer camp. An historic photo of the main building at the camp almost hidden among trees is explained with text: In the years since the Hoovers left Washington, Rapidan has undergone many changes, the most drastic in the early 1960s when 10 of the 13 original buildings were removed. In 1928, a dense canopy of trees covered the area. A modern photo of the same building taken in fall shows the drastic change with a lack of trees and foliage. Text: The shade provided the much cooler temperatures the Hoovers sought in the days before air-conditioning. The canopy was dominated by old-growth Eastern Hemlocks that were killed by an invasive, exotic insect, the hemlock woolly adelgid. Shenandoah National Park is working to save the remaining few hemlocks and restore the character and beauty of the Hoover-era Rapidan Camp. A color photo of the interior of the president's cabin shows the historic refurnishing--a beige and white stripped love seat in front of windows with a rustic wooden table holding a tray of cookies and tea. A second photo shows a woman studying an exhibit panel. Text: Today, visitors can see an exhibit in the Prime Minister's cabin and tour the president's cabin as part of a Ranger Program. The Brown House has been restored and refurnished to capture the atmosphere created by Mrs. Hoover for their many guests. The Creel cabin serves as housing for volunteer overseers. A wide black band at the bottom of the panel contain 3 historic photos: the first shows four large white tents on platforms with small front porches, the second is a historic photo of a long wooden building with a large porch, and the third shows a close up of one of the tents. Text: The Hoovers' first night in camp was May 18, 1929. The presidential accommodations were five army tents on wooden floors. Despite later becoming a wood-sided building, the name "Five Tents" stuck. Mrs. Hoover's original plan called for "good board flooring and a roof, a boarded strip extending up from the floor perhaps three or four feet, with sides comprised of canvas curtains that let up and down." However, the Hoovers quickly became fond of the camp and decided to make the "tent village" more permanent, replacing the canvas with board siding. By early August the Hoover were already using the camp for official meetings. Their precious retreat soon became an outdoor extension of the nation's capital. The second panel shows a hand-drawn map of the camp, color-coded to show the existing buildings in brown and the obliterated buildings in blue. Streams, paths, trails, and other structures are also shown. A wide black band shows the outline of each building with a short description: Five Tents in blue-the first structure built; fireplace still visible today. Ishbel in blue-guest cabin, named for the Prime Minister's daughter who visited. Town Hall and Quarters are also in blue. The Brown House in brown-Hoovers' residence, now historically refurnished. The Creel in brown-cabin used by Hoover's physician. Other locations in blue are Trails End-guest cabin, the Slums, Duty Office-used by Secret Service and Marines, the Mess Hall, the Owl-guest cabin. Other sites in brown are the fountain, the outdoor fireplace, and the Prime Minister's Cabin-guest cabin named for the British Prime Minister who visited; now houses exhibit Between the two signs is a metal plaque mounted on a large rock near the ground. The raised inscription reads: Camp Hoover has been designated a National Historic Landmark. This site possesses national significance in commemoration the history of the United States of America. 1988 National Park Service United States Department of the Interior.
