title: Rapidan Camp - Five Tents
listingDescription: From here, you can take the trail to the site of the Hoovers' first night's stay at their new camp. Originally, "Five Tents" was just that: five army tents on wooden platforms. From this vantage point, the Hoovers planned their retreat. Despite eventually becoming a wood-sided much more permanent structure, the building retained its original name. "Five Tents" was one of the ten structures removed during the 1960s renovations. The fireplace remains mark the location of the fo

images.altText: Several large white tents in a row.
images.title: Rapidan Camp
images.caption: "Five Tents" when it was tents!

bodyText: From here, you can take the trail to the site of the Hoovers' first night's stay at their new camp. Originally, "Five Tents" was just that: five army tents on wooden platforms. From this vantage point, the Hoovers planned their retreat. Despite eventually becoming a wood-sided much more permanent structure, the building retained its original name. "Five Tents" was one of the ten structures removed during the 1960s renovations. The fireplace remains mark the location of the former building about 200 yards up the trail - a bit of a climb, but a beautiful reminder of lively times at Rapidan Camp.
audioDescription: A metal plaque on a brown post marks the trail to the remains of "Five Tents." There is a picture of the now obliterated building, a long wood-sided structure with a large chimney just right of the gabled center. A porch with rustic X-shaped rails runs the length of the building and there is a wide set of steps to the front door. Accompanying text: "FIVE TENTS" The first permanent structure was actually built around five wooden floored tents. The roof, partitions, fireplace, porch, windows, and doors were then constructed until nothing remained of the original tents except the name. Herbert Hoover, Jr. began his long convalescence here from a serious illness. Five Tents was located several hundred yards upstream from this point. (See map of camp area)

title: Rapidan Camp - Five Tents Chimney
listingDescription: All that is left of "Five Tents" is this huge fireplace and chimney built by the Marines. Still, it's not difficult to imagine the rustic building that surrounded it and housed the many guests who came to Rapidan Camp. Many a cool evening was spent by this fireplace most likely accompanied by lively discussions.

images.altText: A long wood-sided structure with a large chimney just right of the gabled center.
images.title: Rapidan Camp
images.caption: "Five Tents" after its transformation. Note the chimney.

bodyText: All that is left of "Five Tents" is this huge fireplace and chimney built by the Marines. audioDescription: The remains of a huge rustic stone fireplace and chimney.

title: Rapidan Camp - Fountain
listingDescription: In keeping with the theme of the relaxing sound of water, this fountain was built. Water came up through the fountain, emptied into pools below, then ran underground before emerging again and then back underground on its way to Hemlock Run.

images.altText: A 4 feet tall structure constructed from stone in 4 round layers,each layer smaller in diameter.
images.title: Rapidan Camp - Fountain
images.caption: The "wedding cake" fountain

bodyText: In keeping with the theme of the relaxing sound of water, this fountain was built. Water came up through the fountain, emptied into pools below, then ran underground before emerging again and then back underground on its way to Hemlock Run.
audioDescription: Sometimes described as "the wedding cake fountain" this structure is about 4 feet tall and is constructed from stone in 4 round layers, each layer smaller in diameter. Lichen gives it lots of color and texture.

title: Rapidan Camp - Hemlock Run
listingDescription: Water played an important role in the camp. Early on, when the Hoovers were reviewing sites, Mrs. Hoover said, "My husband's idea was to have a camp down on one of the tree-covered flats beside a stream or at the junction between two streams. He likes to be near enough to hear the water murmuring." As plans developed, the Hoovers endeavored to extend that courtesy to all their guests instructing the Marines to build Hemlock Run. The Laurel Prong was diverted by an upstream sl

images.altText: President and Mrs. Hoover stand on a large boulder to the left of a small waterfall.
images.title: Rapidan Camp - Hemlock Run
images.caption: The Hoovers at Hemlock Falls

bodyText: Water played an important role in the camp. Early on, when the Hoovers were reviewing sites, Mrs. Hoover said, "My husband's idea was to have a camp down on one of the tree-covered flats beside a stream or at the junction between two streams. He likes to be near enough to hear the water murmuring." As plans developed, the Hoovers endeavored to extend that courtesy to all their guests instructing the Marines to build Hemlock Run. The Laurel Prong was diverted by an upstream sluice gate creating the two-thousand-foot-long water channel that meanders through the forest and past several of the camp's buildings. Where the channel passes between the President's Cabin and the Prime Minister's Cabin, existing rock outcrops and boulders were incorporated into the channel to for a small waterfall called Hemlock Falls. Next to the falls is a small, concrete-lined pool for holding freshly caught trout.
audioDescription: A metal photo sign is titled "Mountain Streams in the Camp." It shows an historic photo taken downstream back toward this location of the stream and waterfall. In the background the Prime Minister's cabin is visible through the landscape. The sign's text reads: "Hemlock Run, the small artificial stream that flowed through the cabin area was created by a small diversion dam. This dam was built upstream from the cabin area across Laurel Prong. Laurel Prong and Mill Prong join just below the President's Cabin to form the Rapidan River which is a tributary of the Rappahannock River which flows southeast into the Chesapeake Bay."

title: Rapidan Camp - Hemlock Run Sluice
listingDescription: President Hoover was an engineer before he entered public service. Mrs. Hoover accompanied him all over the world and spent many happy years in mining camps. Both loved the simplicity of camp life and wanted to recreate it at Rapidan. They achieved the relaxing sound of the mountain streams even where none originally existed by asking the Marines to construct Hemlock Run. This sluice diverted water from the Laurel Prong sending it through the camp.

images.altText: A concrete block on the edge of the stream with a notch cut through.
images.title: Hemlock Run
images.caption: The sluice for Hemlock Run

bodyText: President Hoover was an engineer before he entered public service. Mrs. Hoover accompanied him all over the world and spent many happy years in mining camps. Both loved the simplicity of camp life and wanted to recreate it at Rapidan. They achieved the relaxing sound of the mountain streams even where none originally existed by asking the Marines to construct Hemlock Run. This sluice diverted water from the Laurel Prong sending it through the camp.
audioDescription: A concrete block on the edge of the stream with a notch cut through faces another just like it, slightly more worn. These blocks held the barrier that created the diversion.

title: Rapidan Camp - Mess Hall
listingDescription: The Hoovers and their guests usually ate their morning and evening meals together in the "Mess Hall" unless the weather was particularly fine, then the evening meal might be served outside or on one of the porches. Meals were informal and served on one or two long wooden tables. One guest described the decor: "The table decorations are a far cry from the massive silver service used for state functions at the White House. There are gay colored dishes. Spritely fall asters or

images.altText: A black and white photo of wooden walls and vaulted ceiling above a set table with checkered floor.
images.title: Rapidan Camp - Mess Hall
images.caption: The interior of the building that once stood here.

bodyText:
The Hoovers and their guests usually ate their morning and evening meals together in the "Mess Hall" unless the weather was particularly fine, then the evening meal might be served outside or on one of the porches. Meals were informal and served on one or two long wooden tables. One guest described the decor: "The table decorations are a far cry from the massive silver service used for state functions at the White House. There are gay colored dishes. Spritely fall asters or some other flower from the surrounding woods are used for decorations with harmonizing candles. The napkins are sometimes of checked gingham."

Meals, too, were rustic. Dinners usually consisting of roasted or grilled meat and fish and in-season vegetables - the British Prime Minister's daughter had her first taste of corn on the cob at Rapidan. Breakfasts were large - bacon, eggs, hotcakes and coffee. They were prepared by Marine chefs and served by the former staff of the presidential yacht which President Hoover decommissioned. Most the staff were Filipino.
audioDescription: A metal photo sign on a brown iron post indicates the location of the former Mess Hall which was obliterated in the early 1960s. The space is grown over with grass. There are two photos on the metal sign, and exterior and an interior. The top photo, the exterior, is dominated by the large stone fireplace of the Mess Hall. The building is board siding and there is a porch on the right side. It is nestled among the trees. The bottom photo shows a rustic dining area with a wooden table and chairs one a straw checkerboard mat. The far end is a wall of windows and on the left there is an impressive stone fireplace with a roaring fire. The fireplace is in an alcove which is mostly stonework with a stone mantle and stone bench.

title: Rapidan Camp - Mill Prong Bridge
listingDescription: This rustic bridge across the Mill Prong was the site of many photo opportunities. The picturesque mountain stream travels just a few feet further before meeting up with the Laurel Prong to form the headwaters of the Rapidan River. The Rapidan has long been known as a premier trout stream and was, perhaps, the biggest consideration of the Hoovers when choosing the area for their camp. President Hoover once claimed that he believed that "God does not subtract from your life th

images.altText: Black and white historic photo of the Hoovers standing on the bridge.
images.title: Rapidan Camp - Mill Prong Bridge
images.caption: President Herbert Hoover and First Lady Lou Henry Hoover

bodyText:
This rustic bridge across the Mill Prong was the site of many photo opportunities. The picturesque mountain stream travels just a few feet further before meeting up with the Laurel Prong to form the headwaters of the Rapidan River. The Rapidan has long been known as a premier trout stream and was, perhaps, the biggest consideration of the Hoovers when choosing the area for their camp. President Hoover once claimed that he believed that "God does not subtract from your life the time you spend fishing." Note: Hoover lived to be 90 years old!

This bridge was washed away in a flood in the late 90s and was replaced.
audioDescription: A narrow wooden footbridge across a tumbling mountain stream. The railings are rough hewn logs in a criss-cross pattern like the deck railings on the cabins.

Today, just over 2,500 historic places bear this national distinction." So, it is worth noting that Rapidan Camp earned this distinction in 1988 as "Camp Hoover," the name the camp came to be known as during the years it operated as a gover

bodyText:
"National Historic Landmarks (NHLs) are nationally significant historic places designated by the Secretary of the Interior because they possess exceptional value or quality in illustrating or interpreting the heritage of the United States. Today, just over 2,500 historic places bear this national distinction." So, it is worth noting that Rapidan Camp earned this distinction in 1988 as "Camp Hoover," the name the camp came to be known as during the years it operated as a government retreat. The Park restored its historic name when the camp was restored in the early 2000s.

The Camp was deemed nationally significant because of its association with the Hoovers and their presidential administration. In addition to providing them respite during a tumultuous time, the Camp is also significant because of the important meetings and conversations held and decisions made here. Hoover said, "I have discovered that even the work of government can be improved by leisurely discussions of its problems out under the trees where no bells or callers jar one's thoughts."
audioDescription: A metal plaque mounted on a large rock. The inscription is raised: Camp Hoover has been designated a National Historic Landmark. This site possesses national significance in commemoration the history of the United States of America. 1988 National Park Service United States Department of the Interior.

title: Rapidan Camp - Outdoor Fireplace
listingDescription: Although this seems a cozy spot, especially when outfitted with hewn logs for sitting and a crackling blaze, the Hoovers and their guests rarely used this outdoor fireplace. It was primarily used for photo opportunities on the rare occasions the Press was allowed in camp. Like the other fireplaces in the camp's buildings, this massive stone chimney was built by the Marines who were stationed here. Initially, President Hoover refused to have the soldiers stationed here, but wa

images.altText: A black and white photograph of an outdoor fireplace in the woods.
images.title: Rapidan Camp - Outdoor Fireplace
images.caption: The outdoor fireplace served as a photo opp for the Hoovers and their guests.

bodyText: Although this seems a cozy spot, especially when outfitted with hewn logs for sitting and a crackling blaze, the Hoovers and their guests rarely used this outdoor fireplace. It was primarily used for photo opportunities on the rare occasions the Press was allowed in camp. Like the other fireplaces in the camp's buildings, this massive stone chimney was built by the Marines who were stationed here. Initially, President Hoover refused to have the soldiers stationed here, but was convinced by the War Department that they could provide security and "carry out considerable military training." The Hoovers were adamant that they personally pay for the expenses of their retreat.
audioDescription: A large fireplace and chimney made of large stones and mortar sets among the trees on a fairly flat stone platform.

title: Rapidan Camp - President's Walk
listingDescription: Though both Hoovers valued the restorative powers of nature, they were not averse to improving upon it. After choosing the Rapidan site, they carefully manipulated and enhanced its natural elements - terrain, boulders, water, and plantings. Their greatest natural artifice, Hemlock Run was created by diverting part of Laurel Prong so that its waters flowed through the heart of the camp in cascading layers, forming waterfalls and feeding the stocked trout pond. Their goal was t

images.altText: A moss covered bridge made of large stones.
images.title: Rapidan Camp - President's Walk
images.caption: The beginning of a beautiful walk!

bodyText: Though both Hoovers valued the restorative powers of nature, they were not averse to improving upon it. After choosing the Rapidan site, they carefully manipulated and enhanced its natural elements - terrain, boulders, water, and plantings. Their greatest natural artifice, Hemlock Run was created by diverting part of Laurel Prong so that its waters flowed through the heart of the camp in cascading layers, forming waterfalls and feeding the stocked trout pond. Their goal was to be sure every guest could hear the sounds of water from their cabins. From here you can take a lovely stroll out to what remains of the sluice the Marines constructed to fill Hemlock Run. To the sluice and back is a level walk of about 1/2 mile.
audioDescription: A moss covered bridge made of large stones and two steps up crosses the stone-lined, Marine-built stream. The bridge leads to a trail through the woods.

audioDescription: A metal photo sign on a brown metal pole. Text: The Prime Minister's Cabin. Prime Minister Ramsey McDonald of England was a frequent guest of President Hoover. The "Press" of that day popularly envisioned these two peace loving leaders sitting on a log in the Camp Hoover area scrapping the navies of the world. After the subsequent naval disarmament conference, the major powers did scrap many obsolete naval vessels. Germany and Japan soon began to rearm their navies with ultra-modern, compact fighting ships like the Graf Spee. Beneath the text is a photo of the Prime Minister's Cabin before the porch was built.

title: Rapidan Camp - Prime Minister's Porch Exhibit
listingDescription: The porch of the Prime Minister's cabin is a great place to continue your exploration of Rapidan Camp. If the camp overseers are in residence, the cabin will be open and you can enter to experience an exhibit about the Hoovers, their lives, their presidency, and their time here at Rapidan Camp. Regardless of the season, you can learn more about the camp from the panel on the porch which has an historic water color map that shows the locations of most features at the camp and

images.altText: A woman and a young girl reading an outdoor exhibit with woods in the background.
images.title: Rapidan Camp - Prime Minister Exhibit
images.caption: Learn about the Prime Minister's Cabin at Rapidan Camp.

bodyText: The porch of the Prime Minister's cabin is a great place to continue your exploration of Rapidan Camp. If the camp overseers are in residence, the cabin will be open and you can enter to experience an exhibit about the Hoovers, their lives, their presidency, and their time here at Rapidan Camp. Regardless of the season, you can learn more about the camp from the panel on the porch which has an historic water color map that shows the locations of most features at the camp and a flip book of most of the former structures and descriptions.
audioDescription: A large metal panel, about 5 feet long is mounted to the porch rail at an angle. Two-thirds of the panel is taken up by a subtly colored historic illustrated map of the camp. Main features are numbered and there is a corresponding key in a text box. Introductory text is to the left of the map. At the top in larger font: "I have discovered that even the work of the government can be improved by leisurely discussions of its problems out under the trees where no bells or callers jar one's thoughts..." President Hoover, "Madison County Day" speech, August 1929. Below: From 1929 to 1932, Rapidan Camp, nestled here in the Blue Ridge mountains at the headwaters of the Rapidan River, served as a weekend retreat for President Herbert and First Lady Lou Henry Hoover. Just to your right, the Laurel Prong stream winds its way to the river, meeting the Mill Prong stream to form the headwaters of one of the most renowned trout streams in Virginia. It was here that the President and First Lady found respite from the heat and formality of Washington, DC. Just ahead and to the left is the Brown House, the Hoovers' rustic weekend counterpart to their city home, the White House. Map key in text box: A. Mill Prong converges with Laurel Prong to form Rapidan. B. Laurel Prong converges with Mill Prong to form Rapidan C. Hemlock Run, created by diverting part of Laurel Prong D. Trout pool, created by the Hoovers. The 13 original structures 1. The Brown House, the Hoover's residence 2. The Prime Minister, guest cabin 3. Ishbel, guest cabin 4. Trail's End, guest cabin 5. Five Tents, the first structure built 6. The Creel, guest cabin 7. The Owl, guest cabin 8. The Slums, usually occupied by Mrs. Hoover's secretaries 9. Mess Hall, where most meals were served 10. Town Hall, the social hall 11. Duty Office, used by Secret Service and Marines 12. Mess servants quarters 13. Quarters occupied by chief commissary officer Caption for map: Illustrated map of Rapidan Camp by Edward Stone, circa 1930. The Marine Camp and "Cabinet Camp" (for members of Hoover's cabinet) were off-site. The right one-third of the panel features an etched metal plaque of the same brown. Text: "We discussed the proposed camp as we explored...Conditions necessitate a rather biggish establishment." Lou Henry Hoover, describing the future Rapidan Camp, 1929 Below is a flip book with historic photos in brown duotones and descriptions. Photos are of the structures and main features. Text:

title: Rapidan Camp - Recreational Pursuits
listingDescription: This area was adjacent to the building the Hoovers called "Town Hall" where guest met to converse, play cards, read, etc. This area was the site of many famous horseshoe pitching tournaments.

images.altText: Three ladies, two seated and one standing. The lady standing is knitting.
images.title: Rapidan Camp - Recreational Pursuits
images.caption: Mrs. Hoover and two guests enjoy the outdoors.

bodyText: This area was adjacent to the building the Hoovers called "Town Hall" where guest met to converse, play cards, read, etc. This area was the site of many famous horseshoe pitching tournaments.
audioDescription: A metal photo sign on a brown metal pole. The top photo shows a horseshoe pitching pit. Two horseshoes are leaning against the peg. There is a hardwood tree in the center and a rock wall border runs along the right side. Text: Recreational Pursuits. Trout fishing was the chief pastime at the camp. Other diversions were horseback riding, horseshoe pitching, hiking and working puzzles. Above is the recreation area adjacent to Town Hall. Below Richey and Boone work on a jig-saw puzzle. The bottom photo shows two men seated in wicker chairs at a small table working a jigsaw puzzle.

title: Rapidan Camp - The Brown House
listingDescription: The Brown House was President and Mrs. Hoover's restful and beautiful answer to their hectic city dwelling, the White House. Tucked between the Mill Prong and the Laurel Prong exactly where they meet to form the headwaters of the Rapidan River, The Brown House features a broad porch from which the President could cast into one of the best waterways on the east coast for trout! Although President Hoover was never known to take the easy way out and spent his time in waders amon

images.altText: A black and white photograph of a rustic log cabin surrounded by forest.
images.title: Rapidan Camp - The Brown House
images.caption: The President's Cabin in 1931.

bodyText: The Brown House was President and Mrs. Hoover's restful and beautiful answer to their hectic city dwelling, the White House. Tucked between the Mill Prong and the Laurel Prong exactly where they meet to form the headwaters of the Rapidan River, The Brown House features a broad porch from which the President could cast into one of the best waterways on the east coast for trout! Although President Hoover was never known to take the easy way out and spent his time in waders among the trout rather than casting from the porch, it was a wonderful place to entertain their many guests and enjoy the outdoors. When the weather or nightfall drove them inside, the Brown House interior was just as welcoming. Furnished in rustic pieces built by the Marines, picked up locally by Mrs. Hoover, or re-purposed from the presidential yacht, the Brown House is a cozy spot.
audioDescription: A rustic wood-paneled cabin painted brown with a wide porch and slanted roof on the left side of the gravel walking path. There is a staircase leading to a porch in the front of the house. Continuing along the path, there is another stairway leading up to the back porch. When there is a caretaker and visitors are permitted inside the building, you will enter at a door in the middle of the back porch. Continuing around the back porch, there are stairs that descend to a trail that leads to a bridge over the stream.

title: Rapidan Camp - The Brown House Back Entrance
listingDescription: The back porch of the President's Cabin, also known as the Brown House provides an accessible entrance. During the summer and fall seasons, visitors can join a van tour with a Ranger to explore the camp. The van is equipped for wheelchairs and this entrance is provided for those who cannot negotiate the steps. The interior of the Brown House has been historically refurnished to the Hoover era. Note the curved notch in the roof overhang. It was the Hoovers' goal to disturb the

images.altText: A dimly lit room with a stone fireplace with rustic furniture and Native American wall hangings.
images.title: Rapidan Camp - The Brown House
images.caption: One of two sitting rooms in The Brown House

bodyText: The back porch of the President's Cabin, also known as the Brown House provides an accessible entrance. During the summer and fall seasons, visitors can join a van tour with a Ranger to explore the camp. The van is equipped for wheelchairs and this entrance is provided for those who cannot negotiate the steps. The interior of the Brown House has been historically refurnished to the Hoover era. Note the curved notch in the roof overhang. It was the Hoovers' goal to disturb the natural features of the camp as little as possible, so rather than cut down trees, they allowed them to grow up through the decking and trimmed the roof overhang as necessary. The tree that grew here recently died and had to be removed.
audioDescription: A ramp onto a brown wooden deck of the wood-sided cabin. The cabin is L-shaped with windows along the upper park. The roof is green shingle and there is a notch in its overhang where a tree grew until recently. The entry is straight in front of the ramp. On the right side is a routed wooden sign: The Brown House. The deck is rimmed with rough wooden logs in with posts, and handrail and X configurations between posts.

title: Rapidan Camp - The Creel Cabin
listingDescription: During the Hoover era at Rapidan Camp, Creel Cabin housed the White House physician, Joel T. Boone. Dr. Boone was at Rapidan every time the president was there. He said of Rapidan, "It was one of the most relaxing places that I have ever known." Today, the Creel houses volunteer caretakers during the season. The President's secretary stayed here when he was in the Camp.

images.altText: Two men sit at a table outdoors working a jigsaw puzzle.
images.title: Rapidan Camp - The Creel Cabin
images.caption: President Hoover's personal physician, Joel T. Boone, Jr. (right) and his secretary, Larry Richey.

bodyText: During the Hoover era at Rapidan Camp, Creel Cabin housed the White House physician, Joel T. Boone. Dr. Boone was at Rapidan every time the president was there. He said of Rapidan, "It was one of the most relaxing places that I have ever known." Today, the Creel houses volunteer caretakers during the season. The President's secretary stayed here when he was in the Camp.
audioDescription: A metal photo sign on a brown metal pole. Text: The Creel. The Creel was occupied by two of President Hoover's Chief Aids. Larry Richey, a former F.B.I. agent, was assigned to guard the President and became his personal "secretary" or manager. He assumed great responsibility for the detailed arrangements necessary for the safety and comfort of the Chief Executive as he moved about the country. The President's personal physician Joel T. Boone, Jr. (Vice Admiral, Retired) shared these quarters with Mr. Richey.

title: Rapidan Camp - Then and Now: Finding your way around the Camp
listingDescription: From this spot, you can plan your exploration of Rapidan Camp. Each building (existing and obliterated) is marked with a sign and most of them are on the main path. Be sure to explore the Prime Minister's cabin. When the caretakers are here you can view the exhibit inside, and year-round you can peruse the interpretive panels on the porch. The Brown House, which is historically refurnished to the Hoover era is also a must-do during the summer and fall when the camp is staffed

images.altText: A map showing the layout of Rapidan Camp's historic and current layout.
images.title: Rapidan Camp Then and now
images.caption: Explore Rapidan Camp!

bodyText: From this spot, you can plan your exploration of Rapidan Camp. Each building (existing and obliterated) is marked with a sign and most of them are on the main path. Be sure to explore the Prime Minister's cabin. When the caretakers are here you can view the exhibit inside, and year-round you can peruse the interpretive panels on the porch. The Brown House, which is historically refurnished to the Hoover era is also a must-do during the summer and fall when the camp is staffed. If you're up for a walk, follow the trail up to the site of Five Tents and/or take the President's Walk, a beautiful stroll along the creek to the sluice built to divert the natural Laurel Prong to feed the Marine-built Hemlock Run.
audioDescription: A panel showing a hand-drawn map of the camp, color-coded to show the existing buildings (brown) and the obliterated buildings (blue). Streams, paths, trails, and other structures are also shown. A wide black band shows the outline of each building with a short description: Five Tents (blue)-the first structure built; fireplace still visible today. Ishbel (blue)-guest cabin, named for the Prime Minister's daughter who visited. Town Hall (blue). Quarters (blue). The Brown House (brown)-Hoovers' residence, now historically refurnished. The Creel (brown)-cabin used by Hoover's physician...Trails End (blue)-guest cabin. The Slums (blue). Duty Office (blue)-used by Secret Service and Marines. The Mess Hall (blue). The Owl (blue)-guest cabin. The fountain (brown). Outdoor fireplace (brown). The Prime Minister (brown)-guest cabin named for the British Prime Minister who visited; now houses exhibit.

title: Rapidan Camp - Town Hall
listingDescription: Town Hall was the social center of the camp. Used for recreation as well as meetings, the large L-shaped building was outfitted with a variety of chairs, couches, gliders, rockers, bookcases, tables, desks, and a ping-pong table. Guests retired to Town Hall after dinner to smoke and sit by the fires knitting, working jigsaw puzzles, and conversing. By many accounts, conversations were lively, interesting, and enjoyed by all who participated. The large grassy area nearby was a

images.altText: Black and white photo of rustic fireplace with a wooden rocking chair and plants in front.
images.title: Rapidan Camp - Town Hall
images.caption: Town Hall sitting room

bodyText: Town Hall was the social center of the camp. Used for recreation as well as meetings, the large L-shaped building was outfitted with a variety of chairs, couches, gliders, rockers, bookcases, tables, desks, and a ping-pong table. Guests retired to Town Hall after dinner to smoke and sit by the fires knitting, working jigsaw puzzles, and conversing. By many accounts, conversations were lively, interesting, and enjoyed by all who participated. The large grassy area nearby was a favorite spot for picnics.
audioDescription: A metal photo sign with two photos separated by text. The top photo shows a sitting room with a large stone fireplace at the end. The narrow room has windows along both sides and is furnished with wicker chairs, a couch, floor lamps, a table, stools and there are two large urns at the room's entrance. The lower photo shows the second sitting room with a large stone fireplace. A native American rug hangs over the fireplace. There are windows on either side of the chimney. There is a wooden rocking chair, wooden stools, and a bookcase filled with books. The text reads: "Town Hall was the center for Executive Meetings and social activities here at Camp Hoover. The two stone fireplaces were kept burning during chilly evenings. The President and his guests furnished brilliant conversation nightly on a wide variety of topics when the Camp was occupied. Few guests could equal their host's ability to tell of interesting experiences he had on his world travels.

title: Rapidan Camp - Town Hall - Famous Town Visitors
listingDescription: This is one of several metal photo signs on posts marking the site of "Town Hall." Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh was a frequent guest to Rapidan. Hoover would hold themed weekends during which he would assemble groups of people with like-interests. He was particularly keen on developing air mail so on one weekend he invited Lindbergh and the Postmaster General to discuss the possibility. Hoover's mail was dropped from an airplane on Big Meadow each day he was in camp.

images.altText: Historic photo of Charles Lindbergh standing in front of his plane
images.title: Rapidan Camp - Town Hall
images.caption: Charles Lindbergh

bodyText: This is one of several metal photo signs on posts marking the site of "Town Hall." Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh was a frequent guest to Rapidan. Hoover would hold themed weekends during which he would assemble groups of people with like-interests. He was particularly keen on developing air mail so on one weekend he invited Lindbergh and the Postmaster General to discuss the possibility. Hoover's mail was dropped from an airplane on Big Meadow each day he was in camp.
audioDescription: A silver metal photo sign on a brown post. The sign has a photo of the interior of the building that once stood here. There is a wicker chair and a Tiffany lamp on stand on a table in front of a window and beside a door. in the background. The foreground shoes a table and simple wooden chair. The table is built into the wall with two legs supporting it. On it are several small unidentifiable objects and in the corner is a vase with a large piece of greenery in it. On the floor beside the chair is a large urn. On the right side of the photo at the base of the table is a square woven basket that appears to be Native American in style. Beside it is a floor lamp with a decorative shade. Above the photo is text: Famous Town Hall Visitors (title). Many famous individuals were invited to visit the President's retreat on the Rapidan River. Among these was Charles A. Lindbergh, the first aviator to fly non-stop from New York to Paris, France in 1927. Lindbergh donated the large parchment lamp shade (seen in photograph) that contained a map showing his flight routes to many places throughout the world, up to the time he visited the camp.

title: Rapidan Camp - Trout Pond
listingDescription: "Fishing seems to be the sole avenue left to Presidents through which they may escape to their own thoughts and my live in their own imaginings and find relief from the pneumatic hammer of constant personal contacts, and refreshment of mind in the babble of rippling brooks. Moreover, it is a constant reminder of the democracy of life, of humility and of human frailty - for men are equal before fishes. And it is desirable that the President of the United States should be perio

images.altText: The Headline in a newspaper announcing that the President had chosen Rapidan as his camp site.
images.title: Rapidan Camp - Trout Pond
images.caption: The Madison Eagle announces the President's choice of Rapidan to his new neighbors.

bodyText:
"Fishing seems to be the sole avenue left to Presidents through which they may escape to their own thoughts and my live in their own imaginings and find relief from the pneumatic hammer of constant personal contacts, and refreshment of mind in the babble of rippling brooks. Moreover, it is a constant reminder of the democracy of life, of humility and of human frailty - for men are equal before fishes. And it is desirable that the President of the United States should be periodically reminded of this fundamental fact - that the forces of nature discriminate for no man."
- Herbert Hoover

Fishing was the primary motivation for building Rapidan Camp at the headwaters of the Rapidan River. Although the Camp came to be much more than a great place to fish, the President's favorite activity provided much needed respite. Hoover's physician, Admiral Joel T. Boone said, "I never saw him happier than when he was on the Rapidan."

As part of the construction of naturalistic water features throughout the camp, the Marines built this trout pond. Reports of its actual use vary somewhat; some calling the trout in the pond "pets," others reporting it as a place to keep the non-native Rainbow trout, and still others describing it as a holding tank for trout intended for dinner. However, many who wrote of the pond remember daily feedings of beef hearts, a fact borne out by household receipts.
audioDescription: A concrete-lined pool edged by large rocks and greenery.

title: Rapidan Camp Trailhead
listingDescription: Milam Gap Parking Area (mile 52.8) | A hike, featuring three stream crossings, to the rustic getaway of President Herbert Hoover and First Lady Lou Henry Hoover. Today, this restful spot features exhibits on the First Couple and their perspectives.

images.altText: An historic wood cabin with a large porch sits in the middle of a forest.
images.title: Rapidan Cam

bodyText:
A hike, featuring three stream crossings, to the rustic getaway of President Herbert Hoover and First Lady Lou Henry Hoover. Today, this restful spot features exhibits on the First Couple and their perspectives. Pets must be on a physical leash no longer than 6 feet at all times.

Distance: 4-mile round trip hike
Difficulty: Moderate (explanation of our hiking difficulty scale)
Hiking Time: 2 hours 45 minutes
Elevation Gain: 870 feet

Hike Description 

  1. From the Milam Gap Parking Area (mile 52.8), cross Skyline Drive and take the Appalachian Trail a few feet to the trailpost.
  2. Go left onto the blue-blazed Mill Prong Trail.
  3. At the second stream crossing, stay right on the yellow-blazed Mill Prong Horse Trail and follow it downhill to the camp.
  4. Return by the same route.
audioDescription: The Milam Gap Trailhead panel is a 36 by 54 inch color poster. On the upper left of the panel is a black and white photograph of a man in bib overalls standing by a roadside fruit stand selling apples and apple cider. The text reads, "Apple of Their Eye - Apples were a cash crop for the people who lived in what is now Shenandoah National Park. Former residents raised different types of apples - some of which were actually created here - including the Milam, for which this gap is named. The Milam apple was probably developed in an orchard very near where you stand right now." The picture on the bottom left of the panel is a black and white photograph of President Herbert Hoover fly-fishing in one of the mountain streams that ran through his property. The text reads, "Fit for a President. The Park's clear mountain streams host a variety of fish species, including native eastern brook trout. Fly-fisherman and U.S. President Herbert Hoover chose a site two miles east of here, at the headwaters of the Rapidan River, for his weekend retreat because of its proximity to these streams and their trout. Rapidan Camp was built in 1929 and gave the 31st President the perfect place to practice his favorite pastime." The top right of the panel is a 20 by 20 inch topographic map of the hike to Rapidan Camp. The trail is marked in yellow with a brown dashed line. The text reads, "Suggested Hikes: Hike #1: Mill Prong - Rapidan Camp. 4-mile round trip, moderate, 2.75 hours hiking time, 870-foot elevation gain, 3 stream crossings. Go left on the Appalachian Trail south, and cross Skyline Drive. Go left on the blue-blazed Mill Prong Trail. Turn right on Mill Prong Horse Trail. Explore the camp, and then retrace your steps to Milam Gap parking." "Hike #2: Appalachian Trail - Tanners Ridge. The trail is marked in purple with a dashed line. 2.1-mile round trip, easiest, 1.5 hours hiking time, 175-foot elevation gain. Go right on the Appalachian Trail north to Tanners Ridge Road. Return by the same route to the starting point." A red text box below the map gives important information that hikers need. The text reads, "Emergency 1-800-732-0911 (cell phone service is unreliable.) Before You Go! Pets must be on a leash at all times. Do not attempt to cross streams in icy conditions or flooding. Be sure you are physically able to complete the hike you've chosen. Take plenty of water - at least a quart per hour Be sure you know your route. Free maps are available at entrance stations, visitors centers, and www.nps.gov/shen. When you return from your hike, check for ticks. Stay on the trail and avoid trampling sensitive vegetation. Be sure someone knows where you are and when to expect your return. Leave what you find. Artifacts are protected by law. Filter or treat water from streams before drinking. Please respect family cemeteries."

title: Rapidan Road
listingDescription: This road was once part of Skyline Drive - the first part of the Drive ready for traffic! However, it was closed for security reasons when President and Mrs. Hoover were spending their weekends at Rapidan Camp, their "summer white house" and never reopened to the public. Today, Rapidan Road is used to take visitors on a tour of the President's Camp. Check at Byrd Visitor Center for details. If you'd like to hike to the Camp, there are several options. We recommend the beautif

images.altText: Original Rapidan Road snaking through the ridges. Two cars driving the road creating dust.
images.title: Rapidan Road
images.caption: The original Rapidan Road.

bodyText:
This road was once part of Skyline Drive - the first part of the Drive ready for traffic! However, it was closed for security reasons when President and Mrs. Hoover were spending their weekends at Rapidan Camp, their "summer white house" and never reopened to the public.
Today, Rapidan Road is used to take visitors on a tour of the President's Camp. Check at Byrd Visitor Center for details. If you'd like to hike to the Camp, there are several options. We recommend the beautiful Mill Prong Trail a mile and a half south of here. It's a 4-mile round trip hike along a stream to the Camp. You can also start here and take the Mill Prong Horse Trail that is ahead on the right. If you follow the road all the way it's a 12.6-mile round trip and you may encounter dust and vehicles along the road.
audioDescription: A chain gate across a dirt road that skirts the Big Meadow.

title: Rattlesnake Point Overlook
listingDescription: Looking south from an elevation of 3,105 ft (946 m), the view from Rattlesnake Point Overlook extends across a small meadow and out to the distant mountains beyond. Many peaks are visible from here including popular destinations like Marys Rock, Stony Man, and even Old Rag in the far distance if the day is clear enough.

images.altText: View across field out to trees with mountains in the distance.

title: Riprap - Wildcat Ridge Trailhead
listingDescription: MILE 90 or 92.1 | This loop can be hiked from Riprap Parking or Wildcat Ridge Parking Areas. It takes you through pristine forest, over several stream crossings, and offers beautiful views of the hollows and valley to the west and north.

images.altText: A color photograph of a woman sitting on a rock atop a mountain looking to the side.
images.title: Riprap (Chimney Rocks)

bodyText:
You may choose start this hike at either the Riprap parking area or the Wildcat Ridge Parking Area. No matter which route you choose, this hike will take you through pristine forest and over several stream crossings, while offering beautiful views of the hollows and valleys to the west and north. Pets must be on a physical leash no longer than 6 feet at all times.

Distance: 9.8-mile circuit hike
Difficulty: Very Strenuous (explanation of our hiking difficulty scale)
Hiking Time: 8 hours 15 minutes
Elevation Gain: 2,365 feet

Hike Description - From Riprap Parking Area

  1. From the trailhead at the Riprap Parking Area (mile 90), follow the Appalachian Trail north.
  2. Turn left on Riprap Trail, continuing past Cavalry Rocks and Chimney Rocks.
  3. Turn left on Wildcat Ridge Trail.
  4. Take another left on the A.T. north, and return to your starting point. 


Hike Description - From Wildcat Ridge Parking Area

  1. From the trailhead at the Wildcat Ridge Parking Area (mile 92.1), take the Wildcat Ridge Trail past its intersection with the Appalachian Trail.
  2. Turn right onto Riprap Trail.
  3. Take another right on the A.T. south.
  4. Turn left on Wildcat Ridge Trail to return to your starting point.
audioDescription: The Wildcat Ridge Trailhead panel is a 36 by 54 inch color poster. On the upper left of the panel is a historic photograph of a CCC era fire watch tower. The black and white photo shows a more than 30 foot high wooden structure with an 8 sided platform. It is being constructed by a group of at least 5 men who are on the top of the platform and have accessed it via a wooden ladder. The text reads, "The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly. In the early 1930s, fire suppression was an important duty of the Civilian Conservation Corps crews stationed here. They built fire towers and manned them around the clock, scanning the horizon for any hint of smoke. Fire crews attacked whenever fire was detected, in an attempt to stop the destruction." "Meanwhile, local residents continued to annually burn their blackberry patches and meadows. They knew that fire regenerates many plants and keeps unwanted plants from choking out others." "Today, we know that both the CCC and the residents were doing the right thing. Unwanted fires caused by lightning or careless people can be destructive. But under the right conditions, fire can encourage healthy, diverse ecosystems. As you explore this area, you are likely to see evidence of past fires, both prescribed and wild." The top right of the panel is a 20 by 20 inch topographic map of the hike on the Wildcat Ridge Trail and Riprap Loop past Chimney Rock and Calvary Rocks. The trail is marked in yellow with a brown dashed line. The text reads, "Suggested Hike: Hike: Riprap Loop. 9.8 mile circuit, very strenuous, 8.25 hours hiking time, 2,365-foot elevation gain, several stream crossings. You can hike this circuit clockwise or counter-clockwise. There's plenty to see and do either way: Straight on Wildcat Ridge Trail, right on Riprap Trail, right on Appalachian Trail (A.T.) south, and left back to the parking lot; or right on A.T. north, left on Riprap Trail; left on Wildcat Ridge Trail, and back to the parking lot." "The section between the Riprap - Wildcat Ridge intersection and Chimney Rock is especially beautiful: lush forest, showy rhododendrons in season (late May), and a wonderful series of streams with cascades and an "ole swimming hole" that's legendary." A red text box below the map gives important information that hikers need. The text reads, "Emergency 1-800-732-0911 (cell phone service is unreliable.) Before You Go! Pets must be on a leash at all times. Do not attempt to cross streams during icy conditions or flooding. Be sure you are physically able to complete the hike you've chosen. Take plenty of water - at least a quart per hour. Be sure you know your route. Free maps are available at entrance stations, visitor centers, and www.nps.gov/shen. When you return from your hike, check for ticks. Be sure someone knows where you are and when to expect your return. Filter or treat water from streams before drinking."

title: Riprap Overlook
listingDescription: Facing west from an elevation of 2,920 ft (890 m), you will look out to Waynesboro and, on a clear day, out to the Alleghenies from Riprap Overlook. In the 1930s, one of the many duties of young men in the Civilian Conservation Corps was to build fire towers and keep them manned around the clock. One of the locations for a fire tower was Wildcat Ridge, straight ahead of this overlook.

images.altText: A view across a field with mountains in the distance.
images.title: Riprap Overlook
images.caption: What's the view from Riprap Overlook?

bodyText: Facing west from an elevation of 2,920 ft (890 m), you will look out to Waynesboro and, on a clear day, out to the Alleghenies from Riprap Overlook. In the 1930s, one of the many duties of young men in the Civilian Conservation Corps was to build fire towers and keep them manned around the clock. One of the locations for a fire tower was Wildcat Ridge, straight ahead of this overlook.
audioDescription: This overlook faces west. There is a field straight ahead surrounded by dense brush and trees. Further away there are ridges of mountains. From the left is Turk Mountain, Wildcat Ridge, and Rocks Mountain. Beyond the mountains there is the flat land of the Shenandoah Valley with the town of Waynesboro off to the left.

title: Robertson Mountain Trailhead
listingDescription: Old Rag Parking Area (Park Boundary) | Pets are not allowed on the Ridge or Saddle Trails, although an alternate route is available for pet owners who still wish to do this hike. This hike does not ascend to the summit of Old Rag, but does provide a great view of the mountain.

images.altText: Color photo of a trail leading into a fall-colored forest
images.title: Hiking Trail in Shenandoah National Park

bodyText:
Pets are not allowed on the Ridge or Saddle Trails, although an alternate route is available for pet owners who still wish to do this hike (see alternate hike description below). This hike does not ascend to the summit of Old Rag, but does provide a great view of the mountain.

Distance: 7.8-mile round trip hike
Difficulty: Strenuous (hiking difficulty scale)
Hiking Time: 6 hours 30 minutes
Elevation Gain: 2,130 feet

Hike Description (No Pets Allowed)

  1. From the Old Rag Parking Area on the Park boundary, take the Ridge Trail and turn right onto the Ridge Access Trail.
  2. Turn left onto Weakley Hollow Fire Road and follow to Robertson Mountain Trail.
  3. Continue to the summit, and then descend to intersection.
  4. Turn left onto Old Rag Fire Road.
  5. Turn left again onto Weakley Hollow Fire Road.
  6. Turn right onto the Ridge Access Trail.
  7. Turn left onto the Ridge Trail and follow back to the Old Rag parking area.

Alternate Hike Description (Pets Allowed)
*Pets must be on a physical leash no longer than 6 feet at all times.

  1. From the Old Rag parking area on the Park boundary, walk along Rt. 600 to Weakley Hollow Fire Road.
  2. Follow the fire road to its intersection with Robertson Mountain Trail.
  3. Turn right onto Robertson Mountain Trail and continue to the summit.
audioDescription: The Old Rag Mountain Trailhead is a 36 by 54 inch color poster. The poster is organized into two columns. On the left the first column begins with the title, "Did You Know?" with a photograph of two hikers helping each other over a large boulder. This image is folloThe Old Rag Mountain Trailhead is a 36 by 54 inch color poster. The poster is organized into two columns. On the left the first column begins with the title, "Did You Know?" with a photograph of two hikers helping each other over a large boulder. This image is followed by the subtitle, "Are You Ready to Hike This Trail?" with text underneath, "The trail to Old Rag summit is strenuous and extremely challenging. Do not attempt this hike unless you are physically able and fully prepared." A list follows, "Wear sturdy footwear. Bring plenty of water and extra food. Bring flashlights and extra clothing in case of emergencies. Be sure you know what time it gets dark and leave adequate time to complete your hike. Note that cell phone service is unreliable throughout the hiking area. There is no public transportation in the Old Rag area." Below this text is a color photograph of a large boulder piles with people scrambling to the top. Below is a second subtitle, "Pets" followed by the text, "Pets are NOT permitted on the Ridge and Saddle Trails. This rule is strictly enforced. Pet owners have the special responsibility of following the park regulations for pets. The challenging terrain and unique habitat of Old Rag mountain make this trail unsuitable and dangerous for pets. If you have a pet, we recommend Hike #2." Beginning the second column on the upper right is a 20 by 20 inch north-oriented topographic map with two recommended hikes highlighted, Hike #1 in yellow and Hike #2 in pink. The text below reads, Hike #1: Old Rag Summit, 9.2-mile circuit, very strenuous, 7-½ hours hiking time, 2,380-foot elevation gain. From the parking area, make a left onto Route 600. Pass the Nicholson Hollow Trailhead and continue to the Ridge Trail. Make a left and continue on the Ridge Trail, crossing the rock scramble to the summit. Be very careful as the footing along the Ridge Trail is challenging, especially in the rock scramble area. Descend from the summit on the Saddle Trail. Continue to follow this path as you pass Old Rag Shelter and the trail becomes a fire road. At the trail intersection, make a right and immediately turn right again to follow Weakley Hollow Fire Road. Continue on this fire road and stay straight on the intersection with Route 600 back to this location. Hike #2: Robertson Mountain, 7.8 mile circuit, strenuous, 6 -½ hours hiking time, 2,130-foot elevation gain. From the parking area, make a left onto Route 600. Pass the Nicholson Hollow Trailhead and continue straight on to the Weakley Hollow Fire Road. Take Weakley Hollow Fire Road to Robertson Mountain Trail. Follow the Robertson Mountain Trail to the summit and descend to the Old Rag Fire Road. Turn left onto Old Rag Fire Road and then another left onto Weakley Hollow Fire Road. Continue on this fire road and stay straight on the intersection with Route 600 back to this location. This hike includes one of the steepest sections of trails in the park, but it is a good alternative for hikers in good physical condition who want a pet-friendly hike with excellent views." A red text box below the map gives important information that hikers need. The text reads, "Emergency 1-800-732-0911 (cell phone service is unreliable.) Before You Go! Pets are not allowed on the Ridge and Saddle Trails. Be sure you are physically able to complete the hike you've chosen. - Do not attempt this hike in wet or icy conditions. Take plenty of water-at least a quart per hour. Be sure you know your route. Free maps are available at entrance stations, visitor centers, and www.nps.gov/shen. When you return from your hike, check for ticks. Be sure someone knows where you are and when to expect your return.wed by the subtitle, "Are You Ready to Hike This Trail?" with text underneath, "The trail to Old Rag summit is strenuous and extremely challenging. Do not attempt this hike unless you are physically able and fully prepared." A list follows, "Wear sturdy footwear. Bring plenty of water and extra food. Bring flashlights and extra clothing in case of emergencies. Be sure you know what time it gets dark and leave adequate time to complete your hike. Note that cell phone service is unreliable throughout the hiking area. There is no public transportation in the Old Rag area." Below this text is a color photograph of a large boulder piles with people scrambling to the top. Below is a second subtitle, "Pets" followed by the text, "Pets are NOT permitted on the Ridge and Saddle Trails. This rule is strictly enforced. Pet owners have the special responsibility of following the park regulations for pets. The challenging terrain and unique habitat of Old Rag mountain make this trail unsuitable and dangerous for pets.

title: Rockfish Backcountry Registration
listingDescription: Backcountry Camping is a wilder, more primitive experience than staying in a campground and requires important planning and appropriate equipment. Backcountry campers are required to have a permit. Register for a backcountry camping permit here. You must register 1 hour before sunset. For more information visit nps.gov/shen/planyourvisit/campbc.htm

images.altText: A small, angled roof supported by two brown, vertical beams shelters a large, flat glass case.
images.title: Rockfish Backcountry Registration
images.caption: Register for a required backcountry camping permit here.

bodyText: Backcountry Camping is a wilder, more primitive experience than staying in a campground and requires important planning and appropriate equipment. Backcountry campers are required to have a permit. Register for a backcountry camping permit here. You must register 1 hour before sunset.
audioDescription: A small, angled roof supported by two brown, vertical beams shelters a large, flat glass case with a poster in it. The poster relates the backcountry camping regulations and explains how to fill out the permit.

title: Rockfish Entrance Station - Historic
listingDescription: This site was the original entrance to Shenandoah from the south. The building was constructed by the Civilian Conservation Corps and served as the welcoming point until the current building just south of here was built in 2010.

images.altText: A poster describing the historic entrance at Rockfish
images.title: Rockfish Entrance Station - Historic
images.caption: The historic entrance to Shenandoah from the south

bodyText: This site was the original entrance to Shenandoah from the south. The building was constructed by the Civilian Conservation Corps and served as the welcoming point until the current building just south of here was built in 2010.
audioDescription:
A poster about the Rockfish entrance to Shenandoah National Park. Across the top in large black letter outlined in white on a blue background: Rockfish Gap. Just under the title is a light blue box with round corners which contains three pictures and three blocks of text.

Top block of text: Although work began on Skyline Drive in 1933, the vision of extending to the planned Blue Ridge Parkway was not realized until 1939 when the final section, Jarman Gap to Rockfish Gap was completed.
To the right of this text: a historic black and white photo of the curving entrance with a white sign indicating Shenandoah National Park
Below this is a historic photo of the Rockfish Station. A black sedan is at the building and a Ranger stands beside a stop sign near the car.
Text beneath: Rangers welcomed visitors to the southern entrance to Shenandoah from a small rustic building that stood in the median just across the southbound lane of Skyline Drive. The Rockfish Gap Entrance Station was built by the "boys" of the Civilian Conservation Corps in the newly established style of "Parkitecture."
In the right third of the box there are a photo and a text block. The photo is a historic black and white photo of a rectangular building, small and rustic with wood siding and a shingle roof.
Text: "Parkitecture" combines native wood and stone with native styles to create visually appealing structures that fit naturally within their specific landscapes. The first Rockfish Entrance Station was side gabled and wood framed with board and batten exterior walls. The roof had fire-resistant concrete shingles, developed for the remote park buildings that were far from localities with fire departments.
Over the years, the requirements of entrance stations and the role of their Rangers have evolved. In 2010, the classic entrance station was removed and a new building was put into service about a mile south.

The first 20 miles or so will be through the quietest part of the Park with beautiful vistas overlooking federally designated wilderness. The Loft Mountain area at mile 7

bodyText: Rockfish is the southern entrance to Shenandoah National Park. From here you can travel north through Shenandoah National Park. Be sure to notice the mile markers. Use those to find dining, lodging, visitor centers, trailheads, and more. You are starting at mile 105; numbers will descend as you travel north. The first 20 miles or so will be through the quietest part of the Park with beautiful vistas overlooking federally designated wilderness. The Loft Mountain area at mile 79.5 is a great place to stop for food, restrooms, and souvenirs.
audioDescription: The entrance station is a drive-through with a covered, slanted roof, and a window on the drivers-side, where a ranger is present during open hours.

title: Rocky Mount Overlook
listingDescription: Facing west-northwest from an elevation of 2,445 ft (745 m), the view from Rocky Mount Overlook looks straight out to Rocky Mount. The second largest forest fire in the history of Shenandoah National Park occurred in the Rocky Mount area. The fire began on April 16, 2016. Dry conditions and wind soon caused the fire to spread rapidly. The fire was contained by April 29, leaving a total of 10,326 acres burned.

images.altText: View over vegetation out to mountains in the distance.
images.title: Rocky Mount Overlook
images.caption: What's the view from Rocky Mount Overlook?

bodyText: Facing west-northwest from an elevation of 2,445 ft (745 m), the view from Rocky Mount Overlook looks straight out to Rocky Mount. The second largest forest fire in the history of Shenandoah National Park occurred in the Rocky Mount area. The fire began on April 16, 2016. Dry conditions and wind soon caused the fire to spread rapidly. The fire was contained by April 29, leaving a total of 10,326 acres burned.
audioDescription: This overlook faces west-northwest. The view extends over brush and down a hollow with Rocky Mount rising straight ahead. From the right a ridge descends in front of Rocky Mount. From the left Two Mile Ridge is to the left and beyond Rocky Mount.

title: Rockytop Overlook
listingDescription: Looking west-northwest at Rockytop Overlook from an elevation of 2,860 ft (871 m), you will see the more rugged south district of Shenandoah National Park. Lewis Mountain is far in the distance, while Loft Mountain is on the right. Loft Mountain is not the location of the Loft Mountain Campground. Rather, the campground is located on Big Flat Mountain. Due to the unappealing nature of the name Big Flat Mountain Campground, park officials decided to use Loft Mountain as the c

images.altText: A view over field with mountains rising in the distance.
images.title: Rockytop Overlook
images.caption: What's the view from Rockytop Overlook?

bodyText: Looking west-northwest at Rockytop Overlook from an elevation of 2,860 ft (871 m), you will see the more rugged south district of Shenandoah National Park. Lewis Mountain is far in the distance, while Loft Mountain is on the right. Loft Mountain is not the location of the Loft Mountain Campground. Rather, the campground is located on Big Flat Mountain. Due to the unappealing nature of the name Big Flat Mountain Campground, park officials decided to use Loft Mountain as the campground's namesake instead.
audioDescription: This overlook faces west-northwest. There is a narrow field with grasses that descends into a valley below with mountains rising up in the distance. From the left is Patterson Ridge. Behind Patterson Ridge is a long ridge that includes Lewis Mountain far in the distance and Rockytop Mountain to the right of Lewis. From the right is Loft Mountain. At the point that the descending slopes of Loft and Rocktop intersect you can see the Shenandoah Valley out to the horizon. There is an interpretive sign at this overlook. The Rockytop Overlook interpretive sign is a 36 by 24 inch color graphic panel on a dark metal frame angled towards the viewer. The title text reads, "Rekindling Nature." The body text reads, "A wildfire swept over this mountain in 1986, burning 4,475 acres in seven days. While dramatic, it certainly wasn't tragic. Fire is nature's way of cleaning house. It keeps the forest healthy by burning leaf litter, dead wood, and even living plants. Fire removes shade-making, fire-intolerant plants from the understory, giving other species sun and space to grow on the forest floor. Many native Appalachian plants, like fire-tolerant oak trees and woodland wildflowers, would disappear without fire in the forest. Fire is as much a part of the ecosystem as rain and sun." The text is on top of two images that are blended together. On the lower left of the graphic is a close up image of a pinecone surrounded by burnt debris on the ground. Text accompanying this image reads, "The table mountain pine depends on fire for regeneration. Fire's heat melts the pinecone resin, allowing the table mountain pine's seeds to drop and germinate on the nutrient-rich forest floor." To the right of the image is a photograph of a fireman in uniform surrounded by smoke. Text accompanying this image reads, "National Park Service fire managers use fire as a tool to help native ecosystems flourish. Wildland firefighters sometimes set small fires deliberately, as controlled burns. Small, controlled fires prevent flammable materials from piling up and creating conditions for large fires-dangerous to firefighters and nearby communities. "A black bar on the top of the graphic reads "Shenandoah National Park" on the left and on the right is the National Park Service Arrowhead symbol with the text "National Park Service/U.S. Department of the Interior"

title: Rose River Falls Trailhead
listingDescription: Fishers Gap Parking Area (mile 49.4) | A hike to a dazzling 67' waterfall. For most of this hike, you’ll be on a beautiful trail in one of the Park’s federally designated Wilderness areas.

images.altText: Color photo of a waterfall in the midst of the fresh spring green trees from a forest.
images.title: Rose River Falls

bodyText:
A hike to a dazzling 67 foot waterfall. For most of this hike, you’ll be on a beautiful trail in one of the Park’s federally designated Wilderness areas. Pets must be on a physical leash no longer than 6 feet at all times.

Distance: 4-mile circuit hike
Difficulty: Moderate (explanation of our hiking difficulty scale)
Hiking Time: 4 hours 30 minutes
Elevation Gain: 910 feet

Hike Description

  1. From the Fishers Gap Parking Area (mile 49.4), cross Skyline Drive and start down the fire road.
  2. Just after the chain, take a left onto the Skyland-Big Meadows Horse Trail (yellow-blazed).
  3. In about 0.6-mile take the blue-blazed Rose River Loop Trail.
  4. Follow it past the 67-foot falls.
  5. Continue to the bridge, where you begin hiking up a steep, rocky section past beautiful cascades.
  6. At the fire road (yellow-blazed), turn right across bridge.
  7. For an added treat (and about .25-mile more hiking), you can take the Dark Hollow Falls Trail to the base of the falls and back.
  8. Then continue uphill about one mile back to Skyline Drive.

title: Sandy Bottom Overlook
listingDescription: From Sandy Bottom Overlook you will see the foothills of the Blue Ridge Mountains descending to the Shenandoah Valley below. Sandy Bottom is the small community in the valley. The southern section of the Shenandoah Valley is historically more sparsely populated and remote than the northern section. In the 1790s when turnpikes arose as a means of connecting towns and villages to larger trade routes further east, smaller enclaves in the southern end of the valley were often byp

images.altText: A view over brush down to foothills and valley below.
images.title: Sandy Bottom Overlook
images.caption: What's the view from Sandy Bottom Overlook?

bodyText:
From Sandy Bottom Overlook you will see the foothills of the Blue Ridge Mountains descending to the Shenandoah Valley below. Sandy Bottom is the small community in the valley. The southern section of the Shenandoah Valley is historically more sparsely populated and remote than the northern section. In the 1790s when turnpikes arose as a means of connecting towns and villages to larger trade routes further east, smaller enclaves in the southern end of the valley were often bypassed in favor of faster routes between larger towns.

Maintenance of this view funded by Rockingham County Tourism through the Shenandoah National Park Trust Adopt an Overlook program.
audioDescription: This overlook faces north-northwest. There is a small clearing and some vegetation before the slope descends revealing the mountains and valley in the distance. From the left is Bush Mountain, Beldor Ridge, Hanse Mountain, and Dollys Knob. In front of Hanse Mountain and between Beldor Ridge and Dollys Knob is the small community of Sandy Bottom. Beyond Hanse Mountain is the Shenandoah Valley. The long ridge of Massanutten is Mountain spans the horizon.

title: Sawmill Ridge Overlook
listingDescription: See a sweeping view of Shenandoah's south district from Sawmill Ridge Overlook. Facing southwest from an elevation of 2,215 ft (675 m), the mountains visible from here are, from the left, Calf Mountain, further back is Scott Mountain, closer and straight ahead is Ramsey Mountain, and closer still and moving off to the right is Sawmill Ridge. Sawmill Ridge leads up to Turk Mountain.

images.altText: View across field with line of trees and mountains in the distance.
images.title: Sawmill Ridge Overlook
images.caption: What's the view from Sawmill Ridge Overlook?

bodyText:
See a sweeping view of Shenandoah's south district from Sawmill Ridge Overlook. Facing southwest from an elevation of 2,215 ft (675 m), the mountains visible from here are, from the left, Calf Mountain, further back is Scott Mountain, closer and straight ahead is Ramsey Mountain, and closer still and moving off to the right is Sawmill Ridge. From the left is Calf Mountain, further back is Scott Mountain, closer and straight ahead is Ramsey Mountain, and closer still and moving off to the right is Sawmill Ridge.

title: Sawmill Run Overlook
listingDescription: Facing southwest from an elevation of 2,200 ft (670 m), Sawmill Run Overlook gives you a small window to view the distant mountains. To your right is Sawmill Ridge, heading up to Turk Mountain. Straight ahead at the descent of Sawmill Ridge is Sawmill Run. This overlook is obscured by vegetation for much of the year.

images.altText: A view of vegetation with a window of mountains in the distance.
images.title: Sawmill Run Overlook
images.caption: What's the view from Sawmill Run Overlook?

bodyText:
Facing southwest from an elevation of 2,200 ft (670 m), Sawmill Run Overlook gives you a small window to view the distant mountains. To your right is Sawmill Ridge, heading up to Turk Mountain. Straight ahead at the descent of Sawmill Ridge is Sawmill Run. This overlook is obscured by vegetation for much of the year.

Maintenance of this view funded by Augusta County through the Shenandoah National Park Trust Adopt an Overlook program.
audioDescription: The view from this overlook looks southwest. The view is overgrown with dense vegetation for much of the year. To the right there is Sawmill Ridge, a higher ridge that moves further from the view as it descends to the valley below. Straight ahead is Sawmill Run, where there is a low point in the mountains. Further in the distance are ridges of the mountains with the Shenandoah Valley along the horizon. There is an interpretive sign at this overlook. The Sawmill Run Overlook interpretive sign is a 36 by 24 inch color graphic panel on a dark metal frame angled towards the viewer. The title text reads, "A Cumulative Tale." The body text reads, "Azalea, blueberry, mountain laurel, black huckleberry, and trailing arbutus-these are all members of the Heath family, plants that thrive in acidic, otherwise infertile soils. Think the heathers of the British Isles and the cranberry bogs of New England. Also think Shenandoah National Park, specifically at Sawmill Run Overlook, where you are now. Notice the plants that thrive here. Now think geology. The underlying rock here- metamorphosed sandstone and siltstone-is rich in quartzite. Quartzite breaks down into soil that is quite acidic. Acidic soil helps these Heaths flourish. Geologic history affects soil type which affects what kinds of plants grow in that soil. Like the fairy tale house that Jack built, it's a cumulative tale-in this case a geologic and ecologic one." In the background there is a close up image of pine needles and branches. The caption for this image reads, "The area around Sawmill Run Overlook is a dry, oak-chestnut forest, but it is also good habitat for pines like the table mountain pine, Virginia pine, and pitch pine." On the lower right of the graphic there is a transparent black box. The title text in this box reads, "A Habitat of Their Own." The body text reads, "Since everything in an ecosystem is affected by everything else in that ecosystem, even one plant would be missed. Leave everything as you find it, including the wildflowers and plants which depend on this particular habitat to grow. This area hosts several rare, acid-loving plants." Below this text are six images. From the left, there is an image of a brown, drooping flower-type plant labeled, "Sweet pinesap," an image of a cluster of bright green petals with several pink petals labelled, "Goat's rue," an image of a purple flower with one large petal labeled, "Butterfly pea," an image of a vertical cluster of small, white flowers labeled, "Slender ladies' tresses," an image of a round cluster of star-shaped light pink flowers labeled, "Trailing arbutus," and lastly, an image of a yellowish, brownish butterfly with a grey body perched atop a leave labeled, "Elfin butterfly." A black bar on the top of the graphic reads "Shenandoah National Park" on the left and on the right is the National Park Service Arrowhead symbol with the text "National Park Service/U.S. Department of the Interior"

title: Shenandoah National Park Headquarters
listingDescription: This building houses the Park's administrative offices and is open 8:00 a.m. to 4:30 p.m., Monday through Friday. (Closed federal holidays.) The signage out front has a map, and information about some of the natural and cultural resources that make Shenandoah National Park a special place for everyone.

images.altText: A large two-story building with a stone facade.
images.title: Shenandoah National Park Headquarters
images.caption: Shenandoah National Park Headquarters

bodyText: This building houses the Park's administrative offices and is open 8:00 a.m. to 4:30 p.m., Monday through Friday. (Closed federal holidays.) The signage out front has a map, and information about some of the natural and cultural resources that make Shenandoah National Park a special place for everyone.
audioDescription: A parking lot with an orientation shelter and a paved pathway leading up to a large two-story stone building across a lawn. The orientation shelter is a small roof supported by six brown beams. The beams are frames for six upright 36 inch by 54 inch panels in glass enclosures. Panel 1. Bulletin Board This panel contains seasonal information. Panel 2. Park History Bulletin Board This panel contains rotating information about topics relating to the history of Shenandoah National Park. Panel 3. Park Map This graphic is divided into two columns, the left has text and images and the right has a map. On the right column, title text reads, "Welcome to Shenandoah National Park." Below the title is a color photograph of a man standing atop a rock outcrop and looking to the mountains in the distance on a sunny day. Layered on the image is the quote "...for the recreation and the re-creation they shall find here." -President Franklin Roosevelt, Shenandoah's Dedication." Text below the image reads, "Shenandoah National Park was established in 1935 to bring the western national park experience to the urban east. Here, within a few hours' drive of millions, you will find "recreation and re-creation." Experience the wonder of nature, the power of shared heritage, and the inspiration that is the future of our national parks." Below there is the subheading "Shenandoah Highlights," and the text "- Skyline Drive - 105 miles of beauty. Please observe the 35 mph speed limit to see it all safely. - 75 Overlooks - Spectacular views of the Shenandoah Valley and Virginia Piedmont. - 500 Miles of Trails - Beautiful waterfalls, quiet forests, and mountain summits are just a hike away. - Visitor Centers - Films, exhibits, and Ranger-led walks and talks tell Shenandoah's stories." The map to the right shows the boundaries of, driving route through, and highlights in Shenandoah National Park. The map area is 30 miles wide by 150 miles long. Shenandoah National Park is shaded green. Highlights include entrance stations, visitor centers, campgrounds, lodging, restrooms, food services, and trailheads. At the bottom of the map is the park emergency number: (800) 732-0911. At the top and bottom of the graphic are black bars. The black bar at the top has the text, "Shenandoah National Park," to the left, and "National Park Service, U.S. Department of the Interior," on the right with the National Park Service arrowhead logo to the far right. The lower black bar has the Leave No Trace logo on the left with the text "Leave No Trace Principe #6, Respect Wildlife," and on the right the text "www.nps.gov/shen." Panel 4. Spring/Summer The graphic is split into two horizontal sections with text and graphics in rectangles. The top section has the title, "Spring" with the subtitle "Renewal." The rectangle is split vertically. The left side contains three color photographs with text descriptions. The first image is white flowers with four petals labeled "Flowering Dogwood," and the accompanying text, "Dogwood blossoms are well-known messengers of spring, but this understory tree has other jobs, too - like providing food and shelter." The second image shows a mother deer and two fawns walking in high grasses labeled "White-tailed Deer" with the accompanying text "White-tailed deer hide their fawns under the dogwood's low-hanging branches and feed on its tender shoots, buds, and later, berries." The third image shows a dark blue bird with black tail feathers labeled "Indigo Bunting," and the accompanying text "Indigo buntings often build their nests in dogwood trees and line them with deer hair. Birds love the berries' high fat content, a great trade-off for the dogwood, since its seeds are spread by those who eat them, ensuring the dogwood's renewal." The right side of the top panel contains the text, "From the moment the first plant pushes up through the forest floor beginning its annual growth cycle, spring is renewal. Hungry black bears come out of their dens with winter-born cubs. Migratory birds return, butterflies emerge, and wildflowers herald the season. Every life, new and old, depends on another." There are nine color photographs under this text arranged in a 3 by 3 square. From the top left they are: a bush with clumps of white flowers labeled "Mountain Laurel," a butterfly with white and yellow markings and blue tips on the wings labeled "Eastern Tiger Swallowtail," round mounds of fungus growing out of the forest floor labeled "Morel Mushrooms" a small curled up salamander labeled "Red-backed Salamander," a bird with yellow, black, and white markings labeled "Chestnut-sided Warbler," a single white flower with three petals and large green leaves labeled "Large-flowered Trillium," a light brown toad on the ground labeled "Spring Pepper," a set of three yellow and red bell shaped flowers labeled "Wild Columbine," and a bird with a white chest and tan head and wings labeled "Red-eyed Vireo." The bottom section has the title "Summer".
