title: Shenandoah Valley Battlefields National Historic District
listingDescription: A place of unmatched scenic beauty where generations can gather to understand, commemorate, and draw meaning from our nation's heritage.

images.credit: Ninja Pix, courtesy of Shenandoah Valley Battlefields NHD
images.altText: Fisher's Hill Witness Tree
images.caption: Fisher's Hill Witness Tree

relatedParks.fullName: Cedar Creek & Belle Grove National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Cedar Creek & Belle Grove

tags: Shenandoah Valley Battlefields National Historic District
bodyText:
During the Civil War, control of the Shenandoah Valley was critical to the fate of Virginia and the Confederacy. The Valley witnessed Stonewall Jackson’s adept 1862 Valley Campaign, General Robert E. Lee’s advance to the Confederate “high tide” at Gettysburg, the Virginia Military Institute Cadets’ valiant charge at New Market, and U.S. General Philip H. Sheridan’s final campaign to crush Confederate ambitions for the Valley—which included "the Burning," the fiery destruction of the region’s agricultural bounty.

Today, the Valley’s historic towns and preserved landscapes offer a wealth of sites where you can experience the region’s dramatic Civil War story. You can also explore the spectacular natural beauty of the Valley via historic roadways, winding mountain roads, leisurely walking tours, or challenging hiking trails to spectacular overlooks.  And you can enjoy the wide variety of other experiences that the Valley has to offer: natural wonders, history and heritage sites, arts and culture, and dining and lodging in the Valley’s historic towns.

In 1996, Congress designated eight counties (Augusta, Clark, Frederick, Highland, Page, Rockingham, Shenandoah, and Warren) in the Shenandoah Valley of Virginia as the Shenandoah Valley Battlefields National Historic District. The purpose of this National Heritage Area is to preserve and interpret the region’s significant Civil War battlefields and related historic sites. That effort is led by the Shenandoah Valley Battlefields Foundation, which works with partners to preserve the hallowed ground of the Valley’s Civil War battlefields, to share its Civil War story with the nation, and to encourage tourism and travel to the Valley’s Civil War sites.

The Shenandoah Valley Battlefields National Historic District is home to the following NPS units:

  • Cedar Creek & Belle Grove National Historic Park

  • Shenandoah National Park

quickFacts.value: The peaceful beauty of Virginia’s Shenandoah Valley was shattered during the American Civil War.  Today you can still view much of the landscape as it was seen by soldiers and civilians during the war, and you can explore the region’s dramatic Civil War story at historic sites, battlefields, courthouses, cemeteries, walking trails, and museums that tell the story of those storm-tossed years.

bodyText:
Facing north from an elevation of 1,390 ft (423 m) you are looking at the northern end of the Shenandoah Valley. Looking to the right you can see Signal Knob. Signal Knob is the northern tip of the Massanutten Mountain, a range that divides the Shenandoah Valley and forks the Shenandoah River.
The town of Front Royal is to the right of the view. Front Royal was incorporated in 1788. It is believed that the name Front Royal derived from the French "le front royal," referring to the frontier of British (hence, royal) territory during the early days of colonial America.
audioDescription: This overlook faces north. From the left is Signal Knob, a part of Massanutten Mountain. Skyline High School is a larger building closer to the overlook. Toward the right is the town of Front Royal. title: Shenandoah-Blue Ridge Parkway
listingDescription: This spot is where Skyline Drive, the scenic byway through Shenandoah National Park joins the Blue Ridge Parkway, another national park unit. The orientation panels in the kiosk here describe the differences between the two. Both are wonderful! If you are traveling north into Shenandoah, welcome! You will encounter a ranger station in less than a mile where you can pay your entrance fee and get a map and other information. Have a great visit in Shenandoah National Park!

images.altText: A color photograph of people looking at a shelter with two sets of informational panels.
images.title: Shenandoah-Blue Ridge Parkway
images.caption: Learn more about Shenandoah National Park at the orientation shelter here.

bodyText: This spot is where Skyline Drive, the scenic byway through Shenandoah National Park joins the Blue Ridge Parkway, another national park unit. The orientation panels in the kiosk here describe the differences between the two. Both are wonderful! If you are traveling north into Shenandoah, welcome! You will encounter a ranger station in less than a mile where you can pay your entrance fee and get a map and other information. Have a great visit in Shenandoah National Park!

Spring/SummerThe graphic is split into two horizontal sections with text and graphics in rectangles. The top section has the title, "Spring" with the subtitle "Renewal." The rectangle is split vertically. The left side contains three color photographs with text descriptions. The first image is white flowers with four petals labeled "Flowering Dogwood," and the accompanying text, "Dogwood blossoms are well-known messengers of spring, but this understory tree has other jobs, too - like providing food and shelter." The second image shows a mother deer and two fawns walking in high grasses labeled "White-tailed Deer" with the accompanying text "White-tailed deer hide their fawns under the dogwood's low-hanging branches and feed on its tender shoots, buds, and later, berries." The third image shows a dark blue bird with black tail feathers labeled "Indigo Bunting," and the accompanying text "Indigo buntings often build their nests in dogwood trees and line them with deer hair. Birds love the berries' high fat content, a great trade-off for the dogwood, since its seeds are spread by those who eat them, ensuring the dogwood's renewal." The right side of the top panel contains the text, "From the moment the first plant pushes up through the forest floor beginning its annual growth cycle, spring is renewal. Hungry black bears come out of their dens with winter-born cubs. Migratory birds return, butterflies emerge, and wildflowers herald the season. Every life, new and old, depends on another." There are nine color photographs under this text arranged in a 3 by 3 square. From the top left they are: a bush with clumps of white flowers labeled "Mountain Laurel," a butterfly with white and yellow markings and blue tips on the wings labeled "Eastern Tiger Swallowtail," round mounds of fungus growing out of the forest floor labeled "Morel Mushrooms" a small curled up salamander labeled "Red-backed Salamander," a bird with yellow, black, and white markings labeled "Chestnut-sided Warbler," a single white flower with three petals and large green leaves labeled "Large-flowered Trillium," a light brown toad on the ground labeled "Spring Pepper," a set of three yellow and red bell shaped flowers labeled "Wild Columbine," and a bird with a white chest and tan head and wings labeled "Red-eyed Vineo." The bottom section has the title "Summer" and the subtitle "Abundance." The rectangle is split vertically. The left side has the text, "Summer buzzes with activity. Wildflowers bloom profusely, attracting birds, insects, and butterflies. Animals take advantage of the season's abundance, their young growing

title: Signal Knob Overlook
listingDescription: Facing west-northwest from an elevation of 2,090 ft (637 m), you are looking across the Shenandoah Valley to the Massanutten Mountain Range. Signal Knob is the northern most point of the Massanutten before the ridge descends back into the valley. During the Civil War, Confederate soldiers held signal knob as a lookout, most notably for the Battle of Cedar Creek. Union soldiers later took control of Signal Knob in 1864. Today, Signal Knob is a part of George Washington Nationa

images.altText: View of Shenandoah Valley with hills in the foreground and background.
images.title: Signal Knob Overlook
images.caption: What's the view from Signal Knob Overlook?

bodyText: Facing west-northwest from an elevation of 2,090 ft (637 m), you are looking across the Shenandoah Valley to the Massanutten Mountain Range. Signal Knob is the northern most point of the Massanutten before the ridge descends back into the valley. During the Civil War, Confederate soldiers held signal knob as a lookout, most notably for the Battle of Cedar Creek. Union soldiers later took control of Signal Knob in 1864. Today, Signal Knob is a part of George Washington National Forest, but its history lives on in story and scattered remains.
audioDescription: This overlook faces west-northwest across the Shenandoah Valley. From the left is Gimlet Ridge, descending to the valley floor. The Shenandoah River weaves through the landscape. Across the valley is the Massanutten Mountain Range that ends at Signal Knob, toward the right. There is an interpretive sign at this overlook. The Signal Knob Overlook interpretive sign is a 48 by 24 inch color graphic panel on a dark metal frame angled towards the viewer. The title text reads, "No Park is an Island. The body text reads, "Skyline Drive was conceived and built so that people could enjoy views of the rural Shenandoah Valley and Virginia Piedmont. Indeed, the Valley looks like a folk art painting from up here-brush strokes of farms, homes, forests, and small businesses. Though the landscape you see from Signal Knob Overlook is mostly rural, it's less rural than it was 20, 30, 50 years ago. More houses have been built, and more businesses. This view is losing its folk art character. Shenandoah National Park is not an island. What happens outside its boundaries-expansion, industrialization, the building of cell phone towers-affects the park and views from Skyline Drive. Park management can make decisions on how to best protect and preserve the resources inside Shenandoah. But because many of the views from our overlooks and peaks lie in towns and cities outside Park boundaries, surrounding communities also have a role in protecting the Park's views. There is a delicate balance between development and preservation." In the background there is a photograph from a high elevation looking down to the Shenandoah Valley below and out to mountains in the distance. On the lower right there is a river weaving through the image with the label, "South fork of Shenandoah River." Above the river there is a peak that is labeled, "Signal Knob." On the right side of the photograph is the text, "From this overlook you can see Signal Knob, the northernmost peak of Massanutten Mountain. Much of the Massanutten remains undeveloped because it too is public land, protected as part of the George Washington National Forest. You can also see the Shenandoah River flowing north to its confluence with the Potomac before emptying into the Chesapeake Bay." On the lower left of the graphic is a transparent black box. The title text of the box reads, "A Landscape Forever Changing." To the right of the title are three photographs labeled with different years, taken from the same location. The first photograph is black and white and shows old cars in the overlook's parking lot with a view of farmland and the river below. This image is labeled "1940," and accompanied by the text, "The view from Signal Knob Overlook when the Drive was much newer was only dotted with development." The second image is a color photograph of the view with more human structures visible in the distance. This image is labeled, "1965," and accompanied by the text, "By 1965 visitors to Shenandoah could see the beginnings of construction and expansion in the Valley." The third image is also a color photograph and shows the view with even more cleared land. This image is labeled, "1997" and accompanied by the text, "More houses and small businesses encroach upon the view." A black bar on the top of the graphic reads "Shenandoah National Park" on the left and on the right is the National Park Service Arrowhead symbol with the text "National Park Service/U.S. Department of the Interior"

title: Skyland
listingDescription: Whether you want to sit down to a nice dinner, unwind in one of the many available lodging accommodations, or attend an evening Ranger program, Skyland has you covered. This historic resort predates Shenandoah National Park, marketed as an escape from city life beginning in the 1890s by businessman and promoter George Freeman Pollock. Today, the facilities here are managed by the Park concessioner and still offer that same sense of escape.

images.altText: A color photograph of a historical wooden sign for Skyland.
images.title: Skyland

bodyText:
Whether you want to sit down to a nice dinner, unwind in one of the many available lodging accommodations, or attend an evening Ranger program, Skyland has you covered. This historic resort predates Shenandoah National Park, marketed as an escape from city life beginning in the 1890s by businessman and promoter George Freeman Pollock. Today, the facilities here are managed by the Park concessioner and still offer that same sense of escape. There are many services within the Skyland area:

Massanutten Lodge
Skyland Amphitheater
Skyland Dining Room, Taproom, and Gift Shop
Skyland Lodging
Skyland Stables: Guided Horseback Rides
audioDescription: The entrance to Skyland is an access road located off of Skyline Drive. There is one brown sign with large white lettering "Skyland" a short distance before the turn-off. At the turn-off to the access road, on a triangular area of grass, is a second sign. This large sign is made of wood and is supported by two wooden pillars and is underneath a small shingled roof. Accompanying Text: 1/4 mile to Skyland. Cabins, Rooms, Dining Hall, Conference Hall, Riding Horses, Gift Shop.

title: Skyland Amphitheater
listingDescription: Nothing adds to the National Park experience quite like enjoying an evening ranger program at Skyland amphitheater! Come listen to a Park Ranger present a variety of topics that will help you to connect to Shenandoah on a deeper level.

images.altText: A color photograph of an amphitheater with benches facing a wood-paneled building.
images.title: Skyland Amphitheater

bodyText:
Nothing adds to the National Park experience quite like enjoying an evening ranger program at Skyland amphitheater! Come listen to a Park Ranger present a variety of topics that will help you to connect to Shenandoah on a deeper level. 

Evening ranger programs are typically held at the Skyland Amphitheater during late spring, summer, and fall. The program schedule can be found on the back page of your visitor guide or in the bulletin board at the amphitheater entrance. You can also view the ranger program schedule online or on our calendar.
audioDescription: A sidewalk leads past a water fountain to the Skyland Amphitheater. Approaching the amphitheater, on the left there are eight rows of benches divided by a middle aisle. The benches are positioned on a slight slope downward directed towards the Amphitheater projection booth building. It is a small brown building with a metal door that raises to show a large screen. There is a railing and small stage.

title: Skyland Conference Hall
listingDescription: The Skyland Conference Hall is located on the lower level of Skyland (mile 41.7). The venue can be rented out for private functions.

images.altText: A brown wooden building with a sign on front that reads "Skyland Conference Hall"
images.title: Skyland Conference Hall

bodyText: The Skyland Conference Hall is a beautiful venue that can be rented for private functions, meetings, and conferences. It is operated by the Park concessioner. Their website contains more information about meeting room reservations.
audioDescription: A long rectangular brown wooden building slightly raised from the ground. A sidewalk and four steps lead up to a porch which runs the length of the building. There are benches on the porch and in front of the building. There are multiple sets of doors with glass panes that lead into the building. There is a light pole to the right of the sidewalk. There is also a chimney.

title: Skyland Dining Room
listingDescription: This beautiful building on the site of historic Skyland resort gives diners a beautiful view of the Shenandoah Valley below, while offering the chance to relax and unwind after a busy day exploring the Park. There are several different dining options.

images.altText: A group of diners sit at several tables in a dining room with wooden floors and large windows.
images.title: Skyland Dining Room

bodyText:
Opens April 7, 2023. Closes November 12, 2023. 

This beautiful building on the site of historic Skyland resort gives diners a beautiful view of the Shenandoah Valley below, while offering the chance to unwind on the patio after a busy day exploring the Park. There are several different dining options within the building. Skyland’s Pollock Dining Room is a full service dining room serving breakfast, lunch and dinner. The Mountain Taproom features a lighter fare menu with beer, local wines, and nightly family-friendly entertainment. The Grab 'n Go station offers sandwiches, salads, pastries, snacks and drinks for meals to go.

The building also houses the Skyland Gift Shop, which sells souvenirs, gifts, and local wines.

Skyland is typically open from late spring through late fall. Delware North, the Park concessioner, operates all of the dining services within Shenandoah National Park. Their website has more information and seasonal operating hours.
audioDescription: Wide concrete steps bordered by a handrail and low stone wall lead to a short covered walkway and the main entrance glass doors to the Skyland Dining Room. On the right of the walkway are the large windows of the Gift Shop.

title: Skyland Lodging
listingDescription: If you're staying at Skyland, the Skyland Registration Office will be your first stop to check in. Lodging accommodations range from premium rooms to detached small cabins, preferred and traditional rooms, suites, and pet friendly rooms - located in 28 separate buildings along the ridge and in the wooded areas on over 27 acres of Shenandoah National Park.

images.altText: A hotel room with two beds and a view through the window of blue mountains.
images.title: Skyland Lodge Preferred Room

bodyText:
Opens April 7, 2023. Closes November 26, 2023. 

If you're staying at Skyland, the Skyland Registration Office will be your first stop to check in. Lodging accommodations range from premium rooms to detached small cabins, preferred and traditional rooms, suites, and pet friendly rooms - located in 28 separate buildings along the ridge and in the wooded areas on over 27 acres of Shenandoah National Park.

Skyland typically opens in the spring and closes in late fall and is operated by the Park concessioner, Delaware North. More information about rates, reservations, and operating hours can be found on their website.

title: Skyland Stables
listingDescription: There is no more genuine way to experience Shenandoah National Park than on horseback. Leaving from Skyland Stables, guided horse and pony rides are typically available throughout the day, May through October, weather permitting. Rides depart from the stables, cross over Skyline Drive, and travel past the Limberlost area through an old apple orchard.

images.altText: A line of people on horseback ride down a dirt trail in a green forest.
images.title: Skyland Horseback Riding

bodyText:
Opens May 5, 2023. October 29, 2023. 

There is no more genuine way to experience Shenandoah National Park than on horseback. Guided horseback and pony rides are available at Skyland Stables throughout the day, weather and season permitting. Horseback rides depart from the stables, cross over Skyline Drive, and travel past the Limberlost area through an old apple orchard.

Horseback rides are managed by Delaware North, the Park's concessioner, and are typically offered May through October, but may extend if weather permits. Visit their website for more information, rates, and operating hours.
audioDescription: A long, paved walkway leads to a rectangular, one-story brown building, Skyland Stables.

title: Snead Farm Loop Trailhead
listingDescription: Dickey Ridge Visitor Center (Mile 5.1) | Hike through old apple orchards and farmlands to an historic barn on the former Snead homesite.

images.altText: An old, white barn sits under a canopy of green trees
images.title: Snead Family Barn

bodyText:
Discover the cultural history of Shenandoah National Park as you hike to the historic Snead family barn. Pets must be on a physical leash no longer than 6 feet at all times. Note that, while allowed on Snead Farm Loop Trail, pets are not allowed on the adjacent Fox Hollow Trail.

Distance: 3.7-mile circuit hike
Difficulty: Moderate (explanation of our hiking difficulty scale)
Hiking Time: 2 hours 30 minutes
Elevation Gain: 580 feet

Hike Description 

  1. From the trailhead located across Skyline Drive from Dickey Ridge Visitor Center (mile 5.1), go right onto Dickey Ridge Trail.
  2. Go left on Snead Farm Road, which will take you to Snead Barn. For a shorter, 0.7-mile round-trip hike, turn around here and return to your starting point.
  3. To continue on the loop hike, stay on the Snead Farm Loop Trail to its intersection with the Dickey Ridge Trail.
  4. Turn right and follow it back to your starting point.
audioDescription: The Fox Hollow Trailhead panel is a 36 by 54 inch color poster. On the upper left of the panel is a photograph of a single purple periwinkle blossom amid glossy green leaves. The text reads, "Home: Before this part of Virginia was called Shenandoah National Park, people lived here and called it home. This land is where they got their sustenance, made their living, raised their families, and buried their dead. You can still see evidence of former human habitation throughout the Park, including here in Fox Hollow. The daffodils and periwinkle you see are gone-wild descendants of plants nurtured by them; the cemetery, too, reminds us that they were here." The picture on the bottom left of the panel shows 3 tombstones from the Fox family cemetery. The stone in the center of the picture reads, "Gertrude Fox, Died June 22, 1904, Aged 21 Years". That stone has been broken near its base and is lying on an angle among the green ground cover. The text reads, "They Still Speak - There are more than 100 family cemeteries in Shenandoah. Some are still maintained by the descendants of those buried there and some are not. The cemeteries that are not as well maintained might surprise hikers who come across the weathered tombstones in the Park's backcountry. Whether or not they are kept up and taken care of, these cemeteries speak gently to us of the people who made their lives in the hollows and on the ridges of what is now Shenandoah National Park." The top right of the panel is a 20 by 20 inch topographic map of the hikes to Fox Hollow Trail and Snead Farm Loop. The Fox Hollow Trail is marked in yellow with a brown dashed line. The text reads, "Suggested Hikes: Hike #1: Fox Hollow Trail, 1.2 mile circuit, easiest, .75 hours hiking time, 310-foot elevation gain. Turn left onto Dickey Ridge Trail, then right onto Fox Hollow Trail. Stay on Fox Hollow Trail - past rock piles and the Fox family cemetery - back to the starting point." "Hike #2: Snead Farm Loop, (This hike is marked in purple with a dashed line.) 3.7 mile circuit, moderate, 2.5 hours hiking time, 580-foot elevation gain. Go right onto the Dickey Ridge Trail. Go left on the Snead Farm Road, which will take you to Snead Barn. Continue on the Snead Farm Loop Trail to its intersection with the Dickey Ridge Trail. Turn right and follow it back to your starting point." A red text box below the map gives important information that hikers need. The text reads, "Emergency 1-800-732-0911 (cell phone service is unreliable.) Before You Go! Pets are not allowed on Fox Hollow Trail. Where allowed, pets must be on a leash at all times. Be sure you are physically able to complete the hike you've chosen. Take plenty of water - at least a quart per hour Be sure you know your route. Free maps are available at entrance stations, visitors centers, and www.nps.gov/shen When you return from your hike, check for ticks. Be sure someone knows where you are and when to expect your return. Leave what you find. Artifacts are protected by law. Please respect family cemeteries."

title: South River Falls Observation Point Trailhead
listingDescription: South River Picnic Grounds (mile 62.7) | From the South River Picnic Grounds, this hike leads you through a verdant forest alive with a wide variety of plant and animal life to a stone-walled observation point overlooking an 83’ waterfall.

images.altText: A color photo showing a forest of green trees with a dirt trail underneath of them.
images.title: South River Falls Trail

bodyText:
From South River Picnic Grounds, this hike leads you through a verdant forest alive with a wide variety of plant and animal life to a stone-walled observation point overlooking an 83 foot waterfall. Be prepared for one stream crossing. Pets must be on a leash no longer than 6 feet at all times.

Distance: 2.6-mile round trip hike
Difficulty: Moderate (explanation of our hiking difficulty scale)
Hiking Time: 1 hour 15 minutes
Elevation Gain: 850 feet

Hike Description 

  1. Just below the South River Picnic Grounds comfort station (mile 62.7), take the blue-blazed South River Falls Trail.
  2. You’ll cross the Appalachian Trail, but stay on the South River Falls Trail to the stone-walled observation point. You can continue to the base of the falls from here if you wish, adding a steep and rocky 1.5-miles to your hike.
  3. Retrace your steps to return to your starting point.
audioDescription: The South River Falls Trailhead panel is a 36 by 54 inch color poster. On the upper left of the panel is a photograph taken from the forest floor up toward the high, green, canopy with the light of the sky peeking through occasionally. The text reads, "Safe Harbor: It's different in this hollow. As you descend from the ridge top to South River Falls, you'll notice how things change. Little by little you'll find yourself surrounded by tall, wide trees - tulip trees, sugar maples, and white ashes. If it's spring, you'll smell oink azalea. You might hear the clear whistle and metallic chip of the Louisiana waterthrush, and the "tsee-tsee-tsee-tsway" of the American redstart. You're hiking through a specific type of ecosystem: Appalachian Rich Cove Forest. Wet conditions and rich soils provide perfect habitat for the animals and plants that live here. The east-facing slopes get plenty of rain and protection from harsh winds. You can find this environment elsewhere in Shenandoah National Park, but you won't see it outside the Appalachian Mountains." The picture on the bottom left of the panel is a handsome Louisiana waterthrush showing the brown stripes on its white breast. The text reads, "What Thrives Here: Migratory birds favor the wet forest and closed canopy of South River Falls. They travel from as far as Central and South America to live here in the summer. The Louisiana waterthrush, pictured here, is the only bird in the Park that always chooses a streamside habitat like that at South River Falls. The American redstart - a type of warbler - and scarlet tanager also live in these woods. Black cohosh, wild geraniums, and maidenhair fern enjoy the cool, wet forest around South River Falls." The top right of the panel is a 20 by 20 inch topographic map of the hike to South River Falls. The text reads, "Suggested Hikes: Hike #1 - South River Falls Observation Point (This trail is marked in yellow with a brown dashed line.) 2.6-mile round trip, moderate, 1.75 hours hiking time, 850-foot elevation gain, one stream crossing. Take blue-blazed South River Falls Trail. Cross the Appalachian Trail, but stay on the South River Falls Trail to the stone-walled observation point. Retrace your steps to return." "Hike #2: South River Falls Loop (This trail is marked in purple with a brown dashed line.) 3.3 mile circuit , moderate, 2.25 hours hiking time, 910-foot elevation gain, one stream crossing. Take blue-blazed South River Falls Trail. Cross the Appalachian Trail (A.T.), but stay on the South River Falls Trail to the stone-walled falls observation point. Continue on South River Falls Trail to the trail post. Go left at the trail post; the trail is now blazed yellow. At the next trail post, go left. Ascend to the next intersection and trail post, where you will go left onto the white-blazed A.T. Continue south on the A.T. to the next intersection; go right on South River Falls Trail back to the starting point. A red text box below the map gives important information that hikers need. The text reads, "Emergency 1-800-732-0911 (cell phone service is unreliable.) Before You Go! Pets must be on a leash at all times. Be sure you are physically able to complete the hike you've chosen. Take plenty of water - at least a quart per hour Be sure you know your route. Free maps are available at entrance stations, visitors centers, and www.nps.gov/shen When you return from your hike, check for ticks. Stay on the trail and avoid trampling sensitive vegetation. Be sure someone knows where you are and when to expect your return. It's dangerous and potentially deadly to climb on the rocks near waterfalls. Filter or treat water from streams before drinking."

title: South River Falls Trailhead
listingDescription: South River Picnic Grounds Comfort Station (mile 62.7) | From the South River Picnic Grounds, this route is a circuit hike that takes you to an observation point overlooking an 83’ waterfall. A great hike for wildflower and bird enthusiasts, alike!

images.altText: A color photo showing a forest of green trees with a dirt trail underneath of them.
images.title: South River Falls Trail

bodyText:
From the South River Picnic Grounds, this route is a circuit hike that takes you to the base of a 83’ waterfall. A great hike for wildflower and bird enthusiasts, alike! This hike has one stream crossing. Pets must be on a physcial leash no longer than 6 feet at all times.

Distance: 3.3-mile circuit hike
Difficulty: Moderate (explanation of our hiking difficulty scale)
Hiking Time: 2 hour 15 minutes
Elevation Gain: 910 feet

Hike Description

  1. From the trailhead just below the South River Picnic Grounds Comfort Station (mile 62.7), take the blue-blazed South River Falls Trail.
  2. You'll cross the Appalachian Trail, but stay on the South River Falls Trail to the stone-walled observation point.
  3. From the observation point, continue on the South River Falls Trail to the trailpost.
  4. Go left onto the yellow-blazed South River Falls Road. 
  5. The trail joins the South River Fire Road.
  6. Continue on the fire road to its intersection with the Appalachian Trail.
  7. Turn left and follow the A.T. (white-blazed) to its intersection with the South River Falls Trail.
  8. Go right to return to your starting point.
audioDescription: The South River Falls Trailhead panel is a 36 by 54 inch color poster. On the upper left of the panel is a photograph taken from the forest floor up toward the high, green, canopy with the light of the sky peeking through occasionally. The text reads, "Safe Harbor: It's different in this hollow. As you descend from the ridge top to South River Falls, you'll notice how things change. Little by little you'll find yourself surrounded by tall, wide trees - tulip trees, sugar maples, and white ashes. If it's spring, you'll smell oink azalea. You might hear the clear whistle and metallic chip of the Louisiana waterthrush, and the "tsee-tsee-tsee-tsway" of the American redstart. You're hiking through a specific type of ecosystem: Appalachian Rich Cove Forest. Wet conditions and rich soils provide perfect habitat for the animals and plants that live here. The east-facing slopes get plenty of rain and protection from harsh winds. You can find this environment elsewhere in Shenandoah National Park, but you won't see it outside the Appalachian Mountains." The picture on the bottom left of the panel is a handsome Louisiana waterthrush showing the brown stripes on its white breast. The text reads, "What Thrives Here: Migratory birds favor the wet forest and closed canopy of South River Falls. They travel from as far as Central and South America to live here in the summer. The Louisiana waterthrush, pictured here, is the only bird in the Park that always chooses a streamside habitat like that at South River Falls. The American redstart - a type of warbler - and scarlet tanager also live in these woods. Black cohosh, wild geraniums, and maidenhair fern enjoy the cool, wet forest around South River Falls." The top right of the panel is a 20 by 20 inch topographic map of the hike to South River Falls. The text reads, "Suggested Hikes: Hike #1 - South River Falls Observation Point (This trail is marked in yellow with a brown dashed line.) 2.6-mile round trip, moderate, 1.75 hours hiking time, 850-foot elevation gain, one stream crossing. Take blue-blazed South River Falls Trail. Cross the Appalachian Trail, but stay on the South River Falls Trail to the stone-walled observation point. Retrace your steps to return." "Hike #2: South River Falls Loop (This trail is marked in purple with a brown dashed line.) 3.3 mile circuit , moderate, 2.25 hours hiking time, 910-foot elevation gain, one stream crossing. Take blue-blazed South River Falls Trail. Cross the Appalachian Trail (A.T.), but stay on the South River Falls Trail to the stone-walled falls observation point. Continue on South River Falls Trail to the trail post. Go left at the trail post; the trail is now blazed yellow. At the next trail post, go left. Ascend to the next intersection and trail post, where you will go left onto the white-blazed A.T. Continue south on the A.T. to the next intersection; go right on South River Falls Trail back to the starting point. A red text box below the map gives important information that hikers need. The text reads, "Emergency 1-800-732-0911 (cell phone service is unreliable.) Before You Go! Pets must be on a leash at all times. Be sure you are physically able to complete the hike you've chosen. Take plenty of water - at least a quart per hour Be sure you know your route. Free maps are available at entrance stations, visitors centers, and www.nps.gov/shen When you return from your hike, check for ticks. Stay on the trail and avoid trampling sensitive vegetation. Be sure someone knows where you are and when to expect your return. It's dangerous and potentially deadly to climb on the rocks near waterfalls. Filter or treat water from streams before drinking."

title: South River Overlook
listingDescription: Facing southeast from an elevation of 2,950 ft (899 m), the view from South River Overlook spans across a field and provides a small window to see Saddleback Mountain in the distance. During late summer the field surrounding this overlook can burst with colorful wildflowers.

images.altText: A field of yellow flowers with a trees and a mountain in the background.
images.title: South River Overlook
images.caption: What's the view from South River Overlook?

bodyText: Facing southeast from an elevation of 2,950 ft (899 m), the view from South River Overlook spans across a field and provides a small window to see Saddleback Mountain in the distance. During late summer the field surrounding this overlook can burst with colorful wildflowers.
audioDescription: This overlook faces southeast. There is an open field stretching to a line of trees in the distance. Beyond the trees there is an opening with the peak of Saddleback Mountain barely visible. A small section of the Piedmont stretches out in the horizon.

title: South River Picnic Grounds
listingDescription: The South River Picnic Grounds is open year round. There are picnic tables, grates for cooking, restrooms, and water from spring to fall. During winter the water in the picnic grounds is shut off, but the vault toilets will remain open.

images.altText: A picnic table on a concrete platform with a rectangular brown building in the background.
images.title: South River Picnic Ground
images.caption: Enjoy a picnic at South River Picnic Ground.

bodyText: The South River Picnic Grounds is open year round. There are picnic tables, grates for cooking, restrooms, and water from spring to fall. During winter the water in the picnic grounds is shut off, but the vault toilets will remain open.
audioDescription: The entrance to South River Picnic Ground is on the southwest side of the road. The road loops through the picnic grounds with the picnic facilities located in the interior of the circle.

title: Spitler Knoll Overlook
listingDescription: Stand atop Spitler Knoll Overlook and imagine what it would be like to watch over livestock on the mountain. Looking west-northwest and sitting at an elevation of 3,285 ft (1,001 m) Spitler Knoll Overlook was once the location of Spitler Ranch. Prior to the establishment of Shenandoah National Park, some mountain areas were used to graze cattle and other livestock, while the valley below produced more crops.

images.altText: View atop field looking down to valley with hills in the distance.
images.title: Spitler Knoll Overlook
images.caption: What's the view from Spitler Knoll Overlook?

bodyText: Stand atop Spitler Knoll Overlook and imagine what it would be like to watch over livestock on the mountain. Looking west-northwest and sitting at an elevation of 3,285 ft (1,001 m) Spitler Knoll Overlook was once the location of Spitler Ranch. Prior to the establishment of Shenandoah National Park, some mountain areas were used to graze cattle and other livestock, while the valley below produced more crops.
audioDescription: This overlook faces west-northwest. There is a meadow that stretches over the foreground that descends to the forest and hills below. From the left there are ridges of the mountains descending into the valley. Included in these ridges are Dovel Mountain, Dog Slaughter Ridge, and Roundhead Ridge. On the right in the distance is the town of Stanley in the Shenandoah Valley. Beyond the valley is Massanutten Mountain at the horizon.

title: Stony Man Trailhead
listingDescription: Stony Man Parking Area (Mile 41.7) | Pets are not allowed on this hike. This enjoyable hike brings you to an outstanding view of the Shenandoah Valley, Massanutten Mountain, and beyond.

images.altText: A color photograph of people on the summit of Stony Man, some joyously facing the camera.
images.title: Stony Man Summit

bodyText:
Pets are not allowed on this hike. This enjoyable hike brings you to an outstanding view of the Shenandoah Valley, Massanutten Mountain, and beyond. 

Distance: 1.6-mile round trip hike
Difficulty: Easiest (hiking difficulty scale)
Hiking Time: 1 hours
Elevation Gain: 340 feet

Hike Description 

  1. From the Stony Man Parking Area (mile 41.7), take the Appalachian Trail (A.T.) to the trail post.
  2. Continue on the blue-blazed Stony Man Trail to the viewpoint.
  3. Then continue on the Stony Man Trail to its intersection with the A.T. and retrace your steps to your starting point.
audioDescription: The Stony Man Trailhead panel is a 36 by 54 inch color poster. On the upper left of the panel is a photograph of a peregrine falcon sitting on a dead tree branch. The text reads, "Allow Me to (Re)Introduce Myself - The Park's resource protection mission makes it a superb place to reintroduce wildlife. In 1989 Shenandoah first tried to bring endangered peregrine falcons-once permanent residents-back to this part of the Appalachians. Young birds were released from several spots, in hopes that some would return to the Park to live. So you might find this once-endangered bird of prey soaring over Stony Man!" The photograph on the bottom left of the panel is a view of the Passamaquoddy Trail showing a large rock outcropping, the lush mountain foliage, and a portion of the Valley to the west. The text reads, "Abounding in Pollock' - Passamaquoddy Trail meanders under Stony Man Cliffs, past alluring geology and, in winter, amazing drapery-like ice formations. George Pollock had the trail built in 1932 and so named it because, he said, Passamaquoddy' is a Maine Indian word for abounding in Pollock' (a kind of fish)-and more or less after himself, since it's not likely there were any fish on this streamless trail!" The top right of the panel is a 20 by 20 inch topographic map of the hike to Stony Man. The trail is marked in yellow with a brown dashed line. The text reads, "Suggested Hikes: Hike #1: Stony Man Trail - 1.6-mile lariat, easiest, 1 hour hiking time, 340-foot elevation gain. Pets are not allowed on this trail. Take the blue- and white-blazed Stony Man Trail/Appalachian Trail (A.T.). At the trail post continue onto the blue-blazed Stony Man Trail to the viewpoint. To continue the loop, take the blue-blazed Stony Man Trail back to the junction with the A.T., and follow the A.T. back to the starting point. At the viewpoint, you'll overlook the Shenandoah Valley, the town of Luray, and the Massanutten and Allegheny Mountains beyond." "Hike #2: Passamaquoddy Loop - (This trail is marked in purple with a dashed line.) 3.5-mile circuit, moderate, 2-½ hours hiking time, 770-foot elevation gain. Walk to the other end of Stony Man parking. Look for the trail post; go straight on the yellow-blazed Furnace Spring Horse Trail. At the next trail post, go right onto the blue-blazed Passamaquoddy Trail. At the next trail post, go right onto the Appalachian Trail (A.T.) south to your starting point at Stony Man parking." A red text box below the map gives important information that hikers need. The text reads, "Emergency 1-800-732-0911 (cell phone service is unreliable.) Before You Go! - Pets are not allowed on Stony Man Trail. Where allowed, pets must be on a leash at all times. - Be sure you are physically able to complete the hike you've chosen. - Take plenty of water-at least a quart per hour. - Be sure you know your route. Free maps are available at entrance stations, visitor centers, and www.nps.gov/shen - When you return from your hike, check for ticks. - Stay on the trail and avoid trampling sensitive vegetation. - Be sure someone knows where you are and when to expect your return.

title: Story of the Forest Trailhead
listingDescription: Byrd Visitor Center (mile 51) | Pets are not allowed on this hike. An easier stroll through the woods that passes next to the Big Meadows Air Quality Station, an important place for scientists and researchers to learn about air quality in Shenandoah.

images.altText: A wooden sign that reads, “Story of the Forest” and has an arrow pointing to the right.
images.title: Story of the Forest Trail

bodyText:
Pets are not allowed on this hike. An easier stroll through the woods that passes next to the Big Meadows Air Quality Station, an important place for scientists and researchers to learn about air quality in Shenandoah.

Distance: 1.8-mile round trip hike
Difficulty: Easiest (explanation of our hiking difficulty scale)
Hiking Time: 1 hours 30 minutes
Elevation Gain: 290 feet

Hike Description 

  1. From Byrd Visitor Center (mile 51), follow the sidewalk to the trailhead and take the trail right. 
  2. After crossing the bridge, turn left and follow the trail to its intersection with a paved walkway near the campground office.
  3. Turn left and follow the walkway back to your starting point.
audioDescription: A brown wooden sign that reads "Story of the Forest Trail" with an arrow pointing right, leading to a path through the forest. Along the trail there is an interpretive sign near the location of an air quality monitoring station. The Air quality station is located through the woods in a locked enclosure. Within the enclosure are many scientific instruments for collecting rain and air samples. The sign is a 24 by 36 inch color graphic on a dark metal frame angled towards the viewer. The graphic has the title "Getting to know the air you breathe." Above the title is the quote, "Unless someone like you cares a whole awful lot, nothing is going to get better. It's not." -The Lorax, Dr. Seuss. Below the title is the text, "Every living thing is affected by what's in the air. To protect and improve air quality, it's vital to know what's in the air, how it got there, and how it affects plants, animals, and humans. The Big Meadows air quality station does exactly that. This equipment collects data on weather, visibility, ozone levels, and pollutants in the air. Scientists across the nation use the data to advise protection agencies and lawmakers about regulations that will help reduce pollution and protect the air we breathe. This monitoring station has been providing data for 30 years, giving scientists some of the most valuable information available about trends in air quality over time. The data shows that when strong regulations are in place, the quality of air improves. Cleaner air means cleaner water, healthier lives for plants, animals, and humans, and more beautiful views from the peaks and overlooks of Shenandoah. Learn more about air quality monitoring and what you can do at Byrd Visitor Center, or visit out website: www.nps.gov/shen." To the right of the text is a large color photograph with three color photographs below it. The large image shows a view over mountains and out to a valley in three different days with decreasing visibility and haze over the valley. The text below this image reads, "Spectacular views in Shenandoah's overlooks and mountains draw visitors from around the world. Protecting the views is part of the responsibility of being a national park. Scientists estimate that without pollution you could see 115 miles. But these days, increased haze limits your view to just 23 miles on average. Clear days are a rare treat, with moderate days being the norm. A string of hot, humid days can produce poor visibility that obscures even the closest range. Below, the first image is a photograph of a single green leaf with small spots on it. A caption reads, "Among national parks, Shenandoah experiences some of the highest ground-level ozone. One of the first signs of damage appears as brown spots on milkweed leaves." The second image is a photograph of a waterfall cascading over rocks and into the stream below with the caption, "Acid rain pollutes our streams and endangers fragile aquatic life. What appear to be clear mountain streams can be lethal to the acid-sensitive fish that live here." The third image is a close up photograph of one of the scientific instruments at the air quality station. The caption reads, "Each piece of equipment collects information that helps scientists understand and fight for what's needed to protect Shenandoah's vital resources. You can help!" At the bottom of the poster is the note, "Funded in part by the Shenandoah National Park Trust."

title: Sugarloaf Loop Trailhead
listingDescription: Piney River Parking Area (mile 22) | Follow the trail to a viewpoint. In the early summer, the showy white flowers of mountain laurel bloom in abundance here.

images.altText: A color photograph with the sun illuminating a snowy trail with a concrete trailpost on the left.
images.title: Piney River Trailhead in Winter

bodyText:
Sugarloaf Loop leads to a scenic viewpoint. In the early summer, the showy white flowers of mountain laurel bloom in abundance here. Pets must be on a physical leash no longer than 6 feet at all times.

Distance: 5.0-mile circuit hike
Difficulty: Moderate (explanation of our hiking difficulty scale)
Hiking Time: 7 hours
Elevation Gain: 1,120 feet

Hike Description

  1. From the trailhead at the Piney River Parking Area (mile 22), take the Piney Branch Upper Trail to its intersection with the Pole Bridge Link Trail.
  2. Go left on the Pole Bridge Link Trail.
  3. Turn left onto Sugarloaf Trail. This will bring you out near Skyline Drive, above Hogback Overlook.
  4. Turn left to take the Appalachian Trail (white-blazed) back to your starting point.
audioDescription: The Piney River Trailhead panel is a 36 by 54-inch color poster. On the upper left of the panel is a black and white photograph of one of the original Civilian Conservation Corps buildings. The foreground is a 1930s era pick-up truck. The text reads, "Camp Red Bird - The Piney River area was home to NP-12, "Camp Red Bird," of the Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC), a work-relief program during the Great Depression. From 1935 to 1942, the camp housed hundreds of young men who learned skills, earned much-needed money, and helped build Shenandoah National Park. The building to your right is one of the few remaining original CCC buildings." The photograph on the bottom left is a black and white historic picture of Range View Cabin with a man sitting on a stump just beyond the overhang of the shelter. The text reads, "Range View Cabin - Just down the trail is Range View Cabin, one of six cabins operated by the Potomac Appalachian Trail Club (PATC). With the exception of the stonework, PATC volunteers built the cabin in 1932. The club hired local stonemason, Charlie Sisk, whose skills were also frequently used at Skyland." The top right of the panel is a 20 by 20-inch topographic map of the hikes at Piney River. The trail to Range View Cabin is marked in yellow with a brown dashed line. The text reads, "Suggested Hikes: Hike #1: Range View Cabin - 1.8-mile round trip, easiest, 1-¼ hours hiking time, 150-foot elevation gain. Follow the Piney Branch Trail to your left. At the junction with the Appalachian Trail (A.T.) turn right to head south. Turn left onto the Range View Service Road and follow this road to the cabin. Retrace your steps to return to the parking lot." "Hike #2 - Sugarloaf Loop - (This trail is marked in purple with a dashed line.) 4.9-mile circuit, moderate, 3-½ hours hiking time, 956-foot elevation gain. Follow the Piney Branch Trail to your left. At the junction with the Appalachian Trail (A.T.) stay left to follow the Piney Branch Trail for another 1.5 miles. Turn left onto the Pole Bridge Link Trail and follow this trail for .4 miles to the Sugarloaf Trail. Turn left onto the Sugarloaf Trail and continue for 1.4 miles to the intersection with the A.T. Make a left to head south on the A.T. for 1.2 miles to the intersection with the Piney River Branch Trail. Turn right to return to this parking area." "Exploring Further. This trailhead also leads to a network of many trails and former road traces. If you are not familiar with the area, you should get a map. See the opposite side of this kiosk for a detailed map of the Mathews Arm and Overall Run Falls area." A red text box below the map gives important information that hikers need. The text reads, "Emergency 1-800-732-0911 (cell phone service is unreliable.) Before You Go! Be sure you are physically able to complete the hike you've chosen. Be sure you know your route. Free maps are available at Entrance Stations, Visitor Centers, and www.nps.gov/shen. Take plenty of water-at least a quart per hour. Pets must be on a leash no longer than six feet. When you return from your hike, check for ticks. Be sure someone knows where you are and when to expect your return."

title: Swift Run Entrance
listingDescription: Entering the park here at Swift Run entrance gives you an opportunity to travel north or south along Skyline Drive and experience Shenandoah National Park. You'll notice mile posts as you travel. Use these as references to find everything from dining and lodging to trails and visitor centers. Travel north and you will reach the Big Meadows area with a scenic meadow, Byrd Visitor Center, and plenty of options for hiking, lodging, and dining. Travel south and you will ride thro

images.altText: A color photograph of an entrance station for vehicles.
images.title: Swift Run Entrance Station
images.caption: Swift Run Entrance Station

bodyText: Entering the park here at Swift Run entrance gives you an opportunity to travel north or south along Skyline Drive and experience Shenandoah National Park. You'll notice mile posts as you travel. Use these as references to find everything from dining and lodging to trails and visitor centers. Travel north and you will reach the Big Meadows area with a scenic meadow, Byrd Visitor Center, and plenty of options for hiking, lodging, and dining. Travel south and you will ride through a quieter section of Shenandoah National Park with beautiful overlooks and trails.
audioDescription: Leading to the entrance station the road parts into two lanes, each with a booth where there is a ranger to give information and where you will purchase a park pass. There is a roof connecting the booths above with posted information about fees.

title: Swift Run Entrance Backcountry Registration
listingDescription: THE BACKCOUNTRY IS CLOSED TO OVERNIGHT USE AT THIS TIME. Backcountry Camping is a wilder, more primitive experience than staying in a campground and requires important planning and appropriate equipment. Backcountry campers are required to have a permit. Register for a backcountry camping permit here. You must register 1 hour before sunset. For more information visit nps.gov/shen/planyourvisit/campbc.htm

Backcountry campers are required to have a permit. Register for a backcountry camping permit here. You must register 1 hour before sunset. title: Swift Run Overlook
listingDescription: Facing north from an elevation of 2,715 ft (827 m) the view from Swift Run looks out to the Shenandoah Valley and Massanutten Mountain on the horizon. The view here is overgrown for most of the year. There is an orientation shelter at this overlook with information to help you during your visit.

images.altText: View with brush in foreground looking down on valley in distance.
images.title: Swift Run Overlook
images.caption: What's the view from Swift Run Overlook?

bodyText: Facing north from an elevation of 2,715 ft (827 m) the view from Swift Run looks out to the Shenandoah Valley and Massanutten Mountain on the horizon. The view here is overgrown for most of the year. There is an orientation shelter at this overlook with information to help you during your visit.
audioDescription: This overlook faces north. There is lush vegetation growing most of the year in front of the Shenandoah Valley below. The long ridge of Massanutten is Mountain spans across the horizon.There is an orientation kiosk at this overlook:The orientation shelter is a small roof supported by six brown beams. The beams are frames for six upright 36 inch by 54 inch posters in glass enclosures.Panel 1. Bulletin BoardBulletin boards contain seasonal information. Panel 2. Park MapThis graphic is divided into two columns, the left has text and images and the right has a map. On the right column, title text reads, "Welcome to Shenandoah National Park." Below the title is a color photograph of a man standing atop a rock outcrop and looking to the mountains in the distance on a sunny day. Layered on the image is the quote " â€˜...for the recreation and the re-creation they shall find here." -President Franklin Roosevelt, Shenandoah's Dedication." Text below the image reads, "Shenandoah National Park was established in 1935 to bring the western national park experience to the urban east. Here, within a few hours' drive of millions, you will find "recreation and re-creation." Experience the wonder of nature, the power of shared heritage, and the inspiration that is the future of our national parks." Below there is the subheading "Shenandoah Highlights," and the text "- Skyline Drive - 105 miles of beauty. Please observe the 35 mph speed limit to see it all safely. - 75 Overlooks - Spectacular views of the Shenandoah Valley and Virginia Piedmont. - 500 Miles of Trails - Beautiful waterfalls, quiet forests, and mountain summits are just a hike away. - Visitor Centers - Films, exhibits, and Ranger-led walks and talks tell Shenandoah's stories."The map to the right shows the boundaries of, driving route through, and highlights in Shenandoah National Park. The map area is 30 miles wide by 150 miles long. Shenandoah National Park is shaded green. Highlights include entrance stations, visitor centers, campgrounds, lodging, restrooms, food services, and trailheads. At the bottom of the map is the park emergency number: (800) 732-0911. At the top and bottom of the graphic are black bars. The black bar at the top has the text, "Shenandoah National Park," to the left, and "National Park Service, U.S. Department of the Interior," on the right with the National Park Service arrowhead logo to the far right. The lower black bar has the Leave No Trace logo on the left with the text "Leave No Trace Principe #6, Respect Wildlife," and on the right the text "www.nps.gov/shen." Panel 3. Spring/SummerThe graphic is split into two horizontal sections with text and graphics in rectangles. The top section has the title, "Spring" with the subtitle "Renewal." The rectangle is split vertically. The left side contains three color photographs with text descriptions. The first image is white flowers with four petals labeled "Flowering Dogwood," and the accompanying text, "Dogwood blossoms are well-known messengers of spring, but this understory tree has other jobs, too - like providing food and shelter." The second image shows a mother deer and two fawns walking in high grasses labeled "White-tailed Deer" with the accompanying text "White-tailed deer hide their fawns under the dogwood's low-hanging branches and feed on its tender shoots, buds, and later, berries." The third image shows a dark blue bird with black tail feathers labeled "Indigo Bunting," and the accompanying text "Indigo buntings often build their nests in dogwood trees and line them with deer hair. Birds love the berries' high fat content, a great trade-off for the dogwood, since its seeds are spread by those who eat them, ensuring the dogwood's renewal." The right side of the top panel contains the text, "From the moment the first plant pushes up through the forest floor beginning its annual growth cycle, spring is renewal. Hungry black bears come out of their dens with winter-born cubs. Migratory birds return, butterflies emerge, and wildflowers herald the season. Every life, new and old, depends on another." There are nine color photographs under this text arranged in a 3 by 3 square. From the top left they are: a bush with clumps of white flowers labeled "Mountain Laurel," a butterfly with white and yellow markings and blue tips on the wings labeled "Eastern Tiger Swallowtail," round mounds of fungus growing out of the forest floor labeled "Morel Mushrooms" a small curled up salamander labeled "Red-backed Salamander," a bird with yellow, black, and white markings labeled "Chestnut-sided Warbler," a single white flower with three petals and large green leaves labeled "Large-flowered Trillium," a light brown toad on the ground labeled "Spring Pepper," a set of three yellow and red bell shaped flowers labeled "Wild Columbine," and a bird with a white chest and tan head and wings labeled "Red-eyed Vineo." The bottom section has the title "Summer" and the subtitle "Abundance."

title: Tanners Ridge Overlook
listingDescription: Looking northwest from an elevation of 3,465 ft (1,056 m) the view from Tanners Ridge Overlook moves across a field and out to the Shenandoah Valley below. The town of Stanley below, is located in the center of Page County. Stanley began when the railroad was built in the 1880s. The new town grew at an intersection of two railroad lines. In 1900 the town was officially incorporated as Stanley.

images.altText: View of field with trees in distance and hills at horizon.
images.title: Tanners Ridge Overlook
images.caption: What's the view from Tanners Ridge Overlook?

bodyText: Looking northwest from an elevation of 3,465 ft (1,056 m) the view from Tanners Ridge Overlook moves across a field and out to the Shenandoah Valley below. The town of Stanley below, is located in the center of Page County. Stanley began when the railroad was built in the 1880s. The new town grew at an intersection of two railroad lines. In 1900 the town was officially incorporated as Stanley.
audioDescription: This overlook faces northwest. There is a field that extends to a line of trees. Beyond the trees is the Shenandoah Valley. Roundhead Ridge is at the foothill of the mountains. The town of Stanley is in the valley. Along the horizon is the long ridge of Massanutten Mountain.

title: The Oaks Overlook
listingDescription: Facing west from an elevation of 3,125 ft (952 m), The Oaks Overlook view is a narrow window into the Shenandoah Valley below. The man-made landscape of the Shenandoah Valley provides a stark contrast from the wilderness in Shenandoah National Park. For hundreds of years American Indians cultivated the land and grew corn, squash, and beans. Later European settlers established permanent farms. While agriculture expanded in the valley, the mountains provided land for smaller ho

images.altText: View over vegetation-covered slope with trees and valley in distance.
images.title: The Oaks Overlook
images.caption: What's the view from The Oaks Overlook?

bodyText:
Facing west from an elevation of 3,125 ft (952 m), The Oaks Overlook view is a narrow window into the Shenandoah Valley below. The man-made landscape of the Shenandoah Valley provides a stark contrast from the wilderness in Shenandoah National Park. For hundreds of years American Indians cultivated the land and grew corn, squash, and beans. Later European settlers established permanent farms. While agriculture expanded in the valley, the mountains provided land for smaller homesteads and livestock grazing. With the establishment of the Park, those families that resided in the mountains were forced out of their homes in favor of cultivating the wild nature of the mountains.

Maintenance of this view funded by Rockingham County Tourism through the Shenandoah National Park Trust Adopt an Overlook program.
audioDescription: This overlook faces west. An open field on a slope descends to a line of trees. Beyond the trees is the Shenandoah Valley in the distance with the long ridge of Massanutten Mountain spans across the horizon.

title: The Point Overlook
listingDescription: Looking west-northwest from an elevation of 3,235 ft (986 m), at The Point Overlook you can view the Blue Ridge Mountains, and on a clear day, out to the Shenandoah Valley. Straight ahead lies Powell Mountain. Further back to the left is Grindstone Mountain. To the left of Grindstone Mountain is Green Mountain. The town of Elkton in the Shenandoah Valley is to the left of Green Mountain, but may or may not be visible depending on the air quality in the valley below. There is

images.altText: A view over brush out to mountains in the distance.
images.title: The Point Overlook
images.caption: What's the view from The Point Overlook?

bodyText: Looking west-northwest from an elevation of 3,235 ft (986 m), at The Point Overlook you can view the Blue Ridge Mountains, and on a clear day, out to the Shenandoah Valley. Straight ahead lies Powell Mountain. Further back to the left is Grindstone Mountain. To the left of Grindstone Mountain is Green Mountain. The town of Elkton in the Shenandoah Valley is to the left of Green Mountain, but may or may not be visible depending on the air quality in the valley below. There is a short but slightly steep trail that leads out to a viewpoint, from which the overlook got its name.
audioDescription: This overlook faces west-northwest. There is vegetation in the foreground leading to a line of trees. The trees descend into rolling hills. From the right Is Powell Mountain, Grindstone Mountain, and Green Mountain. Towards the left the mountain drops into the valley where the town of Elkton is. There is an interpretive sign at this overlook. The Point Overlook interpretive sign is a 36 by 24 inch color graphic panel on a dark metal frame angled towards the viewer. The title text reads, "Pleasure and Joy." Under the title is the quote, " Now shall I walk or shall I ride? Ride, Pleasure said. Walk, Joy replied.' W.H. Davies." The body text reads, "Shenandoah National Park and Skyline Drive are the perfect combination of pleasure and joy. Chances are you took a pleasure ride today and found yourself here. You can easily add a bit of joy to your day right here at The Point Overlook. Notice the break in the stone wall and the steps leading to a path. The path takes you just beyond the trees you see ahead to a large boulder just perfect for sitting and contemplating the horizon. It's a beautiful view! Along with the pleasure of a leisurely ride on Skyline drive, Shenandoah's many gifts include numerous "leg stretcher" trails-short walks to beautiful vistas or cool streams. Ask for recommendations at a visitor center and add a little joy to your pleasure." Behind the text is a photograph of a man sitting atop a rock outcrop looking over the landscape to the mountains beyond. A black bar on the top of the graphic reads "Shenandoah National Park" on the left and on the right is the National Park Service Arrowhead symbol with the text "National Park Service/U.S. Department of the Interior"

title: Thornton Gap
listingDescription: Thornton Gap was one many mountain passes used to access the Shenandoah Valley by both Confederate and Union troops during the American Civil War. Neither side controlled it for very long and its scattered inhabitants were left largely undisturbed by the conflict raging in the valleys below.

images.altText: Photo of Thornton Gap at sunset
images.title: Photo of Thornton Gap at sunset
images.caption: Thornton Gap at sunset

bodyText:
Thornton Gap was named for Francis Thornton (1711-April 14, 1749), owner of the land to the east and the "F.T. Valley." In 1740, he built a mansion in the Piedmont region near Nethers in Rappahannock County. The privately-owned Thornton's Gap Turnpike Company was formed to build a road over the mountains at Thornton's Gap. The toll road opened in 1806.

During the Civil War, the Great Valley of Virginia was known as the "breadbasket of the Confederacy" and so was the scene of intensive military action and much destruction. But the Blue Ridge Mountains witnessed only limited military actions and few depredations as the contending armies merely passed through on their way to larger confrontations.

Thornton was one of many passageways that led across the Blue Ridge. Two others were the Gordonsville Turnpike that crossed the Blue Ridge at Fishers Gap and Swift Run Gap Turnpike that crossed at Swift Run Gap. But when Skyline Drive was completed in the 1930s, the National Park Service chose to limit vehicular access to the mountaintop and closed the many roads that crossed the ridge. Today, many of these historic routes are maintained as fire roads or provide limited access for administrative purposes.

Prior to the building of Skyline Drive by the federal Works Progress Administration (WPA) during the Great Depression, the lost town of Beahm was located at Thornton Gap.

quickFacts.value: National Park, National Register of Historic Places

title: Thornton Gap Entrance
listingDescription: Entering the park here at Thornton Gap entrance gives you an opportunity to travel north or south along Skyline Drive and experience Shenandoah National Park. You'll notice mile posts on the west side of the road as you travel. Use these as references to find everything from dining and lodging to trails and visitor centers. Travel south and you will reach the Big Meadows area with a scenic meadow, Byrd Visitor Center, and plenty of options for hiking, lodging, and dining. Tra

images.altText: Wooden routed sign with white letters: Thornton Gap Entrance
images.title: Thornton Gap Entrance Station

bodyText: Entering the park here at Thornton Gap entrance gives you an opportunity to travel north or south along Skyline Drive and experience Shenandoah National Park. You'll notice mile posts on the west side of the road as you travel. Use these as references to find everything from dining and lodging to trails and visitor centers. Travel south and you will reach the Big Meadows area with a scenic meadow, Byrd Visitor Center, and plenty of options for hiking, lodging, and dining. Travel north and you will ride along Skyline Drive with ample hiking opportunities.
audioDescription: Leading to the entrance station the road parts into three lanes. The far left lane is for employees. the two lanes on the right each have a booth where there is a ranger to give information and where you will purchase a park pass. There is a roof connecting the booths above with posted information about fees.

title: Thornton Gap Entrance Backcountry Registration
listingDescription: Backcountry Camping is a wilder, more primitive experience and requires important pre-planning and appropriate equipment. Backcountry campers are required to have a permit. Register for a backcountry camping permit here. You must register 1 hour before sunset. For more information: https://www.nps.gov/shen/planyourvisit/campbc.htm

images.title: Backcountry Registration - Thornton Gap
images.caption: Register for a required backcountry camping permit here.

bodyText: Backcountry Camping is a wilder, more primitive experience and requires important pre-planning and appropriate equipment. Backcountry campers are required to have a permit. Register for a backcountry camping permit here. You must register 1 hour before sunset. For more information: https://www.nps.gov/shen/planyourvisit/campbc.htm
