title: Thornton Hollow Overlook
listingDescription: Looking east from an elevation of 2,460 ft (749 m) the view from Thornton Hollow Overlook provides a window into Thornton Hollow and an expansive view of mountains in the distance. Mount Marshall is visible from the left, while Oventop Mountain is visible from the right.

images.altText: View over field past trees with hills in the distance.
images.title: Thornton Hollow Overlook
images.caption: What's the view from Thornton Hollow Overlook?

bodyText: Looking east from an elevation of 2,460 ft (749 m) the view from Thornton Hollow Overlook provides a window into Thornton Hollow and an expansive view of mountains in the distance. Mount Marshall is visible from the left, while Oventop Mountain is visible from the right.
audioDescription: This overlook faces east across a field to a line of trees. Above the trees are mountains in the distance. From the left the mountains visible are North Marshall, The Peak, Fork Mountain, and Oventop Mountain. Straight ahead, when two hills create a v-shape is Thornton Hollow. There is an interpretive sign at this overlook. The Thornton Hollow Overlook interpretive sign is a 36 by 24 inch color graphic panel on a dark metal frame angled towards the viewer. This graphic is split horizontally in two. The upper portion displays the title text, "The Many Moods of an Overlook," with the quote below, " â€˜No man ever steps in the same river twice, for it's not the same river and he's not the same man.' Heraclitus of Ephesus, Greek philosopher." Behind this text is an image from an overlook of the sun rising over the mountains in the distance. The rays of the sun cover the landscape with warm fall colors. The lower portion of the graphic is layered on a warm gray transparent background. The body text reads, "Changes in seasons, time of day, light, weather, and temperature - all of these changes and more affect what you see when you gaze out from any viewpoint in Shenandoah. You could stand in the exact same spot at different times of the year or at different times of day and never see the same thing twice. It's similar to how colored glass beads inside a kaleidoscope can never land in precisely the same arrangement twice; a view can never repeat itself because there will never again be the same combination of sunlight, humidity, temperature, precipitation, or fog there is in the one moment you stand here and take your picture, mental or real, of the landscape below." To the right of the text is a collage of six color photographs with thin white borders of the same overlook at different times of year and times of day. From the upper left is, a spring day with color staring to sprout on a tree in the foreground and yellow flowers popping up, a winter day with some snow on the ground and bare trees, a sunrise with fog forming an ocean on the mountains, a lush summer day with green everywhere, and lower, a sunset in winter with a deed red sun and dark mountains, and finally a fall sunrise with a pale colored sky and neutral autumn colors in the mountains. To the side of these images is the caption, "One of the main reasons for creating Shenandoah National Park and Skyline Drive was so that you, the visitor, could take in scenic views and marvel at the landscapes spread out below you. Skyline Drive has nearly 70 overlooks and it leads to starting-off points for hikes to peaks and summits, all of which offer dramatic vistas." A black bar on the top of the graphic reads "Shenandoah National Park" on the left and on the right is the National Park Service Arrowhead symbol with the text "National Park Service/U.S. Department of the Interior"

title: Thorofare Mountain Overlook
listingDescription: Looking east from 3,595 ft (1,095 m) Thorofare Mountain Overlook is the highest overlook in the park. Straight ahead is Thorofare Mountain. To the left of Thorofare Mountain in the distance is Hazel Mountain, with Pinnacle Ridge further left and a little closer. The slope in the distance to the right is Old Rag Mountain.

images.altText: A wide view of a field descending to mountains in the distance.
images.title: Thorofare Mountain Overlook
images.caption: What's the view from Thorofare Mountain Overlook?

bodyText: Looking east from 3,595 ft (1,095 m) Thorofare Mountain Overlook is the highest overlook in the park. Straight ahead is Thorofare Mountain. To the left of Thorofare Mountain in the distance is Hazel Mountain, with Pinnacle Ridge further left and a little closer. The slope in the distance to the right is Old Rag Mountain.
audioDescription: This overlook faces east. There is a meadow that stretches out then descends into the hills beyond. Straight ahead is the gently doming peak of Thorofare Mountain. To the left of Thorofare Mountain is Hazel Mountain in the distance and Pinnacle Ridge a little closer and descending toward the center. To the right of Thorofare Mountain is Old Rag in the distance an the smaller Robertson Mountain a little closer.

title: Timber Hollow Overlook
listingDescription: Facing west at an elevation of 3,360 ft (1,024 m), Timber Hollow Overlooks sits atop Timber Hollow. On either side of Timber Hollow are ridges that descend to the valley. The town of Ida is situated right beyond where the ridge of Nakedtop Mountain descends into the valley. Ida was one of the relocation settlements for families who lived within the park boundary during the establishment of Shenandoah in the 1930s.

images.altText: View from overlook with trail and valley in the distance.
images.title: Timber Hollow Overlook
images.caption: What's the view from Timber Hollow Overlook?

bodyText: Facing west at an elevation of 3,360 ft (1,024 m), Timber Hollow Overlooks sits atop Timber Hollow. On either side of Timber Hollow are ridges that descend to the valley. The town of Ida is situated right beyond where the ridge of Nakedtop Mountain descends into the valley. Ida was one of the relocation settlements for families who lived within the park boundary during the establishment of Shenandoah in the 1930s.
audioDescription: This overlook faces west. There is a trail access from this overlook. Beyond a small meadow is a descent to Timber Hollow and a valley below. From the left is the Ridge of Nakedtop Mountain, descending into the Shenandoah Valley. Pollock Knob is the ridge to the right. The town of Ida sits at the bottom of the valley between where these two ridges hit the valley floor.

title: Traces Trailhead
listingDescription: Mathews Arm Campground (mile 22.2) | A hike that follows a trail around Mathews Arm Campground. Along the way, you’ll see traces left behind by former residents of the area.

images.altText: A concrete post with metal band around it pointing to the Traces Trail.
images.title: Traces Trailhead

bodyText:
A hike that follows a trail around Mathews Arm Campground. Along the way, you’ll see traces left behind by former residents of the area. Pets must be on a physical leash no longer than 6 feet at all times.

Distance: 1.7-mile circuit hike
Difficulty: Easiest (explanation of our hiking difficulty scale)
Hiking Time: 1 hours 15 minutes
Elevation Gain: 333 feet

Hike Description 

  1. From the Mathews Arm Campground Registration Parking Area (mile 22.2), take the blueblazed Traces Nature Trail around the campground. It will loop back around to your starting point.
audioDescription: A concrete post with a metal band around the top with the text, "Traces Trail" and an arrow pointing straight to a trail leading through the woods into the distance.

title: Trayfoot Mountain Overlook
listingDescription: Looking south and at an elevation of 2530 ft (771 m), from Trayfoot Mountain Overlook you will see Cedar and Pasture Fence Mountains in the distance. Trayfoot Mountain is far to the right and across Skyline Drive.

images.altText: View over field with rolling hills in the distance.
images.title: Trayfoot Mountain Overlook
images.caption: What's the view from Trayfoot Mountain Overlook?

bodyText: Looking south and at an elevation of 2530 ft (771 m), from Trayfoot Mountain Overlook you will see Cedar and Pasture Fence Mountains in the distance. Trayfoot Mountain is far to the right and across Skyline Drive.
audioDescription: This overlook faces south. There is a field that stretches into rolling hills in the distance. To the left is Cedar Mountain. Behind Cedar Mountain is Fox Mountain. The long mountain from the right is Pasture Fence Mountain.

title: Tunnel Parking Overlook
listingDescription: Looking east at an elevation of 2,510 ft (756 m), from Tunnel Parking Overlook you will view two larger mountains. Skinner Ridge is towards the right. Oventop Mountain is towards the left and a little farther away. Beyond where these two mountains meet is the town of Sperryville. Civilian Conservation Corps workers blasted through the hills of Marys Rock for three months before completing the tunnel that gave this overlook its name in 1932.

images.altText: View overlooking mountains.
images.title: Tunnel Parking Overlook
images.caption: What's the view from Tunnel Parking Overlook?

bodyText:
Looking east at an elevation of 2,510 ft (756 m), from Tunnel Parking Overlook you will view two larger mountains. Skinner Ridge is towards the right. Oventop Mountain is towards the left and a little farther away. Beyond where these two mountains meet is the town of Sperryville. Civilian Conservation Corps workers blasted through the hills of Marys Rock for three months before completing the tunnel that gave this overlook its name in 1932.
 

Historical Views

Tunnel Parking Overlook has long been one of the most popular overlooks in the Park. This image is from a busy Sunday morning in 1935 before Shenandoah National Park was officially established.
audioDescription: This overlook faces east towards mountains in the distance. On the left is Oventop Mountain. A little bit closer and on the right is Skinner Ridge. Beyond the v-shape where Oventop and Skinner Ridge intersect is the town of Sperryville.

title: Turk Mountain Overlook
listingDescription: At the Turk Mountain Overlook you will look straight to the quartzite covered peak of Turk Mountain. Facing northwest from an elevation of 2,720 ft (829 m) you will also look out to the Shenandoah Valley to the right of Turk Mountain and the Blue Ridge Mountains on the left. Turk Mountain takes its name from a family that lived in the area before the establishment of Shenandoah National Park.

images.altText: A view from a mountaintop looking toward another mountain.
images.title: Turk Mountain Overlook
images.caption: What's the view from Turk Mountain Overlook?

bodyText: At the Turk Mountain Overlook you will look straight to the quartzite covered peak of Turk Mountain. Facing northwest from an elevation of 2,720 ft (829 m) you will also look out to the Shenandoah Valley to the right of Turk Mountain and the Blue Ridge Mountains on the left. Turk Mountain takes its name from a family that lived in the area before the establishment of Shenandoah National Park.
audioDescription: This overlook faces northwest. Straight ahead is the peak of Turk Mountain. Descending to the left from Turk Mountain is Sawmill Ridge. Further left is the smaller and closer Scott Mountain. From Turk Mountain to the right the mountain descends and the Shenandoah Valley appears in the distance.

title: Turk Mountain Trailhead
listingDescription: Turk Mountain Parking Area (Mile 94.1) | A hike to the 2,981’ summit of Turk Mountain that provides a wonderful view to the west.

images.altText: A summer view of green bushes in the foreground and a large mountain in the right background.
images.title: Summer View from Turk Mountain Overlook

bodyText:
A hike to the 2,981 foot summit of Turk Mountain that provides a wonderful view to the west. Pets must be on a physical leash no longer than 6 feet at all times.

Distance: 2.2-mile round trip hike
Difficulty: Easiest (explanation of our hiking difficulty scale)
Hiking Time: 2 hours 15 minutes
Elevation Gain: 690 feet

Hike Description 

  1. From the Turk Mountain Parking Area (mile 94.1), cross Skyline Drive and take the Appalachian Trail south to the trailpost.
  2. Go right onto the Turk Mountain Trail and follow it to the summit for a wonderful view to the west.
  3. Retrace your steps to return to your starting point.
audioDescription: This overlook faces northwest. Straight ahead is the peak of Turk Mountain. Descending to the left from Turk Mountain is Sawmill Ridge. Further left is the smaller and closer Scott Mountain. From Turk Mountain to the right the mountain descends and the Shenandoah Valley appears in the distance.

title: Two Mile Run Overlook
listingDescription: Facing west-northwest from an elevation of 2,770 ft (844 m), at Two Mile Run Overlook you are face-to-face with the effects of fire on the ecosystem of Shenandoah National Park. The Rocky Mount fire spread through this area in April of 2016. High winds and dry conditions caused the fire to spread quickly. While it is believed that humans caused this fire, fire is a natural part of the ecosystem. Fires can clear out the forests fast-growing undergrowth and helps many native sp

images.altText: A line of burnt trees with mountains in the distance.
images.title: Two Mile Run Overlook
images.caption: What's the view from Two Mile Run Overlook?

bodyText: Facing west-northwest from an elevation of 2,770 ft (844 m), at Two Mile Run Overlook you are face-to-face with the effects of fire on the ecosystem of Shenandoah National Park. The Rocky Mount fire spread through this area in April of 2016. High winds and dry conditions caused the fire to spread quickly. While it is believed that humans caused this fire, fire is a natural part of the ecosystem. Fires can clear out the forests fast-growing undergrowth and helps many native species such as oaks and the Table Mountain pine. Campfires are not permitted in the backcountry.
audioDescription: The this overlook faces west-northwest. There is a field in the foreground surrounded by a line of trees. Mountains rise above in the distance beyond the trees. From the left is Brown Mountain, Two Mile Ridge, and Rocky Mount. Two Mile Run is the lower gap to the right of Two Mile Ridge. Further towards the horizon is the flatter Shenandoah Valley with the long ridge of Massanutten Mountain along the horizon.

bodyText: On really clear days and nights, you can actually see the Washington Monument from Thorofare Mountain Overlook, 74 miles in the distance!

title: Whiteoak Canyon Falls Lower Trailhead
listingDescription: Whiteoak Canyon Parking Area (Park Boundary) | An easier hike to the base of the lower falls in Whiteoak Canyon. Note that a Park entrance fee is still required.

images.altText: A mountain creek, its water smoothed from a long exposure, winding through rocks in fall.
images.title: Whiteoak Canyon

bodyText:
An easier hike to the base of the beautiful cascades and lower falls in Whiteoak Canyon. Note that a Park entrance fee is still required. Pets must be on a leash no longer than 6 feet at all times.

Distance: 2-mile round trip hike
Difficulty: Easiest (hiking difficulty scale)
Hiking Time: 1 hours 30 minutes
Elevation Gain: 500 feet

Hike Description 

  1. From the Whiteoak Canyon Parking Area at the Park boundary, begin on Whiteoak Canyon Trail and keep right at the intersection with Cedar Run Trail.
  2. Cross a small stream and continue to the base of the lower falls.
  3. Return by the same route.

Directions to boundary trailhead from Sperryville: Follow Route 211 to Route 522 south for 0.8-mile. Turn right on Route 231, follow 10.2 miles to Etlan, turn right on Route 643. Follow for 4.5 miles and turn right onto Route 600. Proceed 3.5 miles to parking area.

Directions to boundary trailhead from Madison: Route 29 Business, take 231 north for 5.6 miles to Route 670 at Banco. Continue 3.6 miles to Route 643 in Syria. Follow 0.8-mile on Route 643 to Route 600. Continue on Route 600 to the parking area.
audioDescription: The Whiteoak Falls Boundary Trailhead is a 36"x 54" color poster. The poster is organized into two columns. On the left the first column begins with the title, "Did You Know?" with a photograph of a waterfall cascading through bright red and orange leaves. This image is followed by the subtitle, "Gushing Over Waterfalls" with text underneath "If you want to see some waterfalls, you have come to the right place. Whiteoak Canyon boasts not one, not two, but a whole series of waterfalls and cascades! They range in height from 35 to 86 feet. Whiteoak Canyon's steep gorge and sheer rock walls make the perfect home for the rush of the trail's pools and cascades. Want even more waterfalls? Head on up the Cedar Run trail to see another three waterfalls gently flowing into deep green pools." Below this are two vertical images, one of a foggy path surrounded by trees, the other of a tall waterfalls surrounded by lush green vegetation. Another subtitle reads, "A Trail for All Seasons." The text below reads, "Each season brings a new level of appreciation for the waterfalls in Whiteoak Canyon. Springtime ushers in a canyon that is overflowing with an abundance of rushing water. In the summer, the cool, clear water offers relief from the season's heat. In autumn, the waterfalls make for a vivid backdrop to the canyon's spectacular foliage. In the winter, the falls form frozen cascades of ice that are suspended in air. And the waterfalls only tell a portion of this trail's annual story. Depending upon the season, Whiteoak Canyon is also home to an abundance of wildflowers, migrating butterflies, lush, moss-covered cliffs, and shy winter residents like bobcats and crayfish. No matter when you visit, there is so much to see and appreciate in White Oak Canyon!" Beginning the second column on the upper right is a 20"x20" topographic map oriented west. There is one trail highlighted in yellow on the map. Below the maps is the title "Suggested Hike" with the following text, "Hike: Whiteoak Falls 6.0-mile round trip, moderately strenuous, 4Â½ hours hiking time, 1600-foot elevation gain. Begin at Whiteoak Falls Trail and keep right at the intersection with Cedar Run Trail. Continue on past a series of falls and cascades. Return before crossing the large metal bridge above the upper falls. The trail to the upper falls is steep and challenging. Consider your physical conditioning before embarking on this route. Many people underestimate the amount of time and energy necessary to hike to the upper falls and return to the parking lot. Allow enough time to complete your hike before dark. There is no shuttle service in the Park." Below this is the subtitle "Shorter Version" with the text "2.0-mile round trip, easiest, 1Â½ hours hiking time, 500-foot elevation gain. Begin at Whiteoak Falls Trail and keep right at the intersection with Cedar Run Trail. Cross a small stream and arrive shortly at the base of the lower falls. Return by the same route." A red text box below the map gives important information that hikers need. The text reads, "Emergency 1-800-732-0911 (cell phone service is unreliable.) Before You Go! Pets must be on a leash at all times. It's dangerous and potentially deadly to climb on the rocks near waterfalls. Do not attempt to cross streams during icy conditions or flooding. Be sure you are physically able to complete the hike you've chosen. Take plenty of water-at least a quart per hour. Be sure you know your route. Free maps are available at entrance stations, visitor centers, and www.nps.gov/shen When you return from your hike, check for ticks. Be sure someone knows where you are and when to expect your return. - Filter or treat water from streams before drinking."

title: Whiteoak Canyon Falls Upper Trailhead
listingDescription: Whiteoak Canyon Parking Area (mile 42.6) | This challenging hike to cascades and waterfalls has been popular since the early days of Skyland Resort. This particular hike goes to the upper falls before returning.

images.altText: Looking downward over a rocky ledge at a tall waterfall cascading down a canyon in the fall.
images.title: Upper Whiteoak Falls

bodyText:
This challenging hike to cascades and waterfalls has been popular since the early days of Skyland Resort. This particular hike goes to the upper falls before returning. Pets must be on a physical leash no longer than 6 feet at all times.

Distance: 4.6-mile round trip hike
Difficulty: Moderate (hiking difficulty scale)
Hiking Time: 3 hours 30 minutes
Elevation Gain: 1,040 feet

Hike Description

  1. From the trailhead at the Whiteoak Canyon Parking Area (mile 42.6), take the Whiteoak Canyon Trail.
  2. Pass the junctions for the Old Rag Fire Road and the Limberlost Trail.
  3. About 2.3 miles from the start you will come to a rocky ledge with a view of the upper falls.
  4. Retrace your steps to return to the parking lot.
audioDescription: The Whiteoak Canyon Trailhead panel is a 36 by 54 inch color poster. On the upper left of the panel is a black and white historic photograph of a group of more than 30 early Skyland Resort visitors taken near the head of the falls. The text reads, "A Popular Playground - The waterfalls of Whiteoak Canyon may well be the reason that Shenandoah National Park even exists. Long before this area was a national park, it was a popular playground for the early visitors to Skyland Lodge. There was even a lodge in the area near the first falls complete with a bridge, a dam, a swimming pool, and bath houses! Fortunately, White Oak Canyon has returned at least partially to its natural state, but remnants of the lodge can still be seen in the stone staircase between the first and second waterfalls." The picture on the bottom left of the panel shows a hiker on a large boulder overlooking the cascading stream. The text reads, "A Walk on the Wild Side - White Oak Canyon is home to impressive waterfalls and cascades that range in height from 35 to 86 feet. As you make your way toward the falls, be sure to take in the rugged and wild scene unfolding before you. The canyon's steep gorge and sheer rock walls soar upward from the water while the falls start as a trickle and build into a rush of water that tumbles into the pools below." The top right of the panel is a 20 by 20 inch topographic map of the hike to Whiteoak Canyon. The trail is marked in yellow with a brown dashed line. The text reads, "Suggested Hikes: Hike #1: Upper White Oak Falls - 4.6-mile round trip, moderate, 3Â½ hour hiking time, 1,040 foot elevation gain. Follow the White Oak Canyon Trail and stay on this trail as you pass the junctions for the Old Rag Fire Road and the Limberlost Trail. About 2.3 miles from the start you will come to a rocky ledge that offers an excellent view of the upper falls. Retrace your steps to return to the parking lot. Remember that the return trip will be very steep." "Hike #2: White Oak Canyon - (This trail is marked in purple with a dashed line.) 7.3-mile round trip, strenuous, 6 hours hiking time, 2,150 foot elevation gain. Please consider your physical condition and available time before embarking on this hike. Follow the White Oak Canyon Trail past the upper falls for another 1.3 miles down the canyon to the lower falls. Return via the same route. The trail on this section is narrow, rocky, and steep." A red text box below the map gives important information that hikers need. The text reads, "Emergency 1-800-732-0911 (cell phone service is unreliable.) Before You Go! Pets must be on a leash at all times. It's dangerous and potentially deadly to climb on the rocks near waterfalls. Do not attempt to cross streams during icy conditions or flooding. Be sure you are physically able to complete the hike you've chosen. Take plenty of water-at least a quart per hour. Filter or treat water from streams before drinking. Be sure you know your route. Free maps are available at entrance stations, visitor centers, and www.nps.gov/shen - When you return from your hike, check for ticks. Be sure someone knows where you are and when to expect your return." A Hiking Difficulty Scale reads: "Easiest - A hike that is generally suitable for anyone who enjoys walking. Mostly level or with a slight incline. Generally less than 3 miles. Moderate - A moderate hike generally suitable for novice hikers seeking a bit of a challenge. The terrain will involve a moderate incline and may have some steeper sections. Generally 3 to 5 miles. Moderately Strenuous - Generally challenging for an unconditioned person. The terrain will involve a steady and often steep incline. Generally 5 to 8 miles. Strenuous - Will challenge most hikers. The hike will generally be longer and steeper, but may be deemed strenuous because of the elevation gain. Generally 7 to 10 miles. Very Strenuous. Only well-conditioned and well-prepared hikers should attempt. Generally long and steep, and may include rock scrambling, stream crossings, and other challenging terrain. Generally 8 miles and over."
